	boundary="=====================_23601877==.ALT"

--=====================_23601877==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit



Ethiopan Capital Celebrates Bob Marley's Birthday

By MARC LACEY

A
DDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 6 - If he had been on stage, Bob Marley would 
have waved his graying dreadlocks in the air and beseeched black people to 
continue struggling. In that lilting voice of his, he would have sung of 
love, of unity, of his beloved Ethiopia.

But Marley was only a memory, albeit a powerful one, at his 60th-birthday 
celebration today in the sprawling central square of the Ethiopian capital. 
So his wife, Rita, his sons, including Ziggy Marley, and numerous other 
admirers did the singing for the late reggae great, as tens of thousands of 
people jumped and gyrated to his trademark beat at a daylong concert titled 
"Africa Unite." Also performing were the singers Lauryn Hill, formerly of 
the Fugees; Angélique Kidjo from Benin; drummers from Burundi; and 
Ethiopian entertainers singing their versions of reggae.

It was a curious scene. Meskel Square, the spot where giant portraits of 
Marx and Lenin looked down on Ethiopians during the country's communist 
days, was decorated with likenesses of Marley. Among the revelers were 
beggars, prevailing on all the idealists to give them something to eat.

Ethiopia is regarded as the promised land for Rastafarians, the dreadlocked 
Jamaican spiritualists who gave Marley so much of his inspiration. That 
special status comes despite the poverty of the place, the regular bouts of 
starvation, the sicknesses that fell so many Ethiopians. Indeed, many here 
mock the Rastas.

Nearly a quarter of a century after Marley's death, Rastas and other reggae 
lovers have flocked here from all over the world to remember him and his 
powerful litany of lyrics. The Marley fans came from Jamaica, the 
birthplace of Rastafarianism, and from other countries that have fallen 
under reggae's spell. Besides celebrating, one of the goals of the 
gathering was to win over the many people in this conservative Christian 
and Muslim country who view Rastas with deep suspicion. The concert was 
organized by the Bob and Rita Marley Foundation, a philanthropic group that 
works in Ethiopia. It was the first time that the birthday festivities had 
been held outside of Jamaica since Marley died of cancer at 36 in 1981.

The Ethiopian government sanctioned the concert because it saw the influx 
of so many visitors as an economic boon. But the arrival of the Rastas was 
unnerving for some locals, who have trouble grappling with their marijuana 
use and the belief among many of them that Haile Selassie, the country's 
deposed emperor, was more deity than man.

"This is our pilgrimage country," said a man who calls himself Jah Eliejah 
Adanjah, an aging Rasta from the Caribbean island of Guadalupe who was 
setting foot on Ethiopian soil for the first time. "The feeling is so 
strong that I can't find words to express it."

Marley's widow, Rita, gave an indication of the deep ties Rastas feel 
toward Ethiopia when she said last month that she planned to dig up the 
singer's remains in Jamaica one day and rebury them in his spiritual home 
of Africa. Her remarks drew fierce criticism in Jamaica, Marley's 
birthplace, but she said it had been her husband's lifelong wish to reach 
the promised land.

In the raucous crowd of revelers were some Japanese Rastas, who said that 
Marley's message of black empowerment appeals to anybody who is rebellious 
inside. "I feel the songs as much as anyone else," said Chihiro Nakamori, 
25, of Kyoto, who had fledgling dreadlocks hanging from his head. "When I 
smoke the herb, I connect with another world." Rastafarians believe that 
smoking marijuana is a sacrament sanctioned by the Bible.

There were Ethiopian Rastas, as well, young people in dreadlocks who said 
Marley's music spoke to them but that some Rasta beliefs did not. One group 
of them chewed khat, a popular stimulant here, instead of smoking marijuana.

Rastas named their movement after Haile Selassie, who was known as Ras 
Tafari before becoming Ethiopia's emperor in 1930. The movement, which came 
of age at a time when Africa was under white rule, deified Selassie, a 
black emperor who symbolized an independent Africa. Ethiopians are 
extremely divided on the merits of Selassie, a man who lifted the country's 
image on the international stage but ruled in an authoritarian manner.

Before he was deposed in 1974, and murdered the following year, Selassie 
set aside land for those in the black diaspora who sought to help develop 
Ethiopia. Hundreds of Rastas responded and settled in the remote village of 
Shashemene, where they continue to worship him.

But the presence of Rastas in their midst has not calmed the concerns of 
some Ethiopians, who see the way of life of Rastafarians as a bad influence 
for their children. "There's a hidden agenda here," said Dr. Henok G. 
Hiwot, an Ethiopian who speaks to parents about dangers young people face 
if they adopt a Rastafarian way of life: "This is a Bob Marley celebration, 
but we fear they're trying to attract Ethiopians to their culture. We don't 
want that."

Critics of Rastafarianism had a message for the many visitors: find another 
promised land.

During the concert, members of various Protestant churches slipped quietly 
through the crowd handing out pamphlets that attacked the deification of 
Selassie by Rastafarians. It was a risky enterprise, as the authorities had 
detained eight young people who were caught with the pamphlets on eve of 
the concert that the government had endorsed.

Many, though, saw no harm. Abuna Paulos, the patriarch of the influential 
Ethiopian Orthodox Church, of which Selassie and later Marley were members, 
delivered the celebration's opening prayer. "The church's task is to preach 
any time to anyone, no matter their hairstyle," said the gray-bearded 
patriarch, calling Marley his "spiritual son."

At scholarly discussions leading up to the concert, Marley's lyrics were 
deconstructed and applied to present-day problems. Azeb Mesfin, the wife of 
Prime Minister Meles Zenawi, spoke of how the Marley hit "No Woman, No Cry" 
inspires struggling women in Africa. When it comes to AIDS, which is taking 
the lives of so many Africans, she referred to another Marley song: "We 
should 'get up, stand up' and defeat this terrible scourge," she said.

The revelers who turned out in the beating sun to soak up Marley's music 
were similarly adapting the lyrics to their own lives. Wouhib Bayou, 29, an 
Ethiopian who says he finds most Rasta ideology compatible with his Muslim 
beliefs, said "Waiting in Vain," one of Marley's love songs, perfectly 
captured his frustration with Ethiopia.

"When you see other countries on TV and you see how advanced they are, you 
long for that kind of wealth," he said. "I'm waiting for that right here in 
Ethiopia, but I'm waiting in vain."




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_23601877==.ALT

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

<h2><b>Ethiopan Capital Celebrates Bob Marley's
Birthday</b></h2><font size=2><b>By MARC LACEY <br><br>
</b></font>
<img src="cid:6.2.0.14.2.20050206233837.02d15130@localhost.0" width=33 height=33 alt="A">
</b><font size=3>DDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 6 - If he had been on stage,
Bob Marley would have waved his graying dreadlocks in the air and
beseeched black people to continue struggling. In that lilting voice of
his, he would have sung of love, of unity, of his beloved
Ethiopia.<br><br>
But Marley was only a memory, albeit a powerful one, at his 60th-birthday
celebration today in the sprawling central square of the Ethiopian
capital. So his wife, Rita, his sons, including Ziggy Marley, and
numerous other admirers did the singing for the late reggae great, as
tens of thousands of people jumped and gyrated to his trademark beat at a
daylong concert titled &quot;Africa Unite.&quot; Also performing were the
singers Lauryn Hill, formerly of the Fugees; Angélique Kidjo from Benin;
drummers from Burundi; and Ethiopian entertainers singing their versions
of reggae.<br><br>
It was a curious scene. Meskel Square, the spot where giant portraits of
Marx and Lenin looked down on Ethiopians during the country's communist
days, was decorated with likenesses of Marley. Among the revelers were
beggars, prevailing on all the idealists to give them something to
eat.<br><br>
Ethiopia is regarded as the promised land for Rastafarians, the
dreadlocked Jamaican spiritualists who gave Marley so much of his
inspiration. That special status comes despite the poverty of the place,
the regular bouts of starvation, the sicknesses that fell so many
Ethiopians. Indeed, many here mock the Rastas.<br><br>
Nearly a quarter of a century after Marley's death, Rastas and other
reggae lovers have flocked here from all over the world to remember him
and his powerful litany of lyrics. The Marley fans came from Jamaica, the
birthplace of Rastafarianism, and from other countries that have fallen
under reggae's spell. Besides celebrating, one of the goals of the
gathering was to win over the many people in this conservative Christian
and Muslim country who view Rastas with deep suspicion. The concert was
organized by the Bob and Rita Marley Foundation, a philanthropic group
that works in Ethiopia. It was the first time that the birthday
festivities had been held outside of Jamaica since Marley died of cancer
at 36 in 1981. <br><br>
The Ethiopian government sanctioned the concert because it saw the influx
of so many visitors as an economic boon. But the arrival of the Rastas
was unnerving for some locals, who have trouble grappling with their
marijuana use and the belief among many of them that Haile Selassie, the
country's deposed emperor, was more deity than man.<br><br>
&quot;This is our pilgrimage country,&quot; said a man who calls himself
Jah Eliejah Adanjah, an aging Rasta from the Caribbean island of
Guadalupe who was setting foot on Ethiopian soil for the first time.
&quot;The feeling is so strong that I can't find words to express
it.&quot;<br><br>

toward Ethiopia when she said last month that she planned to dig up the

of Africa. Her remarks drew fierce criticism in Jamaica, Marley's
birthplace, but she said it had been her husband's lifelong wish to reach
the promised land.<br><br>

Marley's message of black empowerment appeals to anybody who is
rebellious inside. &quot;I feel the songs as much as anyone else,&quot;
said Chihiro Nakamori, 25, of Kyoto, who had fledgling dreadlocks hanging
from his head. &quot;When I smoke the herb, I connect with another
world.&quot; Rastafarians believe that smoking marijuana is a sacrament
sanctioned by the Bible.<br><br>

Marley's music spoke to them but that some Rasta beliefs did not. One
group of them chewed khat, a popular stimulant here, instead of smoking
marijuana.<br><br>

Tafari before becoming Ethiopia's emperor in 1930. The movement, which
came of age at a time when Africa was under white rule, deified Selassie,
a black emperor who symbolized an independent Africa. Ethiopians are
extremely divided on the merits of Selassie, a man who lifted the
country's image on the international stage but ruled in an authoritarian
manner.<br><br>
Before he was deposed in 1974, and murdered the following year, Selassie
set aside land for those in the black diaspora who sought to help develop
Ethiopia. Hundreds of Rastas responded and settled in the remote village
of Shashemene, where they continue to worship him.<br><br>
But the presence of Rastas in their midst has not calmed the concerns of
some Ethiopians, who see the way of life of Rastafarians as a bad
influence for their children. &quot;There's a hidden agenda here,&quot;
said Dr. Henok G. Hiwot, an Ethiopian who speaks to parents about dangers
young people face if they adopt a Rastafarian way of life: &quot;This is
a Bob Marley celebration, but we fear they're trying to attract
Ethiopians to their culture. We don't want that.&quot;<br><br>

another promised land.<br><br>
During the concert, members of various Protestant churches slipped
quietly through the crowd handing out pamphlets that attacked the
deification of Selassie by Rastafarians. It was a risky enterprise, as
the authorities had detained eight young people who were caught with the
pamphlets on eve of the concert that the government had endorsed.
<br><br>
Many, though, saw no harm. Abuna Paulos, the patriarch of the influential
Ethiopian Orthodox Church, of which Selassie and later Marley were
members, delivered the celebration's opening prayer. &quot;The church's
task is to preach any time to anyone, no matter their hairstyle,&quot;
said the gray-bearded patriarch, calling Marley his &quot;spiritual
son.&quot;<br><br>

deconstructed and applied to present-day problems. Azeb Mesfin, the wife
of Prime Minister Meles Zenawi, spoke of how the Marley hit &quot;No
Woman, No Cry&quot; inspires struggling women in Africa. When it comes to
AIDS, which is taking the lives of so many Africans, she referred to
another Marley song: &quot;We should 'get up, stand up' and defeat this
terrible scourge,&quot; she said.<br><br>

were similarly adapting the lyrics to their own lives. Wouhib Bayou, 29,
an Ethiopian who says he finds most Rasta ideology compatible with his
Muslim beliefs, said &quot;Waiting in Vain,&quot; one of Marley's love
songs, perfectly captured his frustration with Ethiopia.<br><br>
&quot;When you see other countries on TV and you see how advanced they
are, you long for that kind of wealth,&quot; he said. &quot;I'm waiting
for that right here in Ethiopia, but I'm waiting in vain.&quot;<br><br>

  Ethiopan Capital Celebrates Bob Marley's Birthday
  By MARC LACEY=20

   DDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 6 - If he had been on stage, Bob Marley =
would have waved his graying dreadlocks in the air and beseeched black =
people to continue struggling. In that lilting voice of his, he would =
have sung of love, of unity, of his beloved Ethiopia.

  But Marley was only a memory, albeit a powerful one, at his =
60th-birthday celebration today in the sprawling central square of the =
Ethiopian capital. So his wife, Rita, his sons, including Ziggy Marley, =
and numerous other admirers did the singing for the late reggae great, =
as tens of thousands of people jumped and gyrated to his trademark beat =
at a daylong concert titled "Africa Unite." Also performing were the =
singers Lauryn Hill, formerly of the Fugees; Ang=E9lique Kidjo from =
Benin; drummers from Burundi; and Ethiopian entertainers singing their =
versions of reggae.

  It was a curious scene. Meskel Square, the spot where giant portraits =
of Marx and Lenin looked down on Ethiopians during the country's =
communist days, was decorated with likenesses of Marley. Among the =
revelers were beggars, prevailing on all the idealists to give them =
something to eat.

  Ethiopia is regarded as the promised land for Rastafarians, the =
dreadlocked Jamaican spiritualists who gave Marley so much of his =
inspiration. That special status comes despite the poverty of the place, =
the regular bouts of starvation, the sicknesses that fell so many =
Ethiopians. Indeed, many here mock the Rastas.

  Nearly a quarter of a century after Marley's death, Rastas and other =
reggae lovers have flocked here from all over the world to remember him =
and his powerful litany of lyrics. The Marley fans came from Jamaica, =
the birthplace of Rastafarianism, and from other countries that have =
fallen under reggae's spell. Besides celebrating, one of the goals of =
the gathering was to win over the many people in this conservative =
Christian and Muslim country who view Rastas with deep suspicion. The =
concert was organized by the Bob and Rita Marley Foundation, a =
philanthropic group that works in Ethiopia. It was the first time that =
the birthday festivities had been held outside of Jamaica since Marley =
died of cancer at 36 in 1981.=20

  The Ethiopian government sanctioned the concert because it saw the =
influx of so many visitors as an economic boon. But the arrival of the =
Rastas was unnerving for some locals, who have trouble grappling with =
their marijuana use and the belief among many of them that Haile =

  "This is our pilgrimage country," said a man who calls himself Jah =

is so strong that I can't find words to express it."

that Marley's message of black empowerment appeals to anybody who is =
rebellious inside. "I feel the songs as much as anyone else," said =

from his head. "When I smoke the herb, I connect with another world." =
Rastafarians believe that smoking marijuana is a sacrament sanctioned by =
the Bible.

said Marley's music spoke to them but that some Rasta beliefs did not. =

smoking marijuana.

Tafari before becoming Ethiopia's emperor in 1930. The movement, which =

authoritarian manner.

help develop Ethiopia. Hundreds of Rastas responded and settled in the =
remote village of Shashemene, where they continue to worship him.

  But the presence of Rastas in their midst has not calmed the concerns =
of some Ethiopians, who see the way of life of Rastafarians as a bad =
influence for their children. "There's a hidden agenda here," said Dr. =
Henok G. Hiwot, an Ethiopian who speaks to parents about dangers young =
people face if they adopt a Rastafarian way of life: "This is a Bob =

their culture. We don't want that."

  Critics of Rastafarianism had a message for the many visitors: find =
another promised land.

quietly through the crowd handing out pamphlets that attacked the =

the authorities had detained eight young people who were caught with the =
pamphlets on eve of the concert that the government had endorsed.=20

influential Ethiopian Orthodox Church, of which Selassie and later =

were deconstructed and applied to present-day problems. Azeb Mesfin, the =
wife of Prime Minister Meles Zenawi, spoke of how the Marley hit "No =
Woman, No Cry" inspires struggling women in Africa. When it comes to =
AIDS, which is taking the lives of so many Africans, she referred to =
another Marley song: "We should 'get up, stand up' and defeat this =
terrible scourge," she said.

  The revelers who turned out in the beating sun to soak up Marley's =

Bayou, 29, an Ethiopian who says he finds most Rasta ideology compatible =
with his Muslim beliefs, said "Waiting in Vain," one of Marley's love =
songs, perfectly captured his frustration with Ethiopia.

  "When you see other countries on TV and you see how advanced they are, =
you long for that kind of wealth," he said. "I'm waiting for that right =
here in Ethiopia, but I'm waiting in vain."

  "The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the =
hands of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An =
invisible empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
  -Woodrow Wilson

  "Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the =
look on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might =
have bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look =
on his face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you =
might be willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
  -Daniel Berrigan

  "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of =
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually =
become visible."
  -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Cheeba? (was innocentchild.in.phoenix.az)

> Anyone know the origin of the term "cheeba"?  I have
> an old jazz record by George Benson caleed Erotic
> Moods on which he discusses "Smoking Cheeba Cheeba"
> I've always assumed it was marijuana...

"They blaze cheeba-cheeba
And dominate the weaker on the street
Hungry bellies only love what they eat
And it's hard to compete
When they're smiling with your heart in their teeth
And the odds is stacked high beyond and beneath"

you assumed correctly.

me likes Phoenix -- much to appreciate there. if Swell Records was
located in the Bay Area I'd probably own more trance than breaks --
truly awesome hard trance selection. most of the hard trance I have
hidden away comes from Swell.

didn't see too much of the scene there, I was only there about a
month, but what I saw I liked. definitely seemed more ravey than
clubby, but then I generally pay more attention to raves than to clubs
in the first place.

-- 
DJ Soundwave

Date: Mon, 7 Feb 2005 19:05:06 -0800
From: Sean Casey <sean@cloudfactory.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20050208030506.GL17666@cloudfactory.org>
Mail-Followup-To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Mime-Version: 1.0

Content-Disposition: inline
User-Agent: Mutt/1.3.28i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Why North America Is Not a Rhythm Nation

I got rhythm,
I got music.
I got my guy,
Who could ask for anything more?
- George Gershwin/Ira Gershwin

North American adults have problems perceiving and reproducing
irregular rhythms. That's what past studies have shown, and some
new research has addressed the question of whether our seeming
inability to dance to a different tune should be chalked up to
nature or culture. New findings point to a harmonious blend of
both.

Music has a communal quality in virtually all cultures, inspiring
dancing, clapping, instrument playing, marching, and chanting.
Despite what seems to be a universal to coordinate movement,
listeners are frequently challenged by the rhythmic patterns of
other cultures. North American adults, for example, have difficulty
perceiving rhythmic patterns in Balkan music.

Erin E. Hannon, Cornell University, and Sandra Trehub, University
of Toronto, found that Bulgarian and Macedonian adults process
complex musical rhythms better than North American adults, who
often struggle with anything other than simple western meter. To
gauge the significance of culture influences our ability to process
musical patterns, the researchers also conducted experiments with
North American infants and found that they too were better than
North American adults.

http://www.psychologicalscience.org/media/releases/2005/pr050207.cfm

(Hmmm....)

Priced at $179 there.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: DJ Mariano on An Epiphany of Sound Thur.

On a quest to help bring about a revival of the PsyTrance scene in San
Francisco, ex KZSU-er DJ Mariano will make a return appearance on An
Epiphany of Sound this Thur., 2/10, from 9a-noon.  He's been DJing since
he was only 17, so you know he can bring it to you like you like it,
with musicians like Psycat, Infected Mushrooom, producers from Medium
records and more.  He's all about making you wanna dance!!  (Just don't
try doing it while you're driving.)

Listen in at 90.1 FM in the bay area and online at
http://kzsulive.stanford.edu between 9a and noon this Thur.  We'll also
be giving away CDs and tickets to the Gravity CD Release party from
Artemis this Fri. as well as more stuff!

Peace.

-----Original Message-----
From: DJ Soundwave [mailto:dj.soundwave@gmail.com] 
Sent: Monday, February 07, 2005 2:15 PM
To: sfr
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Cheeba? (was innocentchild.in.phoenix.az)

> Anyone know the origin of the term "cheeba"?  I have
> an old jazz record by George Benson caleed Erotic
> Moods on which he discusses "Smoking Cheeba Cheeba"
> I've always assumed it was marijuana...

"They blaze cheeba-cheeba
And dominate the weaker on the street
Hungry bellies only love what they eat
And it's hard to compete
When they're smiling with your heart in their teeth
And the odds is stacked high beyond and beneath"

you assumed correctly.

me likes Phoenix -- much to appreciate there. if Swell Records was
located in the Bay Area I'd probably own more trance than breaks --
truly awesome hard trance selection. most of the hard trance I have
hidden away comes from Swell.

didn't see too much of the scene there, I was only there about a
month, but what I saw I liked. definitely seemed more ravey than
clubby, but then I generally pay more attention to raves than to clubs
in the first place.

-- 
DJ Soundwave

Evil Breaks presents...

DIRTY
Saturday, February 19th
@ 330 Ritch, SF
2 rooms a'rockin'
9pm - 3am
$7 b4 11 / $10 after

Yeah you heard that right. DIRTY is back and comin at you with some 
nastiness. Come check out our new monthly venue that we'll be sharing with 
Subscience.  For our first night, we've got some wicked breaks and dirty 
techno.  Come to get down.

Featuring:
FUTURE FUNK SQUAD
(Functional breaks/Island/En:vision/Default/Cryptic) - UK
This man needs no introduction.  Making beats since 1999, Future Funk Squad 
has produced a consistent stream of breakbeat stormers and remixed the likes 
of Moloko, Stanton Warriors and Koma+Bones.  With over 10 years of DJing 
experience, he will do the unthinkably nasty to your earholes!

Breakbeat Extravaganza:
Smoove (Space Cowboys/Newsbreakz/Opel) - Nitevibe Dreamteam 2005
Aaron Jae vs. Bam (Evil Breaks/AaronJae.com/Invibe)

Marco (*thwap!*/substructure)

Andy W (Resource Records/Viberation)
Juan Segovia (Hugger-Mugger/tech-on)
Gamma vs. Mek (Techno-truth/Stilldream)

9pm - 3am
@ 330 Ritch

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: A funny thing happened yesterday...


A funny thing happened yesterday. I started working on a client site in 
San Mateo last month. Low and behold, going through the company directory 
I see a name that I am quite familiar with: my predecessor :)

The name in the email directory was: dhchung

So just out of curiousity, I walked through the engineering department to 
see if my hunch was correct, and sure enough, it was!

Derek Chung is working on site at the same client I am! What a small 
world.

It is really nice to see him, I haven't seen him since the SFR 10 Year 
Anniversary in 2002.

For those who didn't know, Derek did the calendar before myself and 
after Brian Behlendorf.

I want to say thanks to Derek for all of his efforts implementing the 
gencal.cgi version of the calendar, the years of his service to running 
the SFR calendar, and eventually passing it off to me in November 1998. 
Much love to the SFR community.

It's a small world afterall.

Karina
--

******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

The recent discussion here of the Metro was followed by a request, on 
MySpace, to be added by "Metrosexual" as a "friend."  Now I don't know 
"Metrosexual".....or do I?  No matter.  He is a sort of composite, as it were.

Anyhow "Metrosexual" has described himself in some detail on his MySpace 
profile and I thought I share for edutainment purposes.  Think I should 
"add" him?

Love,

Apollo


Metrosexual's Interests:


General <http://www.myspace.com/#>His intrests are dating, 
<http://www.myspace.com/#>wine tasting, <http://www.myspace.com/#>poetry 
reading even if he doesn't understand it. <http://www.myspace.com/#>Going 
to the theater, <http://www.myspace.com/#>seeing art films and professing 
his love of children.

Music <http://www.myspace.com/#>The metro will generally say he enjoys all 
forms of music so as to cover his bases. <http://www.myspace.com/#>In his 
IPOD you will see everything from Al Green to Green Day. 
<http://www.myspace.com/#>The phantom of the opera to Fugazi. 
<http://www.myspace.com/#>Dido to Tupac. 
<http://www.myspace.com/#>Metallica to Mozart. <http://www.myspace.com/#>He 
will know only two lines to each song, <http://www.myspace.com/#>but will 
make you fully aware he knows those two lines just so you believe him to be 
a connoisseur of music. <http://www.myspace.com/#>Just don't ask him to 
spell connoisseur

Movies <http://www.myspace.com/#>The metros movie collection will be vast 
and extensive. <http://www.myspace.com/#>With the advent of the DVD he has 
a new way of showing just how cool he is by owning all of your favorite 
movies, <http://www.myspace.com/#>because he owns every movie. 
<http://www.myspace.com/#>Inside you will find every Pacino and DeNiro 
film. <http://www.myspace.com/#>He will profess his love of gangster movies 
while he sits home at 1 p.<http://www.myspace.com/#>m. 
<http://www.myspace.com/#>on a sunday afternoon after football season and 
watches Finding Nemo. <http://www.myspace.com/#>He will own all 100 movies 
on the American Film Institutes top 100 list, <http://www.myspace.com/#>but 
will only enjoy 4 of them. <http://www.myspace.com/#>The metros "private 
movie" collection will be stored safely away so as not to inhibit his 
"caring and sensitive" side. <http://www.myspace.com/#>However, 
<http://www.myspace.com/#>ladies, <http://www.myspace.com/#>you will be 
secretly videotaped because the metro knows there's a good chance he'll be 
alone at age 50 and need something to look back on.

Television <http://www.myspace.com/#>The simpson and Family Guy. 
<http://www.myspace.com/#>Queer Eye for the Straight Guy. 
<http://www.myspace.com/#>And all sporting events. 
<http://www.myspace.com/#>Conan O'Brien and the Daily Show as well are 
required viewing.

Books <http://www.myspace.com/#>His books are magazines.

Heroes <http://www.myspace.com/#>Derek Zoolander.

Groups: 
<http://www.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=groups.groupProfile&groupID=100007137&Mytoken=20050209074121>Make 
Out Club, 
<http://www.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=groups.groupProfile&groupID=100000065&Mytoken=20050209074121>looking 
for new friends, 
<http://www.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=groups.groupProfile&groupID=100023108&Mytoken=20050209074121>BoysMakeOut,

of sex,

S E X A H O L I C S ::::::---, 
<http://www.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=groups.groupProfile&groupID=100019240&Mytoken=20050209074121>Women 
of MySpace with the Sweetest Smiles!, 
<http://www.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=groups.groupProfile&groupID=100004111&Mytoken=20050209074121>Swingers 
Personals, 
<http://www.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=groups.groupProfile&groupID=100011452&Mytoken=20050209074121>Let's 
Makeout

About me:

The Metro is generally kind and accepting. He will not spend more time than 
his girlfriend in the bathroom, but will spend the exact same amount of 
time, regardless of hair length. He will only date the *trophy* girlfriend, 
however he will "slum it" with a fuck buddy. Point of fact, the trophy 
girlfriend has a wide range of beauty. Most will be the superficial club 
queen who looks like her makeup has been applied by a shotgun and the 
streaks in her hair look like lane markers on a highway. Essential reading 
for him is GQ, Esquire, Maxim, Stuff, Blender, Entertainment Weekly, US 
weekly, The Wall Street Journal, and CNN.com. He will max out his credit 
cards buying clothing for himself and drinks for his friends. He will spend 
entire paychecks to impress a girl he's trying to date. He will constantly 
ask for reassurance but insist he doesn't need it. He's not gay but will 
have a list of five guys he'd screw, but they have to be a "Guy's Guy". 
Most popular choices are Brad Pitt, Ed Norton, Billy Bob Thornton, Tom 
Ford, George Clooney, Johnny Depp, Becks, Freddie Ljunberg, Hugh Grant, 
Clive Owen, Alex Rodriguez and Michael Jordan. If you ask him to name his 
top five designers they will be Versace, Armani, Gucci, Prada and Cavalli. 
The majority of his wardrobe will be from Banana Republic or H&M, however 
when he does bust out an item from one of his fave designers everyone in 
the room will know about it and how much he paid for it. The label will be 
proudly displayed at all times. He will spend an entire day watching a 
"Queer Eye" marathon. He more than likely has a pair of socks that costs 
over 25 dollars, for when he wants to feel special. He will routinely spend 
over 100 dollars per month on skincare products, which does not include 
getting facials. Also he will probably drive a 3 series BMW, a lower class 
Mercedes, or an Audi A4. All will be purchased used but they will swear 
they've been the only owner if you just meet them. He will also own a 
blackberry and an IPOD as well as have every cable station hooked into his 
50" plasma tv and his eight thousand dollar surround system that he had to 
spend four days learning to operate. Nails will be kept clean and 
maintained at all times as well as hair and breath. He will also mention 
from time to time that he is having a fat day and will need to be at the 
gym for the next two weeks 24/7. While in the locker room at the gym he 
will check out every penis available to see if he actually has any worth, 
since the metros penis size is directly proportional to the amount of 
material possessions he has. Once again, this is out of metro curiosity, 
not homo happy time. If you or someone you know is a metrosexual, don't 
worry. It's ok. It's not a bad thing, enjoy them or yourself.

Whom I'd like to meet:

The Metro wants to meet anyone he can impress.





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

> and the 
> streaks in her hair look like lane markers on a highway.
> Essential reading 
> for him is GQ, Esquire, Maxim, Stuff, Blender, Entertainment
> Weekly, US 
> weekly, The Wall Street Journal, and CNN.com. He will max out
> his credit 
> cards buying clothing for himself and drinks for his friends.
> He will spend 
> entire paychecks to impress a girl he's trying to date. He
> will constantly 
> ask for reassurance but insist he doesn't need it. He's not
> gay but will 
> have a list of five guys he'd screw, but they have to be a
> "Guy's Guy". 
> Most popular choices are Brad Pitt, Ed Norton, Billy Bob
> Thornton, Tom 
> Ford, George Clooney, Johnny Depp, Becks, Freddie Ljunberg,
> Hugh Grant, 
> Clive Owen, Alex Rodriguez and Michael Jordan. If you ask him
> to name his 
> top five designers they will be Versace, Armani, Gucci, Prada
> and Cavalli. 
> The majority of his wardrobe will be from Banana Republic or
> H&M, however 
> when he does bust out an item from one of his fave designers
> everyone in 
> the room will know about it and how much he paid for it. The
> label will be 
> proudly displayed at all times. He will spend an entire day
> watching a 
> "Queer Eye" marathon. He more than likely has a pair of socks
> that costs 
> over 25 dollars, for when he wants to feel special. He will
> routinely spend 
> over 100 dollars per month on skincare products, which does
> not include 
> getting facials. Also he will probably drive a 3 series BMW,
> a lower class 
> Mercedes, or an Audi A4. All will be purchased used but they
> will swear 
> they've been the only owner if you just meet them. He will
> also own a 
> blackberry and an IPOD as well as have every cable station
> hooked into his 
> 50" plasma tv and his eight thousand dollar surround system
> that he had to 
> spend four days learning to operate. Nails will be kept clean
> and 
> maintained at all times as well as hair and breath. He will
> also mention 
> from time to time that he is having a fat day and will need
> to be at the 
> gym for the next two weeks 24/7. While in the locker room at
> the gym he 
> will check out every penis available to see if he actually
> has any worth, 
> since the metros penis size is directly proportional to the
> amount of 
> material possessions he has. Once again, this is out of metro
> curiosity, 
> not homo happy time. If you or someone you know is a
> metrosexual, don't 
> worry. It's ok. It's not a bad thing, enjoy them or yourself.
> 
> Whom I'd like to meet:
> 
> The Metro wants to meet anyone he can impress.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> 
> House Music 101: 
> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 
> 
> "The government, which was designed for the people, has got
> into the hands 
> of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An
> invisible 
> empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
> -Woodrow Wilson
> 
> "Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved
> man, the look 
> on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you
> might have 
> bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that
> look on his 
> face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you
> might be 
> willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little,
> even."
> -Daniel Berrigan
> 
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are
> ahead of the 
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will
> gradually become 
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

My ramblings FOR the DJs
I call out to you from afar.
Thank you for the music
It helps me through the hard times
The late night insomnia
Memories of the past
A boring job but the beat goes on
All life passes by and the summer is long gone
But my happy feet keep dancing in my dreams.

Greg

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Recommendation for internet radio stations

I have many of my own recommendations, I've asked this before and am 
always seeking something new to Bump musically through the work 
day. Does anyone here have good suggestions for internet radio stations? 
Possible genres (not limited to these) of interest are:

acidhouse, breakbeat, breaks, classical, deathcore, deep house, dnb, drum 
& bass, electro, electronica, euro dance, freestyle, gabber, garage, goa, 
goa trance, happy hardcore, hardcore, hardhouse, house, jazz, jungle, 
lounge core, progressive house, psytrance, speedcore, techno, terrorcore, 
trance, triphop.

<3 Karina

www.protonradio.com   has tons of different shows. Lots of prog. house - but 
my favorite is "Futurized Radio", which is a HOOOOOOT HOT HOT breakbeat 
show - they archive the previous weeks show too , so you can always hear 
whatever was on the week prior...

Werd.

SamuraiFM has some good shit too - mainly the TCR Breakbeat show.

References: <20050209114001.J32785@taz3.hyperreal.org>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Recommendation for internet radio stations

I just got into icebergradio.com because of their breakbeat channel. 
They have a ton of different genres they cover so you may want to poke
around the site.

breaksfm.com runs a good show from Friday through the end of the
weekend, every week.

somafm.com is great for a lot of different music.  Their groove salad
channel is the shit.

00bliss.com is a good one as well but it's hit or miss as to when
their station is up.  I end up looking for them whenever I am on in
the winamp radio search.

bassdrive is good too for dnb.  My friends that are REALLY into dnb swear by it.

Hope that helps.

Subject: [sfraves] SRR:  Love Potion from Adnan

--=====================_1252380==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

From: DJ Adnan
Title: Love Potion

Here's White Magic Recipe for Love:


In a cooking Pot
Mix 4 cups of water with
2 table spoons of Cinnamon
1 table spoon of honey
2 small slices of mango (eat the rest)
1 tea spoon of cayenne pepper (for hot love)
Bring it to all to a boil
Turn it off and add petals of 4 red roses,
Transfer the mixture from the pot to a glass Jar
And let it sit outside under the night sky.

In the morning take a shower and then use the Love potion all over your 
body, little by little!
During that, chant for Love

Believe it and it will work!!!

Happy Valentine's
Adnan




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  What's In Popeye's Pipe?

--=====================_1642762==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit



What's In Popeye's Pipe?




By Dana Larsen, Cannabis Culture
Posted on February 8, 2005

Popeye is one of the world's most well-known and beloved animated 
characters. Since his creation, the pipe-puffing Popeye has become a global 
phenomenon, with millions of kids heartily munching on spinach in the hopes 
that it will make them as strong as the legendary sailor-man.

Yet is the spinach which gives Popeye his super-strength really a metaphor 
for another magical herb? Have children around the world been adoring a 
hero who is really a heavy consumer of the forbidden weed  marijuana?

The evidence is circumstantial, but it is there, and when added together it 
presents a compelling picture that, for many readers at least, Popeye's 
strength-giving spinach is meant as a clear metaphor for the miraculous 
powers of marijuana.

MORE:  http://www.alternet.org/drugreporter/21206/




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] SRR: Recommendation for internet radio stations

My friend runs http://staticbeats.com

I highly recommend it for work or actually anytime really.  Super tasteful, 
mellow, work-friendly IDM and downtempo and generally great electronic 
music.  He's a real connoisseur and the library of music he has legally 
licensed for the webcast is massive... he's been building it up for years.  
I think he sent an email to another list the other day saying they had 
something like over 100,000 albums cleared for use on there.

As a side note, the website itself is also really robust, it's got a large 
membership and a ton of electronic music news and reviews, forums and what 
not.  The site displays playlists and current song playing, and I think 
provides options to purchase the music through various outlets like iTunes 
or Amazon if you hear something you're hyped about randomly.

Chris

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>

	sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <BAY103-F42E66212F8DC1B77F66304D0750@phx.gbl> <BAY21-DAV12EB3E70CAE5BE1D661CB185750@phx.gbl>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <BAY21-DAV12EB3E70CAE5BE1D661CB185750@phx.gbl>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] a brief rant

quoth VanMundegaarde:
> and people are being really accomodating about booking my silly ass
> even though I have yet to pass out (or record) one real demo out
> here...

It's funny, bookings seem to be inversely proportional to the number of
demos that people hand out. Of course, I haven't handed out any CDs
since Halloween and I STILL get no love. (And no, Hugger-Mugger doesn't
count as long as the same 5 people show up every week!)

Seriously though... I've been seeing some SHITTY DJs at (otherwise)
great parties for a long time now. Do these people just suck a lot of
cock, or am I THAT bad at promoting myself? I can't even seem to get my
own friends to book me anymore!

Oh yeah, and Osby: whatever the fuck happened to me being the "sexiest
house DJ"? I don't really play much house these days, but still... being
sexy's gotta count for something!

I just moved recently, so I've got a whole new perspective on my record
collection. Here's what I can offer:

- deep glitchy techno (Spectral, Sub Static, Treibstoff, Kompakt
  [Extra])
- punky electro-house and *-clash (Playhouse, Output, etc.)
- jackin' tech-house (Natural Rhythm, Swag, RZ, etc.)
- 2004-style deep tech-house (Morris Audio, Traum, etc.)
- dub-house and roots dub (mostly Burial Mix 10"s, various one-offs)
- IDM/experimental (Aphex Twin, Autechre, Lusine, Sutekh,
  Context[errior])
- late 90s-early 00s jungle (Ram Records, Virus, etc.)
- 2000-era cheesed-out clubby disco house (Deep Vision, etc.)
- early 00s deep tech-house (Visitor, Combustible, lots of French stuff)
- tribal house & tech-house (Tango, Siesta, Nighshift, Detour, et al)

Mixes and more:

<http://shazbotica.com/>

Toodles,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Just a follow-up to that hastily-sent rant...

quoth shawn allen:
> Oh yeah, and Osby: whatever the fuck happened to me being the "sexiest
> house DJ"? I don't really play much house these days, but still...
> being sexy's gotta count for something!

It's the beard, isn't it? Will somebody tell me if the beard works or
not? Am I "metro" just for caring?

And here's some more stuff I forgot to mention in my repertoire, as it
were:

- dirty minimal techno (Joel Mull, 2 Dollar Egg, Dan Bell)
- straight-up electro (Carl Finlow, Bpitch Control, Electrix)
- industrial/goth-rock (Skinny Puppy, Front 242, Front Line Assembly,
  Ministry, NIN, et al)
- 80s rock/pop (Bon Jovi, Robert Palmer, B-52s, etc.)
- a smattering of just about anything else you can think of, with the
  exception of hardcore, ghetto-tech, or country

Oh yeah, and if you're crazy enough to want to book me, call me. I don't
have net access at home now. My number's at the bottom of every email
I've sent out since, like 1999.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] a brief rant

>since Halloween and I STILL get no love. (And no, Hugger-Mugger doesn't
>count as long as the same 5 people show up every week!)

hey, last night there were 3 new people there!  me, tim and eva.  we only 
stayed for a bit.  long enough for me to have a chicken wing and a beer.  i 
believe you on the decks.  it was either you or andy's ipod.  no, it was 
you.  i liked it.  it got a little breaky electro for a bit.

and regarding bookings...yes, it's friends booking friends (come on, let's 
all admit it).  sometimes they have skills, sometimes they don't.  sometimes 
it's just cause they play trance/hardcore/jungle/house whatever.  sometimes 
djs that lack skill make up for it by actually knowing a shit load of people 
and somehow can draw people to a party.

i think it's rare that someone books someone that they don't know.  i've 
done it before, and i feel like i'm the crazy one.  or booking a DJ that i 
like...but that i'm not sure that the crowd will like or even care who they 
are.  and of course the incredible number of bay area folks who own 
turntables and enough records to get through an hour long set has continued 
to skyrocket.

with that said, someone should book shawn.  or hell, let's just get all the 
djs that haven't played out as much as they should...let's get a crew 
together and throw our own damn party!   hey, Evil Breaks  parties account 
for atleast 1/4 of all my gigs!

ho hum.

Subject: [sfraves] RIP: Nick Kilroy

I don't know if a lot of people on sfr are familiar with Kin Records,
but if you haven't heard the Junior Boys' album "Exit" yet you're really
missing out.

Unforunately Kin's founder, Nick Kilroy, passed away yesterday. He left
us with these wonderful photos:

<http://www.electrokin.com/zabriskie_point/index.html>

Thanks to Philip Sherburne for getting the word out...

<http://phs.abstractdynamics.org/archives/004954.html>

but if you haven't heard the Junior Boys' album "Exit" yet you're really
missing out.

us with these wonderful photos:

<http://www.electrokin.com/zabriskie_point/index.html>

Thanks to Philip Sherburne for getting the word out...

<http://phs.abstractdynamics.org/archives/004954.html>

-&e->AndyW?? :) )

That was me working with the rebel notion that you can mix records from 
any bin with records from any bin, with no common theme but love.  ghetto 
tech + funk + house + techno + electro + breaks + selections from the 
soundtrack of flashdance cause that is how we do.

and like, the awesome fact that when the guest dj flakes, I get their 
drink tickets.  i am the 80 proof pacman.  love it!  power pill, lights 
out, ghosts who haunted me now die as I eat you.

on the booking stuff shawn... welcome to the fucking planet.  if you play 
techno, your weenie shrivels up from atrophy.  hahahha.  tricked you!  
you can play a million other things, doesn't matter.  you turn into 
bastard techno person.  pr is a bitch mon.  haha!  at least you have your 
integrity and a ton of records that all make mechanical noises that arouse 
significant emotional response in 100% of people in a random sampling of 
um.. YOU!

dooooooot!

techno forever.
andyw

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: DJ Mariano on An Epiphany of Sound today

Francisco, ex KZSU-er DJ Mariano will make a return appearance on An
Epiphany of Sound this Thur., 2/10, from 9a-noon.  He's been DJing since
he was only 17, so you know he can bring it to you like you like it,
with musicians like Psycat, Infected Mushrooom, producers from Medium
records and more.  He's all about making you wanna dance!!  (Just don't
try doing it while you're driving.)

http://kzsulive.stanford.edu between 9a and noon this Thur.  We'll also
be giving away CDs and tickets to the Gravity CD Release party from
Artemis this Fri. as well as more stuff!

Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 09:33:43 -0800

Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] a brief rant

the recent techno/gig thing reminded me of some discussions going on 
elsewhere on the internet.  and mind you, i'm no techno expert, but i'll say 
this.

there's been talk in the DnB and breaks community recently about how to 
expand the scene and introduce more people to the genres.  the points:

1)  get young people involved
2)  work with other crews and communities

getting young people involved is essential.  and by young i mean both young 
in age and young in experience with dance music.  if you want to keep 
playing for the same people that have been listening to techno for 5, 6, 7 
or 10+ years, that's fine. but it's rare that it will inject new energy and 
enthusiasm into that scene.  sure, they love the music and they appreciate 
it...but it's the same community of people.  over and over.  getting new 
people involved can help techno appreciation and love grow in size and 
passion.  as people in the scene move on, you will have a steady influx of 
new pace

working with other crews does the same thing.  but it also lets you see how 
other crews and communities are growing themselves.  we all love music.  
let's get together and help each other

i know it's more comfortable and easier to stay among the folks that you 
know, but i think it's worth the risk to reach out to more people.  lots of 
Evil Breaks DJs play at candy parties that would make some on this list 
nauceous.  we frequent message boards that cater to younger rave audiences 
(yes, I'm talking about Bay Raves).  but we are pushing breaks and getting 
it to the ears of a younger crowd that will eventually (hopefully) move on 
to other scenes, clubs and undergrounds as they grow older.  they are going 
to be the ones at the next FnF new years.  they are going to be at the next 
Moksha Tribe party.  they'll be going to Mighty, DNA Lounge and 550 
Barnaveld once they turn 21.  and they will know and appreciate breaks 
(unless they hate Evil Breaks and we've made them loathe us).

i started throwing parties with Aaron Jae when i was unemployed.  we both 
put our rent money on the line.  we spent every weekend going out to parties 
and meeting people and talking with folks.  it was a tough time and we 
couldn't have made it through without the support of our friends and the 
people that came out to our parties (dancers, djs, volunteers, etc).  but 
it's been great and breaks are out there.  we had ALL breaks in the MAIN 
room of Furious 2, a 600+ person, all ages party.  i haven't seen that in 
the bay area in years.

and with that, i also invite all of you out to Dirty on the 19th of this 
month.  we have breaks AND techno.  fancy that!

and the Evil Breaks one year anniversary party is March 19th.  i'd be 
honored to have you all help us celebrate.
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

February 5th:  Bassline FM @ 90.5 KSJS
February 18th:  Virgin Mega Instore
February 19th:  Dirty w/ Future Funk Squad @ 330 Ritch
March 11th:  Urbanology
March 19th:  Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary Party
April 29th:  Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty
--------------------

least a little happy :)  

As a fellow bay area EDM person I gotta vouch for Shawn- encyclopedic
record collection (you've got to check out his organization method
sometime), beautiful mixes, wonderful dancefloor vibe, great attitude
(unless you're a right-wingnut and you happen to drop some dubious
statistic around him ;), man's got it down.

We booked him for one of the first .folded.s and he rocked it big time.
 Right now we are trying to burn through everybody we want to book
before bringing back any alumnis but when we do decide to go back
around he's first on my list :)

Anyway, just a glowing endorsement for any promoters reading this
thread.  

Btw, shawn, I think you should take a clue from my brilliant (non) dj
career and start playing melodica as you spin (and run it through a
kaoss pad).  Rocksteady ska wind instrument PRESSHA!

Subject: [sfraves] looking for a few good DJs


so a friend of mine is looking for some music (chill, psytrance, more 
ethnic tribal stuff) to flesh out
his Internet radio station (www.earthrites.org/radio.htm).  If you have 
recommendations, or mixes you'd like
put on the air, etc, e-mail info@earthrites.org and a short bio if you'd 
like it put on the site.  payment?
I have no idea.  But the free music industry is like the open source 
movement - gift economies are more
about making contacts, getting your work out there, and profit becomes a 
consequence (an effect) rather
than the motivation (a cause)   I see some philosophical essay coming re: 
how capitalism has to change.....
But I'm not a DJ - do you all see things this way?  thoughts?

thanks,
doug

Subject: RE: [sfraves] a brief rant

At the risk of sounding like a suck up - which, fuck y'all if ya think 
that...I think Shawn is one of the BEST local dj's I have yet to hear. And I 
agree - I have been out and heard some people "spin" that didn't even seem 
to be able to grasp the basics of beatmatching. I won't name names here, 
because that'd just be rude - but there're definitely some dj's out there 
that must kiss a whole lot of ass.

Of course - I'm a fairweather DJ (IMHO anyway). Somedays I'm on - some, I 
just upset myself. Irrational nervousness seems to be a great cause of me 
being off when I'm off, and it's totally frustrating. Eh - what can ya do?

ANyway - bottom line - Shawn Allen = GREAT DJ. Book him people.

Marco


>From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] a brief rant
>Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 16:33:32 -0800
>
>quoth VanMundegaarde:
> > and people are being really accomodating about booking my silly ass
> > even though I have yet to pass out (or record) one real demo out
> > here...
>
>It's funny, bookings seem to be inversely proportional to the number of
>demos that people hand out. Of course, I haven't handed out any CDs
>since Halloween and I STILL get no love. (And no, Hugger-Mugger doesn't
>count as long as the same 5 people show up every week!)
>
>Seriously though... I've been seeing some SHITTY DJs at (otherwise)
>great parties for a long time now. Do these people just suck a lot of
>cock, or am I THAT bad at promoting myself? I can't even seem to get my
>own friends to book me anymore!
>
>Oh yeah, and Osby: whatever the fuck happened to me being the "sexiest
>house DJ"? I don't really play much house these days, but still... being
>sexy's gotta count for something!
>
>I just moved recently, so I've got a whole new perspective on my record
>collection. Here's what I can offer:
>
>- deep glitchy techno (Spectral, Sub Static, Treibstoff, Kompakt
>   [Extra])
>- punky electro-house and *-clash (Playhouse, Output, etc.)
>- jackin' tech-house (Natural Rhythm, Swag, RZ, etc.)
>- 2004-style deep tech-house (Morris Audio, Traum, etc.)
>- dub-house and roots dub (mostly Burial Mix 10"s, various one-offs)
>- IDM/experimental (Aphex Twin, Autechre, Lusine, Sutekh,
>   Context[errior])
>- late 90s-early 00s jungle (Ram Records, Virus, etc.)
>- 2000-era cheesed-out clubby disco house (Deep Vision, etc.)
>- early 00s deep tech-house (Visitor, Combustible, lots of French stuff)
>- tribal house & tech-house (Tango, Siesta, Nighshift, Detour, et al)
>
>Mixes and more:
>
><http://shazbotica.com/>
>
>Toodles,

Subject: Re: [sfraves] a brief rant

quoth AndyW:
> on the booking stuff shawn... welcome to the fucking planet.  if you
> play techno, your weenie shrivels up from atrophy.  hahahha.  tricked
> you!  you can play a million other things, doesn't matter.  you turn
> into bastard techno person.

Goddammit Andy, I'M NOT LIKE YOU! *My* techno induces hour-long
erections... or something. Seriously though, what's up with the techno
stigma? Did I just automatically become an asshole in everyone's eyes
when I started buying Spectral records?

> at least you have your integrity and a ton of records that all make
> mechanical noises that arouse significant emotional response in 100%
> of people in a random sampling of um.. YOU!

That's exactly my problem. I come home every night to find a 2000+
collection staring me in the face:

<http://alterior.net/tmp/records1.jpg>
<http://alterior.net/tmp/records2.jpg> (I'm still unpacking)

"PLAY ME," they scream. "TAKE ME TO A DARK SWEATY WAREHOUSE AND LET ME
SIIIIIIING!" I had them boxed up for nearly a month, and now that I've
finally got my turntables set up again they're psyched. But for both of
us, a lone pink neon flamingo light is not a suitable audience. I'm back
in San Francisco, I'm single for the first time in nearly 5 years, and
I've still got that "fuck 2004, 2005 is the year to rock out" thing that
I picked up on NYE going. Am I desperate? Not yet. Am I shameless? Fuck
yeah, and it's about time. I've been humble far too long. BOOK MY ASS!

Toodles,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

perspective.

i feel you on this.  sometimes i just play to the bartender.  i
consider it "practice".  ;)

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Mario Bezjak makes # 2 on top 10 techno Downloads on beatport.com  with his 
track entitled The Beats.   Mario is one of Cobalts talented producers from 
Croatia.  His track the Beats is also available on Cobalt 02 vinyl sampler.  For 
more info on Mario and other Cobalt artists please log onto 
http://www.cobaltrecordings.net/  .

To get Marios latest release you can log onto http://www.beatport.com/  and 
of course you can also grab a preview on cobalts home site. 

In January we received tons of emails from music lovers showing their support 
for our label. We greatly appreciate everyone who took time to contact us. We 
read and reply to all emails sent, so please continue to write us.
Cobalt 003 is burning up dancefloors worldwide! We are receiving DJ support 
by A-list djs such as Matthew Dear (Ghostly International, Plus 8), James 
Cotton (Ghostly International, Spectral), and Kevin Saunderson (KMS Records, 
Detroit).
Listen to track samples and purchase the 12" on our Releases page. Get it 
while you can!


Tony Russo 
Cobalt Recordings and PMR Records
Co-owner, Promotions, Bookings
E-mail: monk7923@aol.com 
http://www.cobaltrecordings.net/ 
http://www.trackitdown.net/ 
http://www.spins.us/

--1ef.355365ff_alt_bound

and liking to go out to stuff we're not playing at.

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>

Mime-Version: 1.0

In-Reply-To: <20050210125717.V98781@kzsu.stanford.edu>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] record organization

quoth J.C.:
> Well, with all the music geeks that we have here at the station, we
> just went through a 30-40 post thread on record collection
> organization methods.  Some CRAZY ideas out there.  (Can forward some
> of the articles to interested people.)

I'd definitely be interested in hearing how you're handling that insane
collection at KZSU! My method is pretty simple: on the big shelf,
everything's by label. I think visually, so I tend to be pretty good at
remembering which label a particular track was released on. I do have a
bunch of "orphan" records that are on labels from which I don't own any
other releases, and those are the ones I'm still trying to sort out. I'm
probably going to do those by style (roughly), then alphabetically by
artist.

Back in September I visited the Kompakt storefront in Cologne, Germany.
The place was amazing to begin with, but what made it so much cooler was
the organization. Each wall contained its own sufficiently vague style:
abstract/IDM/experimental in one corner; electroclash and pop bootlegs
on the adjacent wall; an entire side of the store (at least 60ft long)
for "minimal techno" (everything from Bpitch Control to Trapez); yet
another wall for electro and "straight" techno; in the opposite corner,
an assortment of crazy hard stuff. Most records were sorted by label,
but a few artists garnered their own hampers.

Anyone else with a lot of records have some tips? Does anyone label
their sleeves with style dots or BPMs anymore? And does anyone know a
place to buy more of those plastic sorting labels?

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

From: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20050210193601.61661.qmail@web53201.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] a brief rant

--- "michael, the red stickman" <red_stickman@yahoo.com> wrote:
> > But for both of us, a lone pink neon flamingo light 
> > is not a suitable audience.
> 
> i feel you on this.  sometimes i just play to the bartender.  i
> consider it "practice".  ;)

Some of my best friends are techno DJs, and even more of my friends are
djs who spin techno and other stuff but would love to be booked more
frequently for techno gigs.  Breaks my heart to see them
underappreciated- techno is one of those genres that really lets a good
dj's technique and heart shine, and a good techno set hitting me at the
right time forces dancing like nothing else.

At this point I see two major problems in the local techno scene.  

1. It is too fragmented/cliquey.  Case in point: DEF:SF, a crew that
has long dedicated itself to throwing quality techno events and uniting
the local scene, threw Is:As, a party with a good lineup, high
production values (or as high as the smaller venue would permit), and,
for the most part, a large underrepresentation in attendance by the
techno community.  

Sure, good-natured stalwarts like Andy and Shawn were there and some
great djs including Forest Green spun, but there were a lot of heads I
expected to see that weren't there.  Same story with a lot of other
really good techno events that should be drawing more folks.  I'm
hoping that the excitement about this weekend's Alien Autopsy party
will bring some of the factions together.

2. It has cool-ed itself out of the popular cool zone.  Some techno
heads are so zealous and monochromatic about their chosen genre that
they put off a "fuck you, I'm more techno than you" aura.  This
attitude does not work to bring new faces and creative input into a
scene.  There is a fine line between generating mystique/exclusivity
and putting a barrier at the gates of a scene through which only those
cool enough may pass.

In any case, I am a techno lover but I myself don't go out to all of
the available parties, mainly because I don't always feel a sense of
family when I do, the way I do at less genre-specific ugs and even some
club nights.  Recent parties at the OW and the DEF party are notable
exceptions in the family department.

I'm not a true techno stalwart so I may be talking out of my
proverbial, but this is how I see it.  I know that I personally felt
outcooled by hardcore techno people until I got to know them.  Once I
did I realized they were silly teddybear bastards like the rest of us.

hehe

_GC

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Silver's North American Tour

-------------------------------1107987171
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

We are currently accepting last minute requests for Silver's North American 
tour!!!!!!
This tour has a few dates left in February and March. All dates will include 
a flight share. Please inquire about availability ASAP (weekend and weekdates 
still available). 

The genre of drum & bass has always been about expanding boundaries and 
filling open gaps to create new, innovative sounds for the dance floor. Sonic & 
Silver, the Accidental Heroes, formed in 1999 for this precise reason: to push 
their funky, dubbed-out, atmospheric sound to a widespread audience across the 
world. With accumulating credits to many major labels including Metalheadz, 
Timeless, Virus, Soul:R, Reinforced, Renegade Hardware, Sonic's Space label and 
the duo's own Science Fiction Recordings, there seems to be no pause for these 
two talented artists.  
In addition to their mighty discography, the Accidental Heroes have worked 
their way into numerous notable publications, including Mixmag, Knowledge, NME, 
and ATM. The Heroes have had an impressive run touring the world over the last 
three years and are now returning home to England to focus on various solo 
projects.  

Silver has been working with BBC's 1xtra as of late, with projects on V 
Recordings, Emotif, Timeless, L Plates, and his newest release on Random 
Recordings, "The Jamaican Indian EP." Don't be surprised if you find him running around 
San Francisco, where he has been working with Gridlok and Hive on a few things 
as well.  

Please inquire about DJ Gamet available for select dates on this tour as well.

Please contact Charity Gallagher of Sublunary Artist Management for bookings. 
Charity@SublunaryAM.com 

-------------------------------1107987171--

Yeah, we're overachievers man, good to know you. :)

>From: "Brandon S." <invibe@hotmail.com>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] a brief rant
>Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 09:33:43 -0800
>
>the recent techno/gig thing reminded me of some discussions going on 
>elsewhere on the internet.  and mind you, i'm no techno expert, but i'll 
>say this.
>
>there's been talk in the DnB and breaks community recently about how to 
>expand the scene and introduce more people to the genres.  the points:
>
>1)  get young people involved
>2)  work with other crews and communities
>
>getting young people involved is essential.  and by young i mean both young 
>in age and young in experience with dance music.  if you want to keep 
>playing for the same people that have been listening to techno for 5, 6, 7 
>or 10+ years, that's fine. but it's rare that it will inject new energy and 
>enthusiasm into that scene.  sure, they love the music and they appreciate 
>it...but it's the same community of people.  over and over.  getting new 
>people involved can help techno appreciation and love grow in size and 
>passion.  as people in the scene move on, you will have a steady influx of 
>new pace
>
>working with other crews does the same thing.  but it also lets you see how 
>other crews and communities are growing themselves.  we all love music.  
>let's get together and help each other
>
>i know it's more comfortable and easier to stay among the folks that you 
>know, but i think it's worth the risk to reach out to more people.  lots of 
>Evil Breaks DJs play at candy parties that would make some on this list 
>nauceous.  we frequent message boards that cater to younger rave audiences 
>(yes, I'm talking about Bay Raves).  but we are pushing breaks and getting 
>it to the ears of a younger crowd that will eventually (hopefully) move on 
>to other scenes, clubs and undergrounds as they grow older.  they are going 
>to be the ones at the next FnF new years.  they are going to be at the next 
>Moksha Tribe party.  they'll be going to Mighty, DNA Lounge and 550 
>Barnaveld once they turn 21.  and they will know and appreciate breaks 
>(unless they hate Evil Breaks and we've made them loathe us).
>
>i started throwing parties with Aaron Jae when i was unemployed.  we both 
>put our rent money on the line.  we spent every weekend going out to 
>parties and meeting people and talking with folks.  it was a tough time and 
>we couldn't have made it through without the support of our friends and the 
>people that came out to our parties (dancers, djs, volunteers, etc).  but 
>it's been great and breaks are out there.  we had ALL breaks in the MAIN 
>room of Furious 2, a 600+ person, all ages party.  i haven't seen that in 
>the bay area in years.
>
>and with that, i also invite all of you out to Dirty on the 19th of this 
>month.  we have breaks AND techno.  fancy that!
>
>and the Evil Breaks one year anniversary party is March 19th.  i'd be 
>honored to have you all help us celebrate.
>--------------------------
>< Brandon / DJ Bam >
>
>DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
>http://www.evilbreaks.com
>
>February 5th:  Bassline FM @ 90.5 KSJS
>February 18th:  Virgin Mega Instore
>February 19th:  Dirty w/ Future Funk Squad @ 330 Ritch
>March 11th:  Urbanology
>March 19th:  Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary Party
>April 29th:  Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty
>--------------------
>
>
>

:)  minimal to hard...

I dunno.. My set at the last Basswaves was probably the most people I've 
ever had "into it" for a straight up techno set in the SF area. The Minimal 
Monday one was pretty rad too; especially since you can hear people 
cheering in the recording (picked up via the needle); probably on the rare 
side for MM. ;P If there was one set for people to check out on this list 
it is the MM one as it is the most "approachable".

My big push this year locally is to organize live EDM events at the new 
Asphodel facility on a 16.8 system running my super sleak _3D_ 
spatialization software.  For my own live performance tools I've got 
this  idea of spatial granular synthesis and being able to do volumetric 
textures and then the matrix math!!! I mean like layers of rotating 
textures..  This and a whole lot more for the most part unheard 
techniques/sounds. Should be good stuff around the end of the year... hint 
hint...

I'm also making a commitment to get a second record out there before 
summer.. Hmm.. If you spin techno or just want to support then check out 
the 1st one and order it... Sadly, it didn't get picked up for distro and 
I'm sitting on over 350 copies.  http://egr.egregious.net/

If not getting booked is discouraging... well not getting your record 
distributed is more so Shawn.. For #2 though I'm going to get a remix by a 
"larger name", unfortunately that seems to be necessary especially if you 
are trying to establish a techno label from the SF area..

Best,
--Mike

Egregious
"Spiritual renewal through music for those outside the heard."
http://www.egregious.net/

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: RE: [sfraves] SpaceHookers - Feb12th @ BlueCube

get to know the Spacehookers:

Spacehookers (Electropussywhipped - Prague / Bucharest / London /
Tokyo / New York)
Andrei and Gustav are one of Eastern Europe's top electronic duos. Known 
equally for their jacked-up and dubbed out beats and Ian Curtis-meets-Lou 
Reed vocals as for their on-stage (and off-stage) decadent debauchery, this 
show is their first American performance. Much closer to Prince than to 
Kraftwerk, Spacehookers are usually seen dancing wildly, simulating sex acts 
with audience members, and arranging rendezvous with groupies during their 
performances. Not to be missed.


--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

February 5th:  Bassline FM @ 90.5 KSJS
February 18th:  Virgin Mega Instore
February 19th:  Dirty w/ Future Funk Squad @ 330 Ritch
March 11th:  Urbanology
March 19th:  Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary Party
April 29th:  Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty

>Gus (aka AudioEl and also of Protolab + Cybrid fame) and I have formed a

>madness, techno, and having a good time rocking out on mics + notebooks +
>assorted garage sale instruments.  Our last gig in December caned it, I
>think we finally got the right blend of energy, high proof liquor and
>planning and I'm ready to tell people about it.  :)

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Chat with Psychedelics Researchers Dr. Sasha Shulgin and
  Ann Shulgin

--=====================_1521277==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Chat with Psychedelics Researchers Dr. Sasha Shulgin and Ann Shulgin

I am pleased to invite you to a 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=78278>live audio web 
chat on Tuesday, February 22 at 3 PM PST / 6 PM EST with Dr. Sasha Shulgin, 
the noted psychedelic chemist and pharmacologist, and his wife Ann Shulgin, 
the beloved writer and therapist. Dr. Shulgin, a former Dow research 
chemist, is well known for his creation and discovery of new psychoactive 
chemicals and for his promotion in the late 1970s and early 1980s of the 
use of MDMA in psychotherapy. Sasha and Ann Shulgin together authored and 
published the books PIHKAL: A Chemical Love Story and TIHKAL: The 
Continuation, detailing the synthesis of and their personal experience with 
hundreds of psychedelics.

The Shulgins will be online to address your questions on a range of topics 
from the "war on drugs" to the therapeutic use of MDMA. Please email 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=78287>questions@drugpolicy.org 
before February 22 to submit questions, and don't forget to bookmark the 
chat address!

When: Tuesday, February 22, 2005
3 PM PST / 6 PM EST
Where: 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=78278>http://www.drugpolicy.org/events/shulginchat




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Message-ID: <816b5dff050211085918a883d9@mail.gmail.com>
Date: Fri, 11 Feb 2005 11:59:12 -0500
From: innocentchild <innocentchild@gmail.com>
Reply-To: innocentchild <innocentchild@gmail.com>
To: sfr <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] party.throwing.people+resources

First off - cool. I hope you guys follow through and have a party.
Take some video for me since I'll be in some other country.

Party throwing is easy.

Venue
Sound
Talent

That with a lot of common sense is all you really need. Sort those 3
things, and hopefully all posess common sense, and you're good for
moving onto the other fun stuff. Now when it comes to the other fun
stuff like prop parties for banners and such don't forget to ask
around. It's rather amazing the resources you can have access to if
you do this party to meet budjet. There are people on this list with
gear and supplies that can save you a lot of time and effort.

Just keep things simple and don't blow the planning up into more than
it has to be. Personally a few of us have been bored out of our minds
and because of that ended up with a party planned and executed in a
day. Always remember that it's a party. This is fun times with good
friends. =)

Use SFRaves to your advantage if you need something...

:: r ::
