>From: innocentchild <innocentchild@gmail.com>
>Reply-To: innocentchild <innocentchild@gmail.com>
>To: sfr <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: [sfraves] party.throwing.people+resources
>Date: Fri, 11 Feb 2005 11:59:12 -0500
>
>First off - cool. I hope you guys follow through and have a party.
>Take some video for me since I'll be in some other country.
>
>Party throwing is easy.
>
>Venue
>Sound
>Talent
>
>That with a lot of common sense is all you really need. Sort those 3
>things, and hopefully all posess common sense, and you're good for
>moving onto the other fun stuff. Now when it comes to the other fun
>stuff like prop parties for banners and such don't forget to ask
>around. It's rather amazing the resources you can have access to if
>you do this party to meet budjet. There are people on this list with
>gear and supplies that can save you a lot of time and effort.
>
>Just keep things simple and don't blow the planning up into more than
>it has to be. Personally a few of us have been bored out of our minds
>and because of that ended up with a party planned and executed in a
>day. Always remember that it's a party. This is fun times with good
>friends. =)
>
>Use SFRaves to your advantage if you need something...
>
>:: r ::

Message-ID: <20050211185141.8958.qmail@web51605.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 11 Feb 2005 10:51:41 -0800 (PST)
From: Siren <siren9911@yahoo.com>
To: karina@hyperreal.org, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Q: What was your most memorable party between 1992-present where you connected with other SFRavers?

Well, mine would have to be Whoopie Ball 1992.  I
lived in Sacramento at the time.  My best mate was
really getting into the rave scene...I didn't know
what to make of it yet.  She'd play her mix tapes
every morning and I really couldn't get into any of
it.  "James Brown is Dead", or "Charly". I have to
admit, I just thought it annoying music. Anyways, she
invited me to go to a "rave" in Oakland with a couple
of our friends.  I thought what the heck since I had a
mad crush on one of the guys we'd be going with. 

So, we all piled in a car and drove to the bay area
listening to the Orbital.  We stopped off at the Shell
in Emerville for blow pops, water, etc.  Called the
info line on the flier for directions and drove to
some undisclosed location off of Hegenberger Rd..  We
parked and proceeded to the place with the thumping
beat.  Well, I had know idea what this "e"xperience
would be like but I just knew I found it thrilling. 
The pumping beats, the friendly people, crazy outfits,
and 3 warehouses of just pure fun. I was hooked on it
& the music. The chill space was relaxing and there
were these computers set up on opposite sides of the
warehouse where you could message back and forth to
unkown strangers passing by.  Wow did I think that was
so cool!  Little did I know where raving would end
up...still going strong today and that the internet
would bust open a whole new world of communicating.  

After joining SFRaves back when it was formed I found
it such a joy to able to communicate with other
ravers.  I remember how excited I was when I got my
SFRaves laminate.  It was like our little club and it
made it nice to be able to keep in touch after
attending parties. Congratulations SFRaves on
continuing to thrive for our awesome community!

Rave On,

- Siren

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Death of a Playwright

--=====================_3279876==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


Death of a Playwright

by Joal Ryan
Feb 11, 2005, 10:00 AM PT

Playwrights don't marry 
<http://www.eonline.com/Facts/People/Bio/0,128,11013,00.html>Marilyn 
Monroe. <http://www.eonline.com/Facts/People/0,12,10822,00.html>Arthur 
Miller was the exception.

The celebrated writer of Death of a Salesman, Miller died Thursday night at 
his home in Roxbury, Connecticut, of congestive heart failure. He was 89.

Even before Monroe formally entered the picture in 1956 as his second wife, 
Miller was famous for his words--and serious ones, at that.

Death of a Salesman, the 1949 play that brought Miller the Tony Award, the 
New York Drama Critics Circle Award, the Pulitzer Prize and celebrity, was 
the heartbreaking tale of Willie Loman, a man who wore out more than shoe 
leather looking for the American dream.

The Crucible, the 1953 Tony winner for Best Play, echoed the era's 
Communist witch hunts in Congress with the story of the 17th century witch 
hunts in Salem, Massachusetts.

<http://www.eonline.com/Facts/Movies/0,60,13420,00.html>Playing for Time, 
the 1980 TV-movie that earned Miller an Emmy for Outstanding Writing, was 
the portrait of a real-life Nazi concentration camp internee, played by 
<http://www.eonline.com/Facts/People/Bio/0,128,13050,00.html>Vanessa 
Redgrave, who used her violin to stave off execution.

In part, Miller's writing won him four Tonys, two Emmys, one Oscar 
nomination (for the 1996 film version of 
<http://www.eonline.com/Facts/Movies/0,60,125,00.html>The Crucible), the 
Pulitzer, and a host of lifetime achievement honors, including those 
bestowed upon him by the Kennedy Center in 1984 and the Tonys in 1999.

As an aside, the writing earned him entree to Hollywood, and access to 
Hollywood's quintessential creation, Marilyn Monroe.

"She was a whirling light to me then, all paradox and enticing mystery," 
Miller wrote of Monroe in his 1987 autobiography, Timebends, "street-tough 
one moment, then lifted by a lyrical and poetic sensitivity that few retain 
past adolescence."

Miller and Monroe became involved as his first marriage to Mary Grace 
Slattery was cooling, and Miller was facing heat for refusing to name names 
of suspected Communists before the House Un-American Activities Committee.




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_3279876==.ALT--

> >around. It's rather amazing the resources you can have access to if
> >you do this party to meet budjet. There are people on this list with
> >gear and supplies that can save you a lot of time and effort.
> >
> >Just keep things simple and don't blow the planning up into more than
> >it has to be. Personally a few of us have been bored out of our minds
> >and because of that ended up with a party planned and executed in a
> >day. Always remember that it's a party. This is fun times with good
> >friends. =)

> >From: innocentchild <innocentchild@gmail.com>

> >Date: Fri, 11 Feb 2005 11:59:12 -0500
> >
> >First off - cool. I hope you guys follow through and have a party.
> >Take some video for me since I'll be in some other country.
> >
> >Party throwing is easy.
> >
> >Venue
> >Sound
> >Talent
> >
> >That with a lot of common sense is all you really need. Sort those 3
> >things, and hopefully all posess common sense, and you're good for
> >moving onto the other fun stuff. Now when it comes to the other fun
> >stuff like prop parties for banners and such don't forget to ask
> >around. It's rather amazing the resources you can have access to if
> >you do this party to meet budjet. There are people on this list with
> >gear and supplies that can save you a lot of time and effort.
> >
> >Just keep things simple and don't blow the planning up into more than
> >it has to be. Personally a few of us have been bored out of our minds
> >and because of that ended up with a party planned and executed in a
> >day. Always remember that it's a party. This is fun times with good
> >friends. =)
> >
> >Use SFRaves to your advantage if you need something...
> >

Subject: [sfraves] ATTENTION:  party idea...

ok, just to get the ball rolling, i'm going to volunteer my pad on sunday 
afternoon for anyone who wants to get together and chat about this.  now, my 
place is pretty damn big (it's a warehouse) but out of respect for my 
housemates, i'd like to keep this meeting at less than 12 people.

i'm going to suggest this sunday at 3pm.  keep the meeting at 2 hours or 
under.  basically, just so people can meet and discuss things.  after that, 
we can set up a mailing list for a core group of organizers and volunteers.  
from there we can organize future meetings.

does this work for people?  if not, do people have other suggestions?

if sunday is a go, i live in SOMA on 5th street near Folsom.  i'll email my 
address and phone number to those that have responded to this "let's throw a 
party thread".

Subject: [sfraves] free storage cabinet for records

holding records.  it has double doors that latch and
everything.

2'5" wide, 1'2" deep, 5' high.  "putty" color.  inside is a bit
banged around on the sides, but it's held my records faithfully
for 15 years.  time to move the fuck on!

yours for free - you'll need a truck and some strong arms and
legs:  the thing is pretty heavy.  i have a handtruck, and will
help you load up at my place in oakland.  i'll post to
craigslist in a couple of days.

shoot me a private email...

From: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <816b5dff0502111130575cebb4@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] party.throwing.people+resources

I think what you said is true- that holy trinity is all that is
required for a good party, the rest are pretty optional (depending on
your aims for production values/party size).  I've had some wonderful
experiences at impromptu get-togethers where it was clear none of the
things below were thought about, but the venue was good enough, the
sound good enough, and the talent good enough to smooth over the rough
edges.  Hell, I've had good times when one or two of those were
missing, even.

All the niceties are great, but when I'm in the moment enjoying myself,
I am thinking chiefly about the music, my mindset, and being with
friends.  I could care less if there's a fuzzy green catarpillar firing
laser bolts onto the dancefloor. ;)  

That's not to say I don't appreciate a party where it's clear people
have worked to make it a beautiful space and a safe place to TAZ out.

To each, their own, and to all, a good rave.
-GC

>From: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
>To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] party.throwing.people+resources
>Date: Fri, 11 Feb 2005 13:07:52 -0800 (PST)
>
>I think what you said is true- that holy trinity is all that is
>required for a good party, the rest are pretty optional (depending on
>your aims for production values/party size).  I've had some wonderful
>experiences at impromptu get-togethers where it was clear none of the
>things below were thought about, but the venue was good enough, the
>sound good enough, and the talent good enough to smooth over the rough
>edges.  Hell, I've had good times when one or two of those were
>missing, even.
>
>All the niceties are great, but when I'm in the moment enjoying myself,
>I am thinking chiefly about the music, my mindset, and being with
>friends.  I could care less if there's a fuzzy green catarpillar firing
>laser bolts onto the dancefloor. ;)
>
>That's not to say I don't appreciate a party where it's clear people
>have worked to make it a beautiful space and a safe place to TAZ out.
>
>To each, their own, and to all, a good rave.
>-GC
>

-----Original Message-----
From: Siren [mailto:siren9911@yahoo.com] 
Sent: Friday, February 11, 2005 10:52 AM
To: karina@hyperreal.org; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Q: What was your most memorable
party between 1992-present where you connected with other SFRavers?

Well, mine would have to be Whoopie Ball 1992.  I
lived in Sacramento at the time.  My best mate was
really getting into the rave scene...I didn't know
what to make of it yet.  She'd play her mix tapes
every morning and I really couldn't get into any of
it.  "James Brown is Dead", or "Charly". I have to
admit, I just thought it annoying music. Anyways, she
invited me to go to a "rave" in Oakland with a couple
of our friends.  I thought what the heck since I had a
mad crush on one of the guys we'd be going with. 

So, we all piled in a car and drove to the bay area
listening to the Orbital.  We stopped off at the Shell
in Emerville for blow pops, water, etc.  Called the
info line on the flier for directions and drove to
some undisclosed location off of Hegenberger Rd..  We
parked and proceeded to the place with the thumping
beat.  Well, I had know idea what this "e"xperience
would be like but I just knew I found it thrilling. 
The pumping beats, the friendly people, crazy outfits,
and 3 warehouses of just pure fun. I was hooked on it
& the music. The chill space was relaxing and there
were these computers set up on opposite sides of the
warehouse where you could message back and forth to
unkown strangers passing by.  Wow did I think that was
so cool!  Little did I know where raving would end
up...still going strong today and that the internet
would bust open a whole new world of communicating.  

After joining SFRaves back when it was formed I found
it such a joy to able to communicate with other
ravers.  I remember how excited I was when I got my
SFRaves laminate.  It was like our little club and it
made it nice to be able to keep in touch after
attending parties. Congratulations SFRaves on
continuing to thrive for our awesome community!

Rave On,

- Siren

>1992-present where you connected with other SFRavers?

Saturday, February 12, 2005 ** Beatsauce Live in Oakland **

EVENT: Beatsauce live in Oakland!

DATE/TIME: Saturday, February 12, 2005. 10:00 pm-2:00 am.

LOCATION: Club Oasis, 135 12th St., Oakland, CA, 94607, (510) 763-0404. 21=
=20
& up. Heated covered patio. Lounge.

EVENT TYPE: Club, DJ, Dance.
GENRES: Dancehall, Hip Hop, Soul, Reggae.
FEATURED TALENT: Beatsauce Crew (Raw B, Wisdom, J-Boogie-Om Records) Big G=
=20
(808 Band), Ales-1 (4OneFunk). ADMISSION: $10.00. 21 & up.
INFORMATION: unifysound@hotmail.com, (510) 763-0404.
PRESENTED BY: Unify Sound, 808 Media.
SPONSORED BY: East Bay Express, Scion, LRG Clothing.

ABOUT EVENT: The event is part of Unify Sound/808 Media~Rs monthly=20
production at Club Oasis featuring a rotation of the world~Rs most=20
renowned turntable artists; legendary DJs who have helped to shape modern=
=20
turntablism.

ABOUT BEATSAUCE (courtesy True Skool): In 1994 three San Francisco DJs --=
=20
Winston "DJ Wisdom" Bailey, Justin "DJ J-Boogie" Boland, and Rob "DJ Raw=20
B" Blach -- joined forces to produce an all-live underground hip-hop mix=20
show out of sheer love for the art. Together the trio bring Beatsauce to=20
the Bay Area on KUSF, 90.3 FM, every Sunday from 6 to 8 p.m. The crew is=20
known for rocking countless parties, events and shows throughout the Bay=20
Area, bringing with them the skills that have made the Beatsauce radio=20
program a legend in Bay Area Hip Hop.

No other radio DJs in San Francisco offer up the originality, on-the-air=20
improvisation, and all-around skills that these three bring to the=20
airwaves. There are no specific set lists, no barely concealed marketing=20
schemes, no Top 40 chunks of filler. Just dope music, intelligent hosts,=20
and positive vibrations.

Guests who have stopped by to pay tribute read like a hip-hop all-star=20
roster, including KRS-One, Mobb Deep, Group Home, Jay-Z, Company Flow,=20
Tracey Lee, Tha Alkaholiks, Xzibit, Loot Pack, Jungle Brothers, Latryx,=20
Masta Ace, DJ Cut Chemist, and DJ Disk, to name just a few.

  "We try to explore the roots of hip-hop every week," J-Boogie said.=20
"Whether it's Wisdom bustin' out some reggae cuts one week, or Z-Trip=20
cutting up a Van Halen song on the air, we try to show that hip-hop is not=
=20
just some tiny box. The doors are wide open, and that's the way we do it."

More info at www.beatsauce.com.

http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1881=
=20
Oakland California, USA

Thursday, February 17, 2005 ** INSIDE - A THURSDAY MONTHLY HOUSE MUSIC=20
AUDIOSOCIAL **

Don~Rt you want to come INSIDE ?  It~Rs a place where you can get away=20
from the traffic, the noise, the hassles, and just let yourself go~E

Come INSIDE and feel the togetherness in our new family of urban beings=20
rocking together in a cascade of house music, warmth, happiness, and great=
=20
vibes.  Being INSIDE makes the rest of the world not seem so crazy, so=20
hectic~E just relax, have a seat, or dance, or laugh, or just nod your=20
head to the music.  It doesn~Rt matter when you~Rre INSIDE.

INSIDE is a new monthly Thursday night audiosocial for everyone,=20
everywhere who can dig it.  INSIDE is a creation of the REVIVE PROJECT, a=
=20
small collective of dj~Rs and social engineers who envision a gathering=20
where going out is fun again, where guests feel like they~Rre at home (=20
but with a better liquor cabinet.. ), where the music is never, ever=20
awful~E The Revive Project consists of Derek Niddery, John Dupre, and Matt=
=20
Valenz.

You can come INSIDE for our next party on February 17th with the amazing=20
and seriously grooving CHRIS LUM, along with Derek and Matt on backup=20
musical duty.

INSIDE exists at the LEVENDE LOUNGE, winner of CITYSEARCH~RS ~Q Best Of ~Q=
=20
award in 10 categories.  Levende Lounge is at 1710 Mission Street at=20
Duboce in San Francisco.

DJ BIO:  Chris Lum The grossly underrated Chris Lum traded the land of=20
smog (L.A.) for the land of fog (San Francisco), where he is now a=20
prominent member of the underground house community. He runs his own=20
commercial sound studio, Abitare Music, and assists in the running of=20
Moulton Studios with his partner in crime Jay J Hernandez. Lum and=20
Hernandez (aka Jay J) co-produce as 2 Utes on a number of respected=20
underground imprints. His own label, Crisp Records, has been an outlet for=
=20
DJ Rasoul (Transport, Naked Music, and Large) and many others.  Lum has=20
produced possibly his best work to date for Tilted, the label managed by=20
Nervous and Freeze recording artist Brent Laurence. With its=20
straightforward kicks, inspired chord changes, and funky disco samples,=20
"Stay With Me" is pure sex on wax. Think Seasons, Dufflebag, and Ovum=20
multiplied by ten. Everyone should own a copy of this record.

DJ BIO: Matt Valenz In a world overtaken by automation and technology,=20
soul can be a hard thing to come by.  For someone lucky enough to be=20
raised on the sounds of Earth Wind & Fire, Kool and the Gang, Diana Ross,=
=20
and Tower of Power, being soulful comes as second nature. At 17 he was=20
turned onto vinyl and was soon playing Miami bass, freestyle, and=20
primitive house at small underground parties in the central California=20
area, then moved on to start a career in the music business when he=20
relocated to San Francisco at age 21.  He continued his drive to learn=20
every aspect of the industry, and returned a few years ago from a two year=
=20
stay in England where he was the booking manager for dy-na-mix agency, the=
=20
best agency for underground music in Europe. Now, back in that city, he is=
=20
resident at ~Q Loveworks Dancing ~Q, a mobile house music phenomenon=20
focusing on vibe, music, and art.  past guests such as Doc Martin, Joi=20
Cardwell, J. Sinister, DJ Diz, and international guests like the UK's=20
Eddie Richards, A Man Called Adam, and Terry Francis have also helped to=20
establish the party as a premier place for true house music, funk, soul,=20
and classics in the bay area.  He continues to play at the some of San=20
Francisco's best parties and is currently assembling a personal studio.

DJ BIO:  Derek Niddery Born and raised in Toronto, Canada, music has=20
always played a pivotal role in his life.  Being exposed to his parent~Rs=
=20
extensive record collection from the 50~Rs, 60~Rs and 70~Rs, he learned to=
=20
appreciate the different styles and sounds of jazz, funk, soul, rock, and=
=20
reggae.  Learning to play the guitar, drums, and congas that were always=20
present in the house, he would often watch his father record his own=20
weekend jam sessions on to old eight tracks.  Having the opportunity to=20
play drums in a band back in the early 90~Rs, he continues to push his=20
percussion skills today and will often play the congas throughout San=20
Francisco.  One of his biggest thrills came when he had the opportunity to=
=20
sit in and play congas with a Cuban jazz band while visiting Havana, Cuba=
=20
in September of 2003.  Now, only two years on the decks, he has already=20
worked with some of the Bay Area~Rs top promoters and DJ~Rs.  He believes=
=20
House music encompasses all styles of music and allows for unlimited=20
creativity.  This philosophy holds true in the music he chooses, always=20
bringing an uplifting passionate energy to his sets.

Bio: LEVENDE LOUNGE

Winner of "Best of" CitySearch 2004 in 10 categories!:  *As seen on ABC &=
=20
CBS National News Sept. 2004...  "Best Lounge", "Best Bar Food", "Best=20
Signature Drinks", "Best Afterwork Bar", "Best Bloody Mary", "Best 30+=20
Singles Scene", "Best Singles Scene", "Best Conversation Bar", "Best=20
Exotic Drinks", "Best See and Be Seen."

Levende Lounge and Restaurant is pioneering the way in San Francisco's=20
restaurant/nightlife culture. Levende offers a sophisticated and=20
comfortable establishment, where innovative cuisine, warm ambiance and=20
state of the art sound merge to form a stylish entertainment atmosphere.

Levende~Rs patrons are treated to a full bar and cocktail menu=20
complimented by eclectic, world-fusion small plates, elegantly presented=20
and served by a knowledgeable, friendly and fun staff. Levende plays host=
=20
to the finest International and local DJs, live musicians and=20
entertainment nightly and spotlights an ever-evolving roster of up and=20
coming artists on its gallery-sized walls.

( contact: John for information and guest list questions / 415 200 8872 or=
=20
Matt at 415 505 5150 )

To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] NRR > Sad Sad SAD SHIT! - American Nun Shot to Death Point Blank Range in Brazil's Amazon 

http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=3Dstory&cid=3D1896&e=3D1&u=3D/nm/cr=

American Nun Shot to Death in Brazil's Amazon


U.S. National - Reuters

BELEM, Brazil (Reuters) - A 74-year-old American nun was shot to death =
early
on Saturday in Brazil's Amazon rain forest (news - web sites) where she
worked to defend human rights and the environment despite frequent death
threats, federal police said.=20


=A0
Unknown assailants shot U.S. missionary, Dorothy Stang at point-blank =
range
at an isolated agricultural settlement in dense jungle 31 miles from the
town of Anapu in the state of Para, police and fellow religious workers
said.=20
"It was three shots at point-blank range," said sister Betsy Flynn of
Stang's order the Sisters of Notre Dame de Namur. "She received so many
threats, I never thought it would happen."=20
Stang had worked in the area around a decade defending the rights of
landless peasants and small farmers and promoting sustainable use of the
rain forest, according to the Brazilian Order of Lawyers (OAB), a =
national
lawyers' association.=20
She recently won a human rights award from the OAB for reporting abuses =
by
land speculators, illegal loggers and large landowners in the area.=20
Only weeks ago she warned federal human rights authorities she faced
continual death threats for her work. She was on an OAB list of people =
who
faced possible assassination.=20
"This death is just more encouragement to continue her work to confront =
the
people who are destroying the forest," said Meire Cohen of the OAB.=20
Brazilian media earlier reported Stang's age as 73.=20

Do You Remember House (Blaze)

i remember house before it was called house
i remember house when house respected house
i remember house when house grew from the roots of house
i remember house when house was soul music and r'n'b before house was disco
i remember house before the superclubs
i remember house when people knew the lyrics of house
i remember house before record labels sold the house
i remember house when house was about love

i remember house

i remember house when house was more than just a name to package this 
sound, this groove, this motion
i remember house when it was just one house
i remember house when house had artist, songwriters and personalities
i remember house when you didn't have to be a dj just to be into house
i remember house when house was broke
i remember house when house was done in the house
i remember house when house it was the spiritual thing

i remember house

do you remember house?
do you remember house?
do you remember house?
do you remember house?
do you remember house?

i remember house before it was techno
i remember house before it had an afro
i remember house before it was deep
i remember house before it was hard
i remember house when house had tempos
i remember house before mpc 60's
i remember house before house had loops
i remember house before the whole knew

i remember house

do you remember house?
do you remember house?
do you remember house?
do you remember house?
do you remember house?

i remember house before it was called house
i remember house when house respected house
i remember house when house grew from the roots of house
i remember house when house was soul music and r'n'b before house was disco
i remember house before the superclubs
i remember house when people knew the lyrics of house
i remember house before record labels sold the house
i remember house when house was about love

i remember house

do you remember house?
do you remember house?
do you remember house?
do you remember house?
do you remember house?


Spiritually Speaking (then and now)
By blaze
Release date: By 20 March, 2003



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

> it really had me groovin'.  house music all night long.

Subject: [sfraves] RE: Blaze is da shiz/ Do You Remember House?

Very familiar with this record. Excellent double pack. Lots of well crafted 
songs pulling elements from jazz, 70's r & b, and disco. Reminiscent of 
early Earth Wind and Fire. Check out the instrumental "Gloria Muse", the 
extended piano solo is absolutely beautiful. This baby stays in my record 
bag at all times!



-- Paulie Paul

"It is one of life's mysteries how an ounce of understanding, cleanses an 
ocean of mistrust and hate"
(The Outer Limits)

On Fri, 11 Feb 2005, Mr. Matt L. Downer - CEO wrote:
-&e->What are you talking about? FNF NYE was awesome! I thought it was great on
-&e->the internals, the nice CGI Page where you picked your shift etc.  I mean
-&e->yes with age comes wisdom, so you certainly know what works and does not
-&e->work. When in history was an FNF event ever broken up? None that I know of,
-&e->as they are always fully prepared :-) FNF has some of the most intelligent
-&e->folks in the universe and beyond. 

I worked and attended that party, and really, it's near the bottom as 
FnF's go in my book.  Better than most parties in general, yes... but 6 
rooms is bullshit that is best left to massive promoters.  I also happen 
to think it was too broadly promoted and at times annoying crowded.  And 
if I recall correctly, they were *selling* bottled water upstairs which I 
can't remember ever seeing at an FNF.

In any case, still the place to be but not my favorite party or favorite 
fnf ever by a long shot.  On the bright side, it was the first time I go 
to play guitar at a rave sorta thing which was fun and I saw tons of 
people I just love to death.

andyw

Subject: Re: [sfraves] party idea...

Yeah I've been trying not to get cynical on ya'll on this, but you're going
to have a bitch of a time getting together a lineup for this party, mainly
because about 75% of SFR is a DJ and everyone will want to play if they
contribute which won't happen and a number of people will be bitter about
it.  About 20 people have nominated themselves already.  That, and you'll be
doing the same thing about every crew in the Bay does which is book their
own crew/friends/girlfriends/boyfriends that only goes to further the
cliqueness of the underground scene out here.  What I'd personally love to
see is an SFR party that booked all DJs from outside of the list so that we
got talent outside of this circle and brought some fresh blood in with it.
But that's never going to happen so I'll shut up now.

Or you could consider having an SFR poll for who people on the list would
most want to see play and pick a lineup that way...

The monthly sounds cool though if people actually were to support it when
they weren't playing, it'd be nice to get to meet folks on the list in a
more relaxed environment and it'd give everyone a chance to play over time.

-Andrew

Well, I have XM, and it ROX! I'm not sure how many EDM
stations are on Sirrius, but there are 3 on XM. Also,

stations, jazz..ETC! I'm a huge music fan, of all
different kinds, so it is awesome for me and my man.
I highly recomend XM to EVERYONE! It's what i pay for
monthly in place of cable, every huge music fan should
have it ;)

> -&e->folks in the universe and beyond.
> 
> I worked and attended that party, and really, it's near the bottom as
> FnF's go in my book.  Better than most parties in general, yes... but 6
> rooms is bullshit that is best left to massive promoters.  I also happen
> to think it was too broadly promoted and at times annoying crowded.  And
> if I recall correctly, they were *selling* bottled water upstairs which I
> can't remember ever seeing at an FNF.
> 
> In any case, still the place to be but not my favorite party or favorite
> fnf ever by a long shot.  On the bright side, it was the first time I go
> to play guitar at a rave sorta thing which was fun and I saw tons of
> people I just love to death.
> 
> andyw
> 
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] party idea...

See to me Ascension was the SFR weekly back in it's hay day. Then
Michael was doing his thing at Thristy Bear and a lot of SFR people
were hitting that up.  Even Andrew and George's Folded @ Anu is a
sorta SFR hangout. Granted, that's not a weekly but you all see the
point. The closest thing to what you're all talking about would have
to be Cannabass in Oakland. 8 - 10pm is open decks. There is a
downside to all of this. Having a night where you might here
happycore, good house, bad trance and then jungle all in the same
night makes my ears bleed and baby jesus cry. Really you have to think
about programming otherwise you're going to make people hurt. Anyway.
I've been on this list for almost 6 years and have seen this *let's
throw a party* and *let's have a club night//meet up* thing discussed
over and over with little action. The only time things happened was
when someone took initiative and made them happen. Find that person
and make with less talky and more action. =)

:: r ::


On Fri, 11 Feb 2005 12:03:23 -0800, Andrew Phelan
<mailinglists@djandrewphelan.com> wrote:
> Yeah I've been trying not to get cynical on ya'll on this, but you're going
> to have a bitch of a time getting together a lineup for this party, mainly
> because about 75% of SFR is a DJ and everyone will want to play if they
> contribute which won't happen and a number of people will be bitter about
> it.  About 20 people have nominated themselves already.  That, and you'll be
> doing the same thing about every crew in the Bay does which is book their
> own crew/friends/girlfriends/boyfriends that only goes to further the
> cliqueness of the underground scene out here.  What I'd personally love to
> see is an SFR party that booked all DJs from outside of the list so that we
> got talent outside of this circle and brought some fresh blood in with it.
> But that's never going to happen so I'll shut up now.
> 
> Or you could consider having an SFR poll for who people on the list would
> most want to see play and pick a lineup that way...
> 
> The monthly sounds cool though if people actually were to support it when
> they weren't playing, it'd be nice to get to meet folks on the list in a
> more relaxed environment and it'd give everyone a chance to play over time.
> 
> -Andrew

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR > XM or Sirius? Which do I choose?

XM. I've been listening to Sirrius the past week and I do NOT like
their electronic stations. Boombox - eh - sometimes good. Chill -
about the ONLY thing you can listen to. Good track selections in
there, but a lot of older shit that's mixed into some not so good
stuff. Then you get into Area 65 or something like that and all those
channels - fucking crap ass trance meathead e-tard crap. We're talking
eurotrash dance music or the stuff you see a shitload of floored kids
bouncing too. I have to say that what I hear on friends' XM systems is
FAR superior in quality of music.

XM has Thump. That alone means you're going to have some good music.
If you like the super cheesy fisher-price my first rave trance -
plenty of it waiting for you on Sirrius and not much else in the dance
genre =(

:: r ::

original?  Seriously!  Gwen Stefani is a Madonna impersonator hack (with a 
little bit of Cyndi Lauper and Olive Pyl thrown in I guess) of the lowest 
creative caliber... while Mark Hollis (of Talk Talk) has one of the most 
amazing voices I've ever heard (check later albums from Talk Talk like 
"garden of eden" and "laughing stock" for reference... some of the most 
heart shearing ambient/spacejazz totally indescribably beautiful &
emotional music I've ever heard).

Subject: Re: [sfraves] party idea...

That's why we have topless girl dj's and other *sexxxy house dj's*
It's really more so about the marketing. Skill wise I have yet to hear
anything impressive. Especially when you look at her specificially and
note that she was a happycore dj and suddenly turned house dj because
that end of the scene is losing people while the house scene is just
getting bigger and bigger. It's business and a good financial move.
But again. I see this more as marketing and business and not so much
about skill and talent. You sounded great at my house party. Matter of
fact you hella surprised me. I totally forgot that you were even
dj'ing. =X  Point being that I don't care what you're wearing if
you're good, but if you market yourself as some upscale glossy female
house dj and aren't doing much on the decks track selection and mixing
wise, well, you're just show and not much go. Sadly most people out in
club land don't know the difference. Really - they don't. Those that
can hear a mix slipping right away are in the minority when we're out.
I'm going to say this is a bad thing.

:: r ::

this may be old news to some, but caffeine gum has hit the market in a big 
way. mad croc energy gum just may impact your life very soon. the same way that 
red bull has influenced dance culture (DJ Hell wrote my favorite track as an 
ode to it), caffeine gum may make the difference between a 'dopey' or 'speedy' 
night. .. or possibly be the thing that makes raves more sober in the long 
term.

the gum has a faster caffeine come up due to the fact that the gum can be 
used sub lingual-ly (sp?), is alot less harsh on your stomach than 3 rockstars, 
and at 49 cents each are quite possibly more easily addicting than crack.

- now only if nicorette would make that nicotine/caffeine/dental gum i always 
wanted. `;)!!



++spects++
-Sean Ocean-

Subject: [sfraves] Saturday YUM!!! Hello 2Day...Rhythm Method & OW

I kinda got 2 the City early 'cause Dhoris gave me a ride & well.. I kinda
went 2 Bam's 2 kick it... we kicked it. fun!  OK.. then I was walkin' 2
Shadowlounge & well there was this Dude in fromt of me walkin' also...
ok.. nothing weird... then he turned around & yelled,

"OSBY IS THAT U?"

LoL.. it was Rich (Re-ach) & well.. whoever remembers him who reading
this, he says HI... but yeah.. we endedup talkin' 4 like 2 fuckin' hours
'cause i ain't seen that CAT in like a year & 1/2 almost...

OK... so Rhythm Method was fuckin Sick!  I mean... the night kinda started
out slow & I dunno... LoL.... it was like Wow... I partying w/ a whole new
bunch of Junglists when i thought about it.. LoL.. there was this "newbie"
junglist DJ Dude who was walkin' around the the party like tellin people
he was "a Jungle DJ who was spinning Jungle 4 a year & 4 months.  He's
been listening 2 Jungle sonce he was 15 & he's 21 now".. LMAO.. it was
funny...

OK... but man... all those fuckin' sets were Awesome... I mean like it was
all kinda like dubby mellow(I dunno terms really yet, hello 2day).. OK...
but like DJs ?Sik? & KillJoy OK.. they tore up the night & brought up the
energy like boom, ya know?  I mean... seriously.. WOW!!  It was also Dope
'cause I finally saw Dymphna after heeeeeeella years! Well, 4 those who
know her...

I mean... OK... Vega & E$KR's tag set was sick!!  I guess E$KR was
droppin' some tracks he produced.. Oh Fuck man... Loved it!!!  & all the
DJs who spun b4 them & tagged.. Awesome!  Bicolas, The "Doctah", oh gosh..
who else???  I LOVED it!  I mean.. seriously.. I was on the floor more
times then not & when i wasn't, I was either like outside chillin' or like
inside eating candy hearts or throwing them @ people... or like playing
basketball w/ some girls & shooting inside their shirts (girls i knew
ofcourse, ya knw!!!) LoL....

OK... it was funny 'cause well.. I saw dMarie & Summer like get there w/
this Dudecarrying a record case.. OK.. so that was Phear I assumed...
lol.. ok... so i went up 2 them.. kisses the girls on the cheek & talked 2
Phear.. LoL.. it was funny 'cause he like well.. I ain't sen him in like 2
years & we talked 4 a bit.. LoL.. he remembers when we were like drunk
last time & like totally hung out last time... LoL  Needless 2 say. his
set was sick.. I mean.. it was all hard Jungle aall the way through...  he
played some tracks he produced on CDJ's & play vinyl.. I LOVED his set
alooooooooooooot!!  Oh my fuckin' Goodness man... so Dope!!  Oh.. I was
wearin' a DOPE shirt on Sat night.. literally!

It was kinda touching also 'cause alota Junglists that night were like all
each remembering the moments like i 1st hung out w/ them... which was
fun... like Genna's husband.. LoL.. 4got his name, always 4gethis name,
was like tellin' me how he remembered me @ DNA like 4 years ago almost
when I was on stage dancin' when AndyC was spinning & LoL.. I dunno... it
was touching that that night like is how alota people remembered me.. .l
la la.... ok.. but every1 who was there was just Awesome.. the Vibe was
sooooooooo Fuckin' Sick!  Oh yeah.. some1 else came up 2 me that night &
like told me they "liked" my style!!  LoL.. How fun!!!  I dunno what that
meant.. but I got heeeeeella giggly (still am) about that.. hehehehehe

Anywaze.. found a ride 2 OW 'cause I wan'ted 2 throw down w/ whoever was
left there still (it was like 4AM when i got there!

OK... so it was alll aobut like the house & the mouse there by the time i
got there... hmmm... I missed the Techno & Breakbeats & a few other peopel
i wanted 2 meet up w/ there... but i did end up seeing Bam
again...LOLOLOLOLOLOLOLOLMAO... I really got 2 C Bam again!!  Hello 2Day
:P  I know... I'll shut up!  But also got 2 hang out w/ more Family!! 
YAY!!!

All in all well ok... wait.. i can't stop there.. unfortunatlely i missed
sevaeral rides home (oppertunies even), so i endedup takin', literally, an
adventure of a ride home on Public Trasortation...  the peak of that
edventure was when a Chinese lady was tryin' 2 ask me 4 instructions on
how to take the bus w/ her bike to Hercules Avenue & how to get back 2 the
bart station!

YAY!!  Oh yeah.. i have 2 make another post 'cause I promised some1...

Hiope y'all havin' a gRovvy Day!!!  YAY!

RHYTHM METHOD = GROOVY MAD FUN!

-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

>> happycore, good house, bad trance and then jungle all in the same

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] hiding an IM

If you want to keep them from seeing your traffic you would have to
ssh tunnel out to another server (cloudfactory.org) and pass all of
your traffic over that connection. It's not super hard and it's not
easy. Best thing I can suggest? Get a T-Mobile Sidekick (Danger
HipTop). Then it's your device and they can't regulate or monitor it.

:: r ::

Subject: Re: [sfraves] party idea...

this shit is really kind of unfair on the lady DJs.

if they're good looking, they get dissed for riding their looks and being hoes.

if they're not good looking, they get dissed for not having looks to ride on.

or, they don't get dissed at all, in which case the mere fact that
they're not getting dissed means the non-disser thinks they're ugly --
which is like some kind of 007 secret dis.

talk about an unwinnable game.

all djs get dissed, even us wannabes, so this is really just kind of
par for the course.

but it's still like whatever.

also, DJing is not about skills. anybody who's fascinated with skills
gets into playing traditional instruments or mastering sound
synthesis. or turntablism, which is not really DJing. DJing is about
the party.

criticizing a DJ for not having skills is like criticizing a
classically trained cellist for not being a party animal.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] hiding an IM


So AIM does two things that are kinda obvious from the network... it's 
port (5190-5193) and the IP's it talks to (sucky is that the IP gets 
dynamically assigned from session to session by login.oscar.aol.com but 
AOL in genral is 64.12.0.0 + 205.188.0.0).  Also, like most chat 
protocols, it is MASSIVELY sniffable... you can literally just tap port 
5190 and watch that shit float by like leaves in a stream... a perl one 
liner fixes it up to be as readable as your chat logs.

So you have to use an alternate port _AND_ destination IP block if you 
want to totally hide your nasty bizniz.  Plus, if they do find it, you 
want to try encrypting it.

Just using a client that supports the AOL AIM server's SSH ability is 
enough to throw off most network admins.  You can find AIM clients that 
support SSH, I actually took a liking to an app called NAIM for anything 
that can compile *nix stuff... (works a lot like IRC, all text from a 
terminal, supports color and mssg cueing).  Using this app takes care of 
the protocol/port problem and also is an obscure app they probably won't 
look for... but it's still talking directly to the AOL servers and can be 
detected or blocked... but not read (they'll know what you're doing, but 
not what you're saying).

Ideally, if you have an offsite computer running unix that you can ssh to, 
run naim there (I've compiled it no prob for solaris, osx, linuxes & 
bsd)... then your work only sees an ssh connect to your server (this is 
what I do).  One ssh session, and screen (a terminal window manager that 
allows you to run multiple windows and disconnected/attach without 
skipping a beat) and you're gravy.

More answers on AIM for the sneaky here
http://www.unto.net/unto/work/aim_over_ssh.html

Naim info:
http://site.n.ml.org/info/naim/

Not too easy... but you're hoping to outsmart your network admin, who does 
this shit for a living if they're any good.  :)

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
"Nothing real can defeat us.  Nothing unreal exists." - Buckaroo Banzai

X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] hiding an IM

I am not sure which IM client you are using, but here Here are a few 
suggestions:

You can tunnel the IMS through SSH, HTTP Proxy (if the client/server 
connection supports SSL), HTTPS (with a lot of know/how config, you can 
encrypt the data using a secure client, or use another messaging 
solution.

http://www.technicalinfo.net/papers/IMSecurity.html eyggestionv


# MSN Messenger . Users must login to the centralised service to locate 
other users. Once a connection is established, users message each other 
directly in peer-to-peer fashion. The default IP port for MSN Messenger is 
1863 but the client is .port-agile. and, if the port is blocked, it will 
look for other open ports . next targeting the HTTP port 80. MSN Messenger 
supports HTTP proxies, but does not support HTTP proxy authentication. 
Note that file transfers occur over TCP port 6891, audio and video 
conferencing over UDP ports 13324 and 13325, and application sharing is 
commonly TCP port 1503.

# Yahoo Instant Messenger . Users login to the centralised Yahoo IM 
service to find other users. Once authenticated and online, users may 
choose to message each other directly or through shared chat rooms. The 
default port for Yahoo Instant Messenger is 5050 but the client is 
.port-agile. and, if the port is blocked, it will look for other open 
ports . next targeting the HTTP port 80. Just like MSN Messenger, the 
client supports HTTP proxies, but not HTTP Proxy authentication. Note that 
file transfers and file sharing is commonly done over TCP port 4443.\

#AOL Instant Messenger (AIM) . Users login in to the AOL Open System for 
Communication in Real-time (OSCAR) and then begin communications with 
Basic OSCAR Services (BOS) to locate and message other users. These 
messages pass through the server before being forwarded to the recipient. 
File transfers, voice traffic and other large digital payloads are 
conducted in peer-to-peer mode . whereby the initiating IM client sends 
its IP address and an open port over the service, so the remote client can 
connect to it.
The default port for the AIM client is 5190 and, if the port is blocked, 
the .port-agile. software will attempt to communicate over port 23 
(telnet), 20 & 21 (FTP) and then 80 (HTTP). In addition, users can choose 
to go through a SOCKS v4/v5, a HTTP proxy or HTTPS proxy. However, when 
tunnelling over the HTTPS proxy connection, AIM does not use SSL to 
encrypt traffic.

Here are other solutions (haven't used them and am not sure of the cost:

http://www.messagingsolutions.com/L7_enterprise.htm

Here are some other solutions depending on your environment 
configuration:

http://216.239.63.104/search?q=cache:ySgYWi4PM-IJ:drn.digitalriver.com/category.php%255Baction%255Dbrowse%26i%3D270%26id%3D163%26f%3D%257C%257C%257C%257C%26s%3Dproduct.date_released%257CDESC%255BSiteID%255Ddriverguide+tunneling+instant+messages&hl=en&start=16

It's a lightweight SOCKS proxy tunneling TCP/UDP traffic through HTTP 
proxy or a firewall. Works with programs like KaZaA, ICQ, Morpheus, WinMX, 
AOL IM, MSN IM, Trillian, FTP, telnet, ssh, and many others. If a client 
program does not support SOCKS protocol Socks2http works in conjunction 
with a "socksifier", like Sockscap32

http://drn.digitalriver.com/product.php%5Bid%5D61790%5Bcid%5D163%5BSiteID%5Ddriverguide?PHPSESSID=bb097d2deac7ac775bc7d507b966b897

Here's more info on proxy tunneling TCP/UDP traffic through HTTP proxy

http://www.google.com/url?sa=U&start=4&q=http://www.faqs.org/docs/Linux-HOWTO/Firewall-HOWTO.html&e=7370

I'm not sure about the reliability of this service, but here is another 
option:

http://www.google.com/url?sa=U&start=1&q=http://www.proxyblind.org/buy.shtml&e=7370

Much love,

Karina.

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SFRaves Dinner

SFRaves Community Dinner - a place to place a face in the SFRaves 
Community homebase.

Each of these dinners is completely personal, with the intention of 
engaging our community for Non-profit purpose, to meet new friends, the 
joy of getting together offline and in real-life, to build our SFRaves 
community as well as to ensure that we have *HAVE FUN*. We can talk about 
music or whatever suits our fancy.

Times after 6:30pm on weeknights and any time on weekends work well for 
most people. However, the time, place, etc is as flexible as our 
suggestions.

Notification of Information, the restaurant Address, Reservations made, 
time and date, with number of people and cost are to be determined.

All suggesetions are welcome, please bring yourself and a smile :)

Please suggest the following:
Day, Month, Date, Year

Meeting Time and Place:

Choose / suggest however you would like. Generally, the restaurant is 
picked  for the cuisine, price, location, and atmosphere. Price is 
determined by the restaurant, but we should try and pick a restaurant that 
suits everyone's budget.

Please rsvp to me by replying to this thread, sending me email @ 
karina@hyperreal.org, via IM, or in person. Email works best so I can 
track whom would like to go and have a way to contact you back for 
confirmation.

I am looking forward to meeting you in person. I appreciate the 
opportunity to meet people, bring them together and build lasting 
friendships both offline and in real-life.

Thanks and much love to you, always :)

-- 
**************************************************************
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
**************************************************************


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

To:  sfraves@hyperreal.org

References: <200502120053.j1C0rDur363060@pimout2-ext.prodigy.net> <Pine.LNX.4.62.0502132016160.28291@atari>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] party.throwing.people+resources

Yeah, 6 rooms wasn't the ideal setup but you also have to realize the 
pressures with "fitting everyone in" who may have stake in the party and 
the resulting dramas and how they are dealt with. Where it gets crazy in 
this place is at the point when whole groups say, "Fuck you I am going 
to throw my party in the building when yours is happening regardless." 
That is what happened at the top of the stairs in a space rented by 
someone here at the building and there wasn't anything that could be 
done about it except "damage control" in the form of finding some way to 
include them. That is some pretty amazing fucking shit, to go from all 
the yelling and screaming at each other and the fuck yous hurled back 
and forth to what all of us presented on NYE.

I think it is downright hilarious how whenever NYE is mentioned it is 
most often referred to as FnF NYE. Maybe it was one of the worst FnF 
parties ever, but it certainly was a fantastic Otherworld party.

FnF barely had a part in the party prior to the night of and a few days 
prior, and certainly weren't there in force months ahead of the party 
planning it all out. Most of the planning of OW/FnF NYE was done by one 
person: From searching out extra spaces in our building to booking and 
paying who needed to get paid, to bringing in Radiant Atmospheres and 
arranging sound systems, to getting folks like Marin to do her awesome 
decorations and captaining that whole effort... all while most of FnF 
had better things to do than be involved early on.

The folks that did come through on the FnF side early on were mostly 
people that enjoy OW to begin with and are down with what we do 
regardless. Those are the people that really made the loading dock and 
overflow space work enough to be called "FnF." Let's be honest, it 
wasn't a full FnF effort... only an effort by the FnF people motivated 
to use parts of our space and share an event. Those people are the 
people who should be given credit for the "FnF" side of things - you 
represented your greater collective with honor and hard work. Ticketing 
and door crew were mostly handled by FnF folks. Regardless there are 
people who feel they are part of both crews - it showed in their effort.

I think it is very important to realize there was a time in the planning 
when the question was posed within our house: "Who should we invite to 
share half of our home with to throw a large NYE event? Who would 
appreciate it and make the most of it?" There were many family 
collectives considered as possibles to share our event with. Let me 
repeat that last part one more time...

WHO WOULD APPRECIATE IT AND MAKE THE MOST OF IT? It turns out those 
people are individuals not a whole "crew" to speak of.

Obviously the solution is to become more involved so you understand the 
behind the scenes issues more... or to develop the wisdom to understand 
them if you are not involved at that level. Better yet, rent out a 
30,000 square foot warehouse at more than $10k/month and start a 
collective there so you can extend your space to folks who will bitch 
about the party later and forget how drunk and bottle breaking 
belligerent they were in your home.

I hope this blanket response is illuminating to some folks in regard to 
larger production events in shared warehouse buildings.


donb



AndyW wrote:

>On Fri, 11 Feb 2005, Mr. Matt L. Downer - CEO wrote:
>-&e->What are you talking about? FNF NYE was awesome! I thought it was great on
>-&e->the internals, the nice CGI Page where you picked your shift etc.  I mean
>-&e->yes with age comes wisdom, so you certainly know what works and does not
>-&e->work. When in history was an FNF event ever broken up? None that I know of,
>-&e->as they are always fully prepared :-) FNF has some of the most intelligent
>-&e->folks in the universe and beyond. 
>
>I worked and attended that party, and really, it's near the bottom as 
>FnF's go in my book.  Better than most parties in general, yes... but 6 
>rooms is bullshit that is best left to massive promoters.  I also happen 
>to think it was too broadly promoted and at times annoying crowded.  And 
>if I recall correctly, they were *selling* bottled water upstairs which I 
>can't remember ever seeing at an FNF.
>
>In any case, still the place to be but not my favorite party or favorite 
>fnf ever by a long shot.  On the bright side, it was the first time I go 
>to play guitar at a rave sorta thing which was fun and I saw tons of 
>people I just love to death.
>
>andyw

Subject: [sfraves] Someone might live there.

Yes, this is going to come off like I am absolutely pissed and bitter so 
if you need to read fluffy optimism skip to the next Osby Oi Oi Jams sender.

There used to be a time when the kids going to undergrounds and parties 
had a sense for something really important that I see lacking in 
people's minds:

The party might be thrown in somebody's home.


It doesn't matter if the place is 1500 square feet or 30,000... it is or 
could be primarily, first and foremost... SOMEBODY'S HOME.

Wouldn't it be nice if the next time we are at an event if we could 
remember that one thing before:

making a mess
becoming drunk and belligerent
slamming up against walls uncontrollably
leaving the front door to the street open at 5am when leaving
putting out a cigarette
breaking bottles
fighting
deciding to bring social drama
destroying the shared building bathroom
tagging
not helping to clean up


Thank you,
donb

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

planners list?  feedback is always good, and this is the first
i've heard of all these problems.

i had very limited involvement with the party (day of setup,
decorations, DJing), but all that i saw went pretty smooth.

michael

Subject: Re: [sfraves] party.throwing.people+resources

No, I had a great time later on and the people that did help were 
great... but it was a subset of people and time and time again this 
party keeps getting referred to as The FnF NYE... when in fact it was 
Otherworld / FnF NYE with a subset of people from both groups who really 
made it happen.

The drama I refer to was dealt with and kept out of the FnF/Otherworld 
partnership for the event, but it is one example of the crap that is 
dealt with that nobody really sees. (Along with things like checking 
certain internet message boards to make sure the bsp was taken down, 
dealing with all the internet drama and bullshit, people threatening to 
have the party shut down, etc.)  It was kept out of FnF's hair because 
it was a building issue along with all the other crap.

I just get tired of people bitching about aspects of parties they had 
only a very small part of. The worst FnF ever, then get off your lazy 
fucking primadonna ass and make it the best FnF ever for yourself or 
understand the limits of what your small role in things gives you the 
right to bitch about.

donb

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
References: <200502140029.j1E0TEHc148766@pimout4-ext.prodigy.net>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR > XM or Sirius? Which do I choose?

Sirius has more original programming, while XM's programming largely
comes from ClearChannel and existing syndicated radio shows. Not sure
if that has changed since ClearChannel sold most of its interest of XM
a while ago.

On the other hand, XM currently has much better EDM programming. It
carries BBC Radio One's Essential Mix, and various other DJ shows.
Sirius' EDM programming is pretty laughable in comparision. I'd
wouldn't be suprised if Sirius eventually launches more original DJ
shows and provide better EDM programming than XM, but right now XM is
much better in terms of EDM.

So if u want EDM, I'd say go with XM now. If you like radio talk
shows, I'd go with Sirius since it has all the syndicated shows that
XM carries, plus Howard Stern.

I suggest you check the XM and Sirius fan sites/forums and decide for
yourself. I've some links on my del.icio.us that u might find useful:

http://del.icio.us/goofrider/radio


- Jeff

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR > XM or Sirius? Which do I choose?

One more thing: here's the list of DJ shows on XM's The Move.

http://www.xmradio.com/programming/channel_guide.jsp?ch=80

Weekly hosts including Deepsky, Halo Vagra, Coldcut, D:Fuse, Omid 16B,
Tom Stephan. Satoshi Tomiie, etc.

Sirius hardly has any DJ shows, they're EDM programming mainly
consists of 'round-the-clock playlists of euro-dance and handbag
clubby tunes.

- Jeff

>See to me Ascension was the SFR weekly back in it's hay day. Then
>Michael was doing his thing at Thristy Bear and a lot of SFR people
>were hitting that up.  Even Andrew and George's Folded @ Anu is a
>sorta SFR hangout. Granted, that's not a weekly but you all see the
>point. The closest thing to what you're all talking about would have
>to be Cannabass in Oakland. 8 - 10pm is open decks. There is a
>downside to all of this. Having a night where you might here
>happycore, good house, bad trance and then jungle all in the same
>night makes my ears bleed and baby jesus cry. Really you have to think
>about programming otherwise you're going to make people hurt. Anyway.
>I've been on this list for almost 6 years and have seen this *let's
>throw a party* and *let's have a club night//meet up* thing discussed
>over and over with little action. The only time things happened was
>when someone took initiative and made them happen. Find that person
>and make with less talky and more action. =)
>
>:: r ::

Subject: Re: [sfraves] party.throwing.people+resources

Boooyakasha - can't argue with that.
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "donb" <mutex@drghetto.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Cc: <andy@saturn5.com>
Sent: Monday, February 14, 2005 6:23 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] party.throwing.people+resources


> Yeah, 6 rooms wasn't the ideal setup but you also have to realize the 
> pressures with "fitting everyone in" who may have stake in the party and 
> the resulting dramas and how they are dealt with. Where it gets crazy in 
> this place is at the point when whole groups say, "Fuck you I am going to 
> throw my party in the building when yours is happening regardless." That 
> is what happened at the top of the stairs in a space rented by someone 
> here at the building and there wasn't anything that could be done about it 
> except "damage control" in the form of finding some way to include them. 
> That is some pretty amazing fucking shit, to go from all the yelling and 
> screaming at each other and the fuck yous hurled back and forth to what 
> all of us presented on NYE.
>
> I think it is downright hilarious how whenever NYE is mentioned it is most 
> often referred to as FnF NYE. Maybe it was one of the worst FnF parties 
> ever, but it certainly was a fantastic Otherworld party.
>
> FnF barely had a part in the party prior to the night of and a few days 
> prior, and certainly weren't there in force months ahead of the party 
> planning it all out. Most of the planning of OW/FnF NYE was done by one 
> person: From searching out extra spaces in our building to booking and 
> paying who needed to get paid, to bringing in Radiant Atmospheres and 
> arranging sound systems, to getting folks like Marin to do her awesome 
> decorations and captaining that whole effort... all while most of FnF had 
> better things to do than be involved early on.
>
> The folks that did come through on the FnF side early on were mostly 
> people that enjoy OW to begin with and are down with what we do 
> regardless. Those are the people that really made the loading dock and 
> overflow space work enough to be called "FnF." Let's be honest, it wasn't 
> a full FnF effort... only an effort by the FnF people motivated to use 
> parts of our space and share an event. Those people are the people who 
> should be given credit for the "FnF" side of things - you represented your 
> greater collective with honor and hard work. Ticketing and door crew were 
> mostly handled by FnF folks. Regardless there are people who feel they are 
> part of both crews - it showed in their effort.
>
> I think it is very important to realize there was a time in the planning 
> when the question was posed within our house: "Who should we invite to 
> share half of our home with to throw a large NYE event? Who would 
> appreciate it and make the most of it?" There were many family collectives 
> considered as possibles to share our event with. Let me repeat that last 
> part one more time...
>
> WHO WOULD APPRECIATE IT AND MAKE THE MOST OF IT? It turns out those people 
> are individuals not a whole "crew" to speak of.
>
> Obviously the solution is to become more involved so you understand the 
> behind the scenes issues more... or to develop the wisdom to understand 
> them if you are not involved at that level. Better yet, rent out a 30,000 
> square foot warehouse at more than $10k/month and start a collective there 
> so you can extend your space to folks who will bitch about the party later 
> and forget how drunk and bottle breaking belligerent they were in your 
> home.
>
> I hope this blanket response is illuminating to some folks in regard to 
> larger production events in shared warehouse buildings.
>
>
> donb
>
>
>

Evil Breaks presents...

DIRTY
Saturday, February 19th
@ 330 Ritch, SF
2 rooms a'rockin'
9pm - 3am
$7 b4 11 / $10 after

Yeah you heard that right. DIRTY is back and comin at you with some 
nastiness. Come check out our new monthly venue that we'll be sharing with 
Subscience.  For our first night, we've got some wicked breaks and dirty 
techno.  Come to get down.

Featuring:
FUTURE FUNK SQUAD
(Functional breaks/Island/En:vision/Default/Cryptic) - UK
This man needs no introduction.  Making beats since 1999, Future Funk Squad 
has produced a consistent stream of breakbeat stormers and remixed the likes 
of Moloko, Stanton Warriors and Koma+Bones.  With over 10 years of DJing 
experience, he will do the unthinkably nasty to your earholes!

Breakbeat Extravaganza:
Smoove (Space Cowboys/Newsbreakz/Opel) - Nitevibe Dreamteam 2005
Aaron Jae vs. Bam (Evil Breaks/AaronJae.com/Invibe)
M.O.D. vs. Influence (Evil Breaks/In tha Mix)
Marc(O) (*THWAP!*/Moksha Tribe)

Techno Delights:
Forest Green (SisterSF/Dim Sum/Forestgreen.org)
Andy W (Resource Records/Viberation)
Juan Segovia (Hugger-Mugger/tech-on)
G.A.M.M.A. vs. Mek (Techno-truth/Stilldream)

9pm - 3am
@ 330 Ritch
$7 before 11pm and only $10 after that, so get there early.

--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

February 5th:  Bassline FM @ 90.5 KSJS
February 18th:  Virgin Mega Instore
February 19th:  Dirty w/ Future Funk Squad @ 330 Ritch
March 11th:  Urbanology
March 19th:  Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary Party
April 29th:  Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty
--------------------

WOOOOOOOOOOOHOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!   I love BREAKS!!!!!  I can't Wait to hit the dance floor to these DIRTY AND EVIL BREAKS!!!!!!!!!!!

HOPE TO C U OUT ON THE DANCE FLOOR!!!!!!!!!!    I"M SOOOOOOOOOOOOO THERE!!!!!!!!!
 
I LOVE U!!!!!  I LOVE TO DANCE!!!!!!!!!!  I"M GETTING SOOOOOOOOO HYPER!!!

~TAMI!!!!  :-)

"Brandon S." <invibe@hotmail.com> wrote:
i cordially invite you all to come help us break in 330 Ritch properly. very 
happy to have more than a few SFR regulars playing at his event! mosey on 
down and git git down. yee ha! it's breaks and techno!


Evil Breaks presents...

DIRTY
Saturday, February 19th
@ 330 Ritch, SF
2 rooms a'rockin'
9pm - 3am
$7 b4 11 / $10 after

Yeah you heard that right. DIRTY is back and comin at you with some 
nastiness. Come check out our new monthly venue that we'll be sharing with 
Subscience.  For our first night, we've got some wicked breaks and dirty 
techno.  Come to get down.

Featuring:
FUTURE FUNK SQUAD
(Functional breaks/Island/En:vision/Default/Cryptic) - UK
This man needs no introduction.  Making beats since 1999, Future Funk Squad 
has produced a consistent stream of breakbeat stormers and remixed the likes 
of Moloko, Stanton Warriors and Koma+Bones.  With over 10 years of DJing 
experience, he will do the unthinkably nasty to your earholes!

Breakbeat Extravaganza:
Smoove (Space Cowboys/Newsbreakz/Opel) - Nitevibe Dreamteam 2005
Aaron Jae vs. Bam (Evil Breaks/AaronJae.com/Invibe)
M.O.D. vs. Influence (Evil Breaks/In tha Mix)
Marc(O) (*THWAP!*/Moksha Tribe)

Techno Delights:
Forest Green (SisterSF/Dim Sum/Forestgreen.org)
Andy W (Resource Records/Viberation)
Juan Segovia (Hugger-Mugger/tech-on)
G.A.M.M.A. vs. Mek (Techno-truth/Stilldream)

9pm - 3am
@ 330 Ritch
$7 before 11pm and only $10 after that, so get there early.

--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

February 5th: Bassline FM @ 90.5 KSJS
February 18th: Virgin Mega Instore
February 19th: Dirty w/ Future Funk Squad @ 330 Ritch
March 11th: Urbanology
March 19th: Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary Party
April 29th: Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty

Subject: Re: [sfraves] party.throwing.people+resources


On Mon, 14 Feb 2005, donb wrote:
-&e->I just get tired of people bitching about aspects of parties they had only
-&e->a very small part of. The worst FnF ever, then get off your lazy fucking
-&e->primadonna ass and make it the best FnF ever for yourself or understand the
-&e->limits of what your small role in things gives you the right to bitch
-&e->about.

Come again?

I worked parking lot/transpo coordinator from before party start till 
after midnight in the rain, dealt with the influx of underage kids who 
showed up after the modified bust, and did my best to keep people from 
getting cranky despite a considerable backup in the shuttle line.  If 
that's nothing, sorry... it's what I chose to offer that night (and more 
than I was scheduled for, there was a high chance I wasn't even going to 
be in SF Bay for NYE till maybe two weeks sprior).

Seeing as this is a direct response to my post, consider the implied 
target before using terms like "primadonna ass".  I did not disrespect 
you, but a couple readings of this aren't making your statements any 
better from my point of view.

As nothing more than an attendee I have the right to review any event on 
this list or any other channel provided I have my facts straight and 
maintain some modicum of respect.  I still said it was better than most 
parties, but again, 6 rooms, loose flyering and a lot of other factors 
contributed to a party that was not quite what I'd hoped for from either 
FnF or OW... let alone the sum of their parts (and I do stand corrected 
on referring to it as FnF NYE).

I had zero to do with the planning, but I did help the party happen and 
have been an active planning member of FnF since 1997 or so.  It's not 
like I haven't helped throw my fair share in for various crews, I know 
what it's like to hear a lackluster review of something you were 
personally involved in, but really... please don't go for the jugluar 
here.

andyw

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy

My backpack's got jets 
I'm boba the fett 
I bounty hunt for jaba hutt 
To finance my vette

>From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
>To: "Philip.X.Diaz" <st_indigo@earthlink.net>
>CC: The Twilight Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] hiding an IM
>Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 16:01:50 -0800 (PST)
>
>
>So AIM does two things that are kinda obvious from the network... it's
>port (5190-5193) and the IP's it talks to (sucky is that the IP gets
>dynamically assigned from session to session by login.oscar.aol.com but
>AOL in genral is 64.12.0.0 + 205.188.0.0).  Also, like most chat
>protocols, it is MASSIVELY sniffable... you can literally just tap port
>5190 and watch that shit float by like leaves in a stream... a perl one
>liner fixes it up to be as readable as your chat logs.
>
>So you have to use an alternate port _AND_ destination IP block if you
>want to totally hide your nasty bizniz.  Plus, if they do find it, you
>want to try encrypting it.
>
>Just using a client that supports the AOL AIM server's SSH ability is
>enough to throw off most network admins.  You can find AIM clients that
>support SSH, I actually took a liking to an app called NAIM for anything
>that can compile *nix stuff... (works a lot like IRC, all text from a
>terminal, supports color and mssg cueing).  Using this app takes care of
>the protocol/port problem and also is an obscure app they probably won't
>look for... but it's still talking directly to the AOL servers and can be
>detected or blocked... but not read (they'll know what you're doing, but
>not what you're saying).
>
>Ideally, if you have an offsite computer running unix that you can ssh to,
>run naim there (I've compiled it no prob for solaris, osx, linuxes &
>bsd)... then your work only sees an ssh connect to your server (this is
>what I do).  One ssh session, and screen (a terminal window manager that
>allows you to run multiple windows and disconnected/attach without
>skipping a beat) and you're gravy.
>
>More answers on AIM for the sneaky here
>http://www.unto.net/unto/work/aim_over_ssh.html
>
>Naim info:
>http://site.n.ml.org/info/naim/
>
>Not too easy... but you're hoping to outsmart your network admin, who does
>this shit for a living if they're any good.  :)
>
>andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
>\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
>"Nothing real can defeat us.  Nothing unreal exists." - Buckaroo Banzai
>

References: <20050215023724.31572.qmail@web53209.mail.yahoo.com>
	 <421165FF.5020807@drghetto.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.62.0502151233080.14365@atari>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] party.throwing.people+resources

As a newcomer to the bay area, I thought this was a kick ass party.  I
had only heard of FnF and had never had heard of Otherworld.  Out of
the slew of parties to pick from, I and my out of town friends picked
this one.  They felt the same way.  I don't know if I cared for my
favorite djs playing the puddle room, but I got down nonetheless.  And
I could tell that I wasn't the only one that did have fun.  Seemed
like the most underground party that night with the best lineup.

I'm sorry about those who chose to trash the house.  It is a reality
of party throwing in a place you call home.  Unless you and those you
work with know everyone that comes to the party, it is most likely
going to happen.  My friend's and have thrown parties for years,
outdoors, in the mountains of Santa Barbara and this reminds me of a
story.

A few of the elders and vets of the crew wandered away from the party
and had found a tagger doing his thing on a rock outside the party. 
This was at a spot that we had been doing parties for years.  We had
been able to do so cause we made sure we knew mostly everyone, made
sure everyone was safe, and left the land we used better than we found
it by picking up all the trash we and others had caused.  This
infuriated the partiers and proceeded to give him the riot act about
respect of the land, and the crew.  That actions like his would mean
we may never be able to throw parties there again, that what he was
calling his art was really just vandalism of nature, no better than
starting a fire or dumping chemicals there.  He tried to claim being
1/16th indian and his actions as going back to his roots but the tag
was lacking of much originality.  My friends ended up making him
scrape it off with a smaller rock.

Remember, the party is always what you make of it.  There will always
be an unwanted element, big or small, that will attend every party. 
And besides, New Years is an odd event.  To throw a party that big
with that many people, it would be a major miracle if you didn't get a
few jerks that trashed the place.  Some people do not know their
limits and there is a place for them.  It's called a club.


On Tue, 15 Feb 2005 12:55:05 -0800 (PST), AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:
>

> -&e->about.

> 
> I worked parking lot/transpo coordinator from before party start till
> after midnight in the rain, dealt with the influx of underage kids who
> showed up after the modified bust, and did my best to keep people from
> getting cranky despite a considerable backup in the shuttle line.  If
> that's nothing, sorry... it's what I chose to offer that night (and more
> than I was scheduled for, there was a high chance I wasn't even going to
> be in SF Bay for NYE till maybe two weeks sprior).
> 
> Seeing as this is a direct response to my post, consider the implied
> target before using terms like "primadonna ass".  I did not disrespect
> you, but a couple readings of this aren't making your statements any
> better from my point of view.
> 
> As nothing more than an attendee I have the right to review any event on
> this list or any other channel provided I have my facts straight and
> maintain some modicum of respect.  I still said it was better than most
> parties, but again, 6 rooms, loose flyering and a lot of other factors
> contributed to a party that was not quite what I'd hoped for from either
> FnF or OW... let alone the sum of their parts (and I do stand corrected
> on referring to it as FnF NYE).
> 
> I had zero to do with the planning, but I did help the party happen and
> have been an active planning member of FnF since 1997 or so.  It's not
> like I haven't helped throw my fair share in for various crews, I know
> what it's like to hear a lackluster review of something you were
> personally involved in, but really... please don't go for the jugluar
> here.
