>On Tue, 15 Feb 2005 23:24:24 +0000, His Highness
><the_emperor99@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > I see. If only I spoke spanish. Now how about explaining that in 
>English.
> > ;) j/k
> >
> > -- Paulie Paul
> > Computer illiterate
> >
> > "It is one of life's mysteries how an ounce of understanding, cleanses 
>an
> > ocean of mistrust and hate"
> > (The Outer Limits)
> >
> > >From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
> > >To: "Philip.X.Diaz" <st_indigo@earthlink.net>
> > >CC: The Twilight Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > >Subject: Re: [sfraves] hiding an IM
> > >Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 16:01:50 -0800 (PST)
> > >
> > >
> > >So AIM does two things that are kinda obvious from the network... it's
> > >port (5190-5193) and the IP's it talks to (sucky is that the IP gets
> > >dynamically assigned from session to session by login.oscar.aol.com but
> > >AOL in genral is 64.12.0.0 + 205.188.0.0).  Also, like most chat
> > >protocols, it is MASSIVELY sniffable... you can literally just tap port
> > >5190 and watch that shit float by like leaves in a stream... a perl one
> > >liner fixes it up to be as readable as your chat logs.
> > >
> > >So you have to use an alternate port _AND_ destination IP block if you
> > >want to totally hide your nasty bizniz.  Plus, if they do find it, you
> > >want to try encrypting it.
> > >
> > >Just using a client that supports the AOL AIM server's SSH ability is
> > >enough to throw off most network admins.  You can find AIM clients that
> > >support SSH, I actually took a liking to an app called NAIM for 
>anything
> > >that can compile *nix stuff... (works a lot like IRC, all text from a
> > >terminal, supports color and mssg cueing).  Using this app takes care 
>of
> > >the protocol/port problem and also is an obscure app they probably 
>won't
> > >look for... but it's still talking directly to the AOL servers and can 
>be
> > >detected or blocked... but not read (they'll know what you're doing, 
>but
> > >not what you're saying).
> > >
> > >Ideally, if you have an offsite computer running unix that you can ssh 
>to,
> > >run naim there (I've compiled it no prob for solaris, osx, linuxes &
> > >bsd)... then your work only sees an ssh connect to your server (this is
> > >what I do).  One ssh session, and screen (a terminal window manager 
>that
> > >allows you to run multiple windows and disconnected/attach without
> > >skipping a beat) and you're gravy.
> > >
> > >More answers on AIM for the sneaky here
> > >http://www.unto.net/unto/work/aim_over_ssh.html
> > >
> > >Naim info:
> > >http://site.n.ml.org/info/naim/
> > >
> > >Not too easy... but you're hoping to outsmart your network admin, who 
>does
> > >this shit for a living if they're any good.  :)
> > >
> > >andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
> > 
> >\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
> > >"Nothing real can defeat us.  Nothing unreal exists." - Buckaroo Banzai
> > >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] global consciousness project.  weird science.

The problem with this experiment is that they choose
the events after the fact.  That is they observe an
anomoly in the random data stream, and then try to
find an event that explains it.

The right way to do this experiment is to define the
events a priori using some sort of rules or criteria
to define the events.  For example, any incident
reported where more than 100 people die.  Or more than
100 people gather to protest war. Or etc...

Other possible explanations include solar activity,
changes in the earths electro-magnetic field, EM
fields from technological systems such as TV, radio,
computers, etc.

The REG devices have applications in cryptography
(Google "one time pad") and so any observed global
correlation effect would have significant importance
even if it was not caused by consciousness or
compassion.

Regards,

Peter

P.S. Yes I actually studied these experiments
(actually the previous version known as PEAR) in a
prior life.

long as we're not burning the place down. i just want to be discreet 
enough to use it every so often without making him feel like he has to 
come down on me.. er, US - it's really most of my department that uses 
IM.

thanks for all your suggestions. i'm trying to sort out this SSH thing.
pxd

Subject: [sfraves] Atlanta! =)

www.lunarmagazine.com - this is your sfraves of Atlanta.

The guy that runs it is the buyer for Satellite Records here. Really
nice guy and he's the one that got me to check out his site. Sure
enough there's a good amount of people on there and everyone is quite
nice. Think bayraves rah rah rah minus the idiotic candy kid//high
school OMG OMG mentality. Oh and about 25% of the traffic. Point being
- if you're ever in Atlanta get on that forum and you'll find the
party scene here quickly.

Half of DeepDish is playiing this weekend at a club called *1150*  Now
is it just me or is that a tad funny//odd that it's their big club
here and ours is 1015. Just shift the zero and... yeah. Thought that
to be a tad amusing. I gotta say that they do bring in some good out
of town talent. On one flyer one of the guys in Sound Navigators
played last week. Had I known I would have gone. Damn!

I'll be taking a lot of pictures from when Dubfire plays this
saturday. There are some UG afterparties too apparently so I'll be
sure to hit those up and come back with a review.

:: r ::

Subject: [sfraves] wanna play at Hugger-Mugger? (BSP, I guess)

We're seeking new talent for upcoming guest slots at the bay area's only
techno weekly. All of the residents (AndyW, Claire, Forest, Juan, Li and
myself) have some specific tastes, but as a whole we're a lot more
open-minded than most promoters in the bay area. :)

What I'm specifically looking for is more along the lines of IDM and
weird acid tracks. Glitchy stuff is right up my alley too, so if you
play anything abstract and noisey, I'd be interested in hearing some of
it--as long as it's not too aggro. Anything that could be described as
"deep", "dubby" and "minimal" works for me. Experimental trip-hop and
anything else along those lines could work as well.

If that sounds like something you can do, send me an email. I'd prefer
to listen to MP3s, but if you want to send me a CD let me know and I'll
give you my address. My next night to book is 3/8, but if I like your
stuff and the lineup is full I'll gladly recommend you to one of the
other residents. And of course, if you play (or make, we're up for live
acts too) anything that I'm not particularly into, don't hesitate to hit
me up for the other residents' contact info.

Thanks,
-- 
shawn allen

  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Immortality Through Google

By 
<http://www.wired.com/news/feedback/mail/1,2330,0-167-66599,00.html>Michelle 
Delio<http://www.wired.com/news/feedback/mail/1,2330,0-167-66599,00.html>
[]


02:00 AM Feb. 16, 2005 PT

Artists participating in a group show being held at the Big Easy's 
charmingly bizarre Barrister's Gallery through March 27 are getting a 
little taste of what their lives might be like after they are dead.

"What are memorials to the dead but touchstones for the great post-mortem 
popularity contest? He whose gravestone draws the biggest crowds wins," 
said <http://www.barristersgallery.com>gallery owner Andy Antippas, who is 
curating Hydriotaphia: New Orleans Artists Design Their Own Funeral Urns 
with artist Dan Teague.

MORE:  http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,66599,00.html




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_3926195==.ALT
Content-Type: text/html; charset="us-ascii"

<html>
<body>
<h1><b>Immortality Through Google&nbsp; </b></h1><font size=3>By
<a href="http://www.wired.com/news/feedback/mail/1,2330,0-167-66599,00.html">
Michelle
Delio</a>
<a href="http://www.wired.com/news/feedback/mail/1,2330,0-167-66599,00.html">
<img src="cid:6.2.1.2.2.20050216143033.024c17e0@localhost.1" width=15 height=13 alt="[]">
</a> <br><br>
02:00 AM Feb. 16, 2005 PT<br><br>
Artists participating in a group show being held at the Big Easy's
charmingly bizarre Barrister's Gallery through March 27 are getting a
little taste of what their lives might be like after they are dead.
<br><br>
&quot;What are memorials to the dead but touchstones for the great
post-mortem popularity contest? He whose gravestone draws the biggest
crowds wins,&quot; said
<a href="http://www.barristersgallery.com">gallery</a> owner Andy
Antippas, who is curating Hydriotaphia: New Orleans Artists Design Their
Own Funeral Urns with artist Dan Teague. <br><br>
MORE:&nbsp;
<a href="http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,66599,00.html" eudora="autourl">
http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,66599,00.html<br><br>

Subject: [sfraves] traffic jams, chaos theory, and community

abcnews is just now picking up on this story about traffic jams,  which was a model used years ago
by chaos theorists  trying discover an order of happenstances in Nature.  

http://userfs.cec.wustl.edu/~ce560/The%20Physics%20of%20Gridlock%20-%2000_12.htm

the idea is that many traffic jams happen for "no reason"-- no accident, no mattress in lane 3,
but instead, the fact that 15 minutes ago, a driver miles ahead of you tapped her brake pedal at a
time & place that was perfect for creating a chain reaction that leads to a meaningless traffic
jam.

why's this important?  i guess because it reminds us that what we do know might influence events
long after we've made a decision, turned it into an action,  and waltzed away to the next scene. 

Spiritualists of the Chaos vein tell us that this is why we should do *good things.*  But what
about the chain of events that might cause an act of charity to result in terrible things?  (Like
helping some diseased geezer across the street stalls the traffic flow enough to allow a taxicab
to flatten your beloved fiance 10 blocks away)

I need to do some more math.  Until then, PLEASE don't do anything.  Opening windows and doors is
particularly risky, especially if your crib is dusty or you have a mischievious cat.

If you *must* do something,  try to make it a positive interaction.  

Some scientists believe that positive actions make the subject feel like rotten ass, but I have
another theory: that positive actions make the subject feel good, even if the action results in
the subject's lover being flattened by a taxicab.  

I just need batteries for my calculator.  And a glass of Scotch to take the wack out of this weed.

boomerang fidget
Junior Analyst
Platypus Road Laboratory 
Oxford University
Oxford 
OX4 1R5
(Petticoat Lane entry)

--- Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

> The problem with this experiment is that they choose
> the events after the fact.  That is they observe an
> anomoly in the random data stream, and then try to
> find an event that explains it.
> 
> The right way to do this experiment is to define the
> events a priori using some sort of rules or criteria
> to define the events.  For example, any incident
> reported where more than 100 people die.  Or more than
> 100 people gather to protest war. Or etc...
> 
> Other possible explanations include solar activity,
> changes in the earths electro-magnetic field, EM
> fields from technological systems such as TV, radio,
> computers, etc.
> 
> The REG devices have applications in cryptography
> (Google "one time pad") and so any observed global
> correlation effect would have significant importance
> even if it was not caused by consciousness or
> compassion.
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Peter
>

> (actually the previous version known as PEAR) in a
> prior life.

Subject: [sfraves] Nothing Left but the Future--mailing more CDs--free of course (bsp)

I'm mailing Jonas a new copy of my CD because the first was a dud.  If anyone wants to be included
in the mailing, send me your snail address.  My last offer was during the holidays when some
people were off-list.  If you asked but never received,  let me know.

Four breakbeat / downtempo tracks.  All composed by Boomerang, entirely from samples.  Plus an
unauthorized remix.

1.   Wanderers			
2.   Your A Idiot   (((Everybody Hates Me mix)))
3.   Ready to Go   (((Goa Trance Kids mix)))
4.   Ayahuasca		
5.   bonus track:      Bucephalus Bouncing Ball - by Aphex Twin 	
       (Boomerangs unauthorized Human-Robot Sex mix) 	
_______
Some interesting samples used: 

(1) Wanderers   
Artists: For voice samples, Wanderers was based almost entirely on astronomer/philosopher Carl
Sagan reading his book Pale Blue Dot.  Other audio text from Frank Herbert (author of Dune)     
Films: Total Eclipse   --[among others]--

(2) Your a Idiot     
Artists: Joe Frank, Beastie Boys (Q-Tip vox), Disasterous Customer Service      
Films: Friday, Ghost World, Full Metal Jacket, Macarthur Park, George B., Zoolander, Scary Movie,
The Score   --[among others]--

(3) Ready to Go   
Artists:  The Greaseman, Khalil, Eazy-E  & NWA, Dr. Dre, US3.     
Films:  Scary Movie 2, Dead Man on Campus, Mr. Deeds, Artificial Intelligence, The Heist,
Zoolander;     --[among others]--  
     
(4) Ayahuasca      
Artists: Carl Sagan, Frank Herbert, radio dub of unknown author      
Films: Dopamine, Powder (Goldblum) --[among others]

(5) Bucephalus Bouncing Ball (boomerangs Human-Robot Sex remix)  
Artists: Bucephalus Bouncing Ball by Aphex Twin, in its entirety.  Apologies to Richard James for
my unauthorized overdub of his song.  The Aphex Twin song is a breath-taking mess of jungle music
fallen to beautiful catastrophe. 
Artists: Isaac Asimov,  George Herbert, Kraftwerk (we are robots),  Styx (mr. roboto), Carl Sagan
(Pale Blue Dot), microphone visionary Mike Patton (faith no more) for inspiration and samples from
his Robot Sex recordings, DJ 7Ups dj tools.       
Films:  Gregorys Girl, I Robot, Artificial Intelligence, Alien Hunter, the Banger Sisters, Total
Eclipse,  the Heist,

Apologies for any copyright credits  that have been overlooked.

> > >
> > > -- Paulie Paul

> > >
> > > "It is one of life's mysteries how an ounce of understanding, cleanses
> >an
> > > ocean of mistrust and hate"
> > > (The Outer Limits)
> > >
> > > >From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
> > > >To: "Philip.X.Diaz" <st_indigo@earthlink.net>
> > > >CC: The Twilight Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > > >Subject: Re: [sfraves] hiding an IM
> > > >Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 16:01:50 -0800 (PST)
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >So AIM does two things that are kinda obvious from the network... it's
> > > >port (5190-5193) and the IP's it talks to (sucky is that the IP gets
> > > >dynamically assigned from session to session by login.oscar.aol.com but
> > > >AOL in genral is 64.12.0.0 + 205.188.0.0).  Also, like most chat
> > > >protocols, it is MASSIVELY sniffable... you can literally just tap port
> > > >5190 and watch that shit float by like leaves in a stream... a perl one
> > > >liner fixes it up to be as readable as your chat logs.
> > > >
> > > >So you have to use an alternate port _AND_ destination IP block if you
> > > >want to totally hide your nasty bizniz.  Plus, if they do find it, you
> > > >want to try encrypting it.
> > > >
> > > >Just using a client that supports the AOL AIM server's SSH ability is
> > > >enough to throw off most network admins.  You can find AIM clients that
> > > >support SSH, I actually took a liking to an app called NAIM for
> >anything
> > > >that can compile *nix stuff... (works a lot like IRC, all text from a
> > > >terminal, supports color and mssg cueing).  Using this app takes care
> >of
> > > >the protocol/port problem and also is an obscure app they probably
> >won't
> > > >look for... but it's still talking directly to the AOL servers and can
> >be
> > > >detected or blocked... but not read (they'll know what you're doing,
> >but
> > > >not what you're saying).
> > > >
> > > >Ideally, if you have an offsite computer running unix that you can ssh
> >to,
> > > >run naim there (I've compiled it no prob for solaris, osx, linuxes &
> > > >bsd)... then your work only sees an ssh connect to your server (this is
> > > >what I do).  One ssh session, and screen (a terminal window manager
> >that
> > > >allows you to run multiple windows and disconnected/attach without
> > > >skipping a beat) and you're gravy.
> > > >
> > > >More answers on AIM for the sneaky here
> > > >http://www.unto.net/unto/work/aim_over_ssh.html
> > > >
> > > >Naim info:
> > > >http://site.n.ml.org/info/naim/
> > > >
> > > >Not too easy... but you're hoping to outsmart your network admin, who
> >does
> > > >this shit for a living if they're any good.  :)
> > > >
> > > >andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
> > >
> > >\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
> > > >"Nothing real can defeat us.  Nothing unreal exists." - Buckaroo Banzai
> > > >

Fwding this conversation, in case anyone else was confused about changes to the CD:
_____________

> > The one I got had Fila Brazilla on it
> > though. 


the 5 tracks i just mentioned are new [WInter 05].  the Fila Brazilla dub is years old & has been
on a lot of my past CDs.  My friends suggested I narrow "Nothing Left"  down to just original
and/or new tracks to avoid confusion about what's what's new or what's original.     

I have a habit of recycling & renovating & re-rereleasing.... but not everyone appreciates it.

_________

From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: petersandifer@sbcglobal.net,

In-Reply-To: <20050217001550.45654.qmail@web81403.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] traffic jams, chaos theory, and community

Well see its not that things happen for "no reason"
its just that the real reasons aren't as impressive as
we'd like them to be.  The woman tapping on her brake
might be the reason for a traffic jam an hour later,
but that doesn't satisfy us as an explanation.  We
need the matress in lane 3 to make us feel safe and
warm.

Also chaos theory (the math not the magic) tells us
that without precise knowledge of the initial
conditions we can't predict the behavior of certain
types of systems even over very short time periods. 
So while it might be true that the woman tapping on
her brakes caused the traffic jam, we'll never be able
to know that unless we track every single car on the
freeway with perfect accuracy.

Yes I studied this shit back in the day at UC Santa
Cruz, with folks like Ralph Abraham
(http://www.ralphabraham.org) and John Guckenheimer. 
My professors were sneaking off into a basement to
watch dripping faucets
(http://www.aerialpress.com/aerial/drip.html), the
grad students were developing shoe born computers to
predict roulette wheel outrcomes and make some cash in
Vegas (http://www.thomasbass.com/work2.htm), and the
rest of us were tramping around wide eyed in Elfland
(http://www.lifeamgood.com/01aprsanta.html) and what I
and my friends called the Pits of Foulness, the waist
deep muddy pits behind the campus often surrounded by
giant toadstools, looking for God or the devil or
maybe just our car keys.  Which way leads back to the
witches circle?

FWIW Ralph Abraham is an amazing teacher who can
demonstrate the truth of a complex mathematical
theorem with a single drawing.  Taking classes from
him was trully eye opening.  He also did some things
with Terrance McKenna and is an ally of Eros, Gaia,
and magick.

See also http://www.techgnosis.com/trialogue.html

And another weird but interesting link I foudn in
writing this:
http://www.jamesmith.com/archives/2005/01/computational_a.html#endnote_ref_1

FWIW I can't stomach Scotch.

Regards,

Peter


--- Intergalactic Ambassador
<petersandifer@sbcglobal.net> wrote:

> abcnews is just now picking up on this story about
> traffic jams,  which was a model used years ago
> by chaos theorists  trying discover an order of
> happenstances in Nature.  
> 
>
http://userfs.cec.wustl.edu/~ce560/The%20Physics%20of%20Gridlock%20-%2000_12.htm
> 
> the idea is that many traffic jams happen for "no
> reason"-- no accident, no mattress in lane 3,
> but instead, the fact that 15 minutes ago, a driver
> miles ahead of you tapped her brake pedal at a
> time & place that was perfect for creating a chain
> reaction that leads to a meaningless traffic
> jam.
> 
> why's this important?  i guess because it reminds us
> that what we do know might influence events
> long after we've made a decision, turned it into an
> action,  and waltzed away to the next scene. 
> 
> Spiritualists of the Chaos vein tell us that this is
> why we should do *good things.*  But what
> about the chain of events that might cause an act of
> charity to result in terrible things?  (Like
> helping some diseased geezer across the street
> stalls the traffic flow enough to allow a taxicab
> to flatten your beloved fiance 10 blocks away)
> 
> I need to do some more math.  Until then, PLEASE
> don't do anything.  Opening windows and doors is
> particularly risky, especially if your crib is dusty
> or you have a mischievious cat.
> 
> If you *must* do something,  try to make it a
> positive interaction.  
> 
> Some scientists believe that positive actions make
> the subject feel like rotten ass, but I have
> another theory: that positive actions make the
> subject feel good, even if the action results in
> the subject's lover being flattened by a taxicab.  
> 
> I just need batteries for my calculator.  And a
> glass of Scotch to take the wack out of this weed.
> 
> boomerang fidget
> Junior Analyst
> Platypus Road Laboratory 
> Oxford University
> Oxford 
> OX4 1R5
> (Petticoat Lane entry)

Help--  list moderator!   

Peter Rothman keeps challenging my stoney, 
regurgitated armchair pseudo-science NRR's!    


So, you like, actually know about stuff that I pretend to grasp.  
Those websites look interesting-- I'mma cheeck them out tonight.  
Meantime, I'm off to school to study... the social sciences. 

I'm a little intimidated about sending that CD now...  I hope you're OK 
with Carl Sagan.  He was such a poetic dreamboat.  

see you out soon, Mr. Rothman.  We'll talk science & shoot the shit.
peace, and thanks for the learnin'!

peter  

"BILLions and BILLions of stars."
     - Carl Sagan


--- Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

> Well see its not that things happen for "no reason"
> its just that the real reasons aren't as impressive as
> we'd like them to be.  The woman tapping on her brake
> might be the reason for a traffic jam an hour later,
> but that doesn't satisfy us as an explanation.  We
> need the matress in lane 3 to make us feel safe and
> warm.
> 
> Also chaos theory (the math not the magic) tells us
> that without precise knowledge of the initial
> conditions we can't predict the behavior of certain
> types of systems even over very short time periods. 
> So while it might be true that the woman tapping on
> her brakes caused the traffic jam, we'll never be able
> to know that unless we track every single car on the
> freeway with perfect accuracy.
> 
> Yes I studied this shit back in the day at UC Santa
> Cruz, with folks like Ralph Abraham
> (http://www.ralphabraham.org) and John Guckenheimer. 
> My professors were sneaking off into a basement to
> watch dripping faucets
> (http://www.aerialpress.com/aerial/drip.html), the
> grad students were developing shoe born computers to
> predict roulette wheel outrcomes and make some cash in
> Vegas (http://www.thomasbass.com/work2.htm), and the
> rest of us were tramping around wide eyed in Elfland
> (http://www.lifeamgood.com/01aprsanta.html) and what I
> and my friends called the Pits of Foulness, the waist
> deep muddy pits behind the campus often surrounded by
> giant toadstools, looking for God or the devil or
> maybe just our car keys.  Which way leads back to the
> witches circle?
> 
> FWIW Ralph Abraham is an amazing teacher who can
> demonstrate the truth of a complex mathematical
> theorem with a single drawing.  Taking classes from
> him was trully eye opening.  He also did some things
> with Terrance McKenna and is an ally of Eros, Gaia,
> and magick.
> 
> See also http://www.techgnosis.com/trialogue.html
> 
> And another weird but interesting link I foudn in
> writing this:
> http://www.jamesmith.com/archives/2005/01/computational_a.html#endnote_ref_1
> 
> FWIW I can't stomach Scotch.
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Peter
> 
> 
> --- Intergalactic Ambassador
> <petersandifer@sbcglobal.net> wrote:
> 
> > abcnews is just now picking up on this story about
> > traffic jams,  which was a model used years ago
> > by chaos theorists  trying discover an order of
> > happenstances in Nature.  
> > 
> >
> http://userfs.cec.wustl.edu/~ce560/The%20Physics%20of%20Gridlock%20-%2000_12.htm
> > 
> > the idea is that many traffic jams happen for "no
> > reason"-- no accident, no mattress in lane 3,
> > but instead, the fact that 15 minutes ago, a driver
> > miles ahead of you tapped her brake pedal at a
> > time & place that was perfect for creating a chain
> > reaction that leads to a meaningless traffic
> > jam.
> > 
> > why's this important?  i guess because it reminds us
> > that what we do know might influence events
> > long after we've made a decision, turned it into an
> > action,  and waltzed away to the next scene. 
> > 
> > Spiritualists of the Chaos vein tell us that this is
> > why we should do *good things.*  But what
> > about the chain of events that might cause an act of
> > charity to result in terrible things?  (Like
> > helping some diseased geezer across the street
> > stalls the traffic flow enough to allow a taxicab
> > to flatten your beloved fiance 10 blocks away)
> > 
> > I need to do some more math.  Until then, PLEASE
> > don't do anything.  Opening windows and doors is
> > particularly risky, especially if your crib is dusty
> > or you have a mischievious cat.
> > 
> > If you *must* do something,  try to make it a
> > positive interaction.  
> > 
> > Some scientists believe that positive actions make
> > the subject feel like rotten ass, but I have
> > another theory: that positive actions make the
> > subject feel good, even if the action results in
> > the subject's lover being flattened by a taxicab.  
> > 
> > I just need batteries for my calculator.  And a

>From another list, fuck this guy and the condescending attitude.


letters@nytimes.com

include your name, address, and telephone numbers.

Subject: Simon Reynold's New York Times article                         

Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company
The New York Times

January 23, 2005 Sunday
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 2; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk; MUSIC; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 1626 words

HEADLINE: The Turn Away From the Turntable

BYLINE: By SIMON REYNOLDS

BODY:


IN the first months of 2005, two of electronic dance music's biggest
bands will release what are generally referred to as long-awaited
albums. But what's uncertain is how many people are actually waiting
to greet the Chemical Brothers' ''Push the Button,'' out this week, or
Daft Punk's ''Human After All,'' due in March. If the humiliatingly
lukewarm response to last fall's comeback albums by the top dance acts
the Prodigy and Fatboy Slim is any measure, neither Daft Punk nor the
Chemical Brothers ought to bank on teeming throngs at the record
stores or a warm radio welcome.

During the halcyon days of the late 90's, these groups were the Big
Four of crossover electronica, their music fusing techno's pounding
machine rhythms with anthemic hooks and hard riffs that worked as well
on rock radio as they did on the dance floor. The Prodigy's success
eclipsed everybody else's (''The Fat of the Land'' sold nearly three
million copies in America alone), but Daft Punk and Chemical Brothers
enjoyed MTV hits (''Da Funk'' and ''Setting Sun,'' respectively),
while tracks by Fatboy Slim achieved ubiquity via movie soundtracks
and TV commercials.

In those days, electronica was so trendy that Madonna jumped on two
different techno bandwagons in swift succession, assimilating the
euphoric riffs of trance with ''Ray of Light'' and aping the spangly
effervescence of French house on ''Music.'' The bullish mood in the
electronic community back then was typified by Paul Oakenfold, the
British superstar D.J., who tried to break his moistly emotional brand
of trance in America, in the belief that this country was set to be
dance music's next big commercial frontier.

Quite the opposite happened. In the new millennium, the mainstream
profile of dance music dipped alarmingly. This downturn occurred on
both sides of the Atlantic, but it was particularly precipitous in
America, where electronica was edged off of the charts by the twin
juggernauts of nu-metal and pop-punk, along with the perennial might
of hip-hop. But it wasn't just a case of mass-media gatekeepers
abandoning electronic music. Something was ailing at the grass roots
of the scene. Formerly packed superclubs began to close, or move to
smaller venues. Large raves, once the mainstay of dance culture,
became nearly extinct. ''Rave is dead in the Los Angeles area,'' says
the West Coast scene watcher Dennis Romero, who is news editor at the
dance magazine BPM.

As recently as 2001, Southern California was still the most vibrant
rave scene in America, but according to Mr. Romero, the kids just
aren't coming out to big events anymore, partly because of Ecstasy
burnout. ''The superclubs here are starting to see diminishing numbers
as well,'' Mr. Romero says, ''with popular nights like Spundae taking
a hiatus and Red closing down altogether.''

Not only were sales of crossover-oriented electronica plummeting; the
underground dance music sold in specialist record stores also
declined. Some of those shops have closed because business is slow and
record labels are suffering. ''People I know who run labels keep
getting worse and worse news,'' says William Linn, a San
Francisco-based dance party promoter. ''Partly it's because of the
Internet, people just taking the music for free. But it's also because
people aren't buying the stuff in the way they were when the music was
a really new thing back in the early 90's.'' During that rave culture
heyday, an underground anthem could sell anywhere from 10,000 to
50,000 copies. Today, shifting a thousand copies of a 12-inch single
is considered a good result.

What happened? One cause is the continued fragmentation of dance
culture into myriad micro-genres with narrow aesthetic parameters and
niche followings. Another factor is musical overproduction, which
effectively divides the pie into smaller slices. But the overall pie
also seems to be shrinking as well. Dance music has simply lost the
ear of the floating consumer. This may be, in part, a matter of
fashion: electronic dance music had been around long enough to lose
its ''new kid on the subcultural block'' status. The music had become
familiar, and familiarity bred ennui.

Other genres have certainly suffered this kind of problem; dance music
is going through the kind of midlife crisis that afflicts any genre
that's been around a while (think rock music in the 1980's). ''We're
just waiting for the next Big New Thing in dance music to come
along,'' says Norman Cook, the man behind Fatboy Slim. ''Right now
we're between New Things, and no one quite knows what the next one
will be.''

The central idea of electronic music's unwritten manifesto was always
to surge full-tilt into the future. But in recent years many creators
of dance music have been investigating the genre's own history,
reworking ideas from electro, synthpop and Italodisco. Even more
oddly, others have been looking to rock music for reinvigoration. Mr.
Cook's ''Palookaville'' used rock instrumentation (guitar and bass)
and more conventional verse/chorus song structures. Last year's
biggest dancefloor anthem was Alter Ego's ''Rocker,'' whose simple,
chugging rhythm and squealing riffs are transparently modeled on heavy
metal. Swaths of Daft Punk's new album, ''Human After All,'' resemble
an electronicized version of hard rock. Two highly touted early 2005
albums, the self-titled debut from LCD Soundsystem and Mu's ''Out of
Breach,'' have a rough-hewn, ''live'' garage punk feel to much of
their contents.

Other currently hot outfits like Black Strobe, Tiefschwarz and Kiki
hark back to 80's alternative rock genres like Goth and industrial.
Kiki's ''End of the World,'' for instance, features the Finnish-born
producer paying vocal homage to the doomy, hollow-drone baritone of
Andrew Eldritch of the goth-rock gods Sisters of Mercy. Perhaps the
most bizarre example of dance music ransacking rock's archives was
last year's fad for schaffel (German for shuffle), which involved
producers renovating the stomping rhythms of 70's glam rock artists
like T. Rex and Gary Glitter. It's hard to say whether all these
different forms of rockified techno represent a subconscious attempt
by the scene to ingratiate its way back into the mainstream, or are
simply a case of producers looking for genre-crossing thrills. But
none of them exactly restake dance music's claim as the music of the
future.

Alongside its commitment to constant innovation, another central tenet
of dance culture was the idea of being underground, an outlaw scene.
In the early days, dance culture was oriented around one-off raves in
unusual locations, often involving organizers breaking into warehouses
or invading outdoor spaces. Proper safety codes were rarely observed,
drugs were rife and the behavior of the participants verged on
anarchy. Gradually, the thrills and dangers of raves were replaced by
the more reliable pleasures offered by superclubs -- organized by
professionals and regularly scheduled but still fairly wild in terms
of drug-fueled hedonism.

Today, the action is mostly in small clubs -- like APT (419 West 13th
Street) and Ikon (610 West 56th Street) in Manhattan -- in some cases
barely more than glorified bars. There, the audience exudes a
clean-cut, metrosexual aura. At times it feels as if the room has been
teleported to a chic bar in Barcelona or Berlin, especially as, more
often than not, the D.J. is from Europe. Germany, in particular, is
the spiritual homeland for American dance hipsters these days. Most of
the leading labels -- Kompakt, B-Pitch Control, Playhouse, Get
Physical -- are based there. In fact, some North American D.J.'s and
producers like Richie Hawtin have moved to Germany because the climate
for electronic music is more supportive.

If neither sonic futurism nor underground edginess apply any longer,
electronic dance music's remaining raison d'etre is, well, dancing.
But in recent years it may have been beaten on the shake-your-booty
front by dancehall and Southern rap. In response, some dance producers
have started to draw upon raucously vibrant ''street'' beats: crunk,
Miami bass, dancehall, grime and so forth.

The result is a growing hybrid genre, highlighted on the recent,
excellent compilation ''Shockout,'' known as ''breakcore.'' Purveyed
by artists like DJ/Rupture and Teamshadetek, the music combines
rumbling basslines, fidgety beats and grainy ragga vocals to create a
home-listening surrogate for the ''bashment'' vibe of a Jamaican sound
system party. Others within the breakcore genre, like Knifehandchop,
Kid 606 and Soundmurderer, hark back to rave's own early days, their
music evoking the rowdy fervor of a time when huge crowds flailed
their limbs to a barrage of abstract noise and convulsive rhythm. It's
a poignant aural mirage of a time when techno music was made for the
popular vanguard rather than a connoisseurial elite, as it is today.

Today's sharpest contemporary dance music operators, like Tiefschwarz
or LCD Soundsystem, are roughly equivalent to recombinant rock auteurs
of the 90's like PJ Harvey and Pavement, who generated sounds that
weren't strictly innovative but managed to somehow feel original.
Tiefschwarz's brothers-in-production duo Ali and Basti Schwarz and
LCD's James Murphy have an almost scholarly knowledge of dance music
history. They're adept at getting period sounds, but they combine them
in fresh ways.

On LCD's album and Tiefschwarz's superb remix collection ''Misch
Masch,'' we don't really encounter the shock of the new; instead we
get the frisson of novelty, subtle twists and cunning permutations
within an established form. Which will have to be enough for now,
until dance music producers once again figure out how to smack
listeners upside the head with sonic strangeness.



URL: http://www.nytimes.com

-------------------------------1108672251

itar and bass)<BR>and more conventional verse/chorus song structures. Last y=
ear's<BR>biggest dancefloor anthem was Alter Ego's ''Rocker,'' whose simple,=
<BR>chugging rhythm and squealing riffs are transparently modeled on heavy<B=
R>metal. Swaths of Daft Punk's new album, ''Human After All,'' resemble<BR>a=
n electronicized version of hard rock. Two highly touted early 2005<BR>album=
s, the self-titled debut from LCD Soundsystem and Mu's ''Out of<BR>Breach,''=
 have a rough-hewn, ''live'' garage punk feel to much of<BR>their contents.<=
BR><BR>Other currently hot outfits like Black Strobe, Tiefschwarz and Kiki<B=
R>hark back to 80's alternative rock genres like Goth and industrial.<BR>Kik=
i's ''End of the World,'' for instance, features the Finnish-born<BR>produce=
r paying vocal homage to the doomy, hollow-drone baritone of<BR>Andrew Eldri=
tch of the goth-rock gods Sisters of Mercy. Perhaps the<BR>most bizarre exam=
ple of dance music ransacking rock's archives was<BR>last year's fad for sch=
affel (German for shuffle), which involved<BR>producers renovating the stomp=
ing rhythms of 70's glam rock artists<BR>like T. Rex and Gary Glitter. It's=20=
hard to say whether all these<BR>different forms of rockified techno represe=
nt a subconscious attempt<BR>by the scene to ingratiate its way back into th=
e mainstream, or are<BR>simply a case of producers looking for genre-crossin=
g thrills. But<BR>none of them exactly restake dance music's claim as the mu=
sic of the<BR>future.<BR><BR>Alongside its commitment to constant innovation=
, another central tenet<BR>of dance culture was the idea of being undergroun=
d, an outlaw scene.<BR>In the early days, dance culture was oriented around=20=
one-off raves in<BR>unusual locations, often involving organizers breaking i=
nto warehouses<BR>or invading outdoor spaces. Proper safety codes were rarel=
y observed,<BR>drugs were rife and the behavior of the participants verged o=
n<BR>anarchy. Gradually, the thrills and dangers of raves were replaced by<B=
R>the more reliable pleasures offered by superclubs -- organized by<BR>profe=
ssionals and regularly scheduled but still fairly wild in terms<BR>of drug-f=
ueled hedonism.<BR><BR>Today, the action is mostly in small clubs -- like AP=
T (419 West 13th<BR>Street) and Ikon (610 West 56th Street) in Manhattan --=20=
in some cases<BR>barely more than glorified bars. There, the audience exudes=
 a<BR>clean-cut, metrosexual aura. At times it feels as if the room has been=
<BR>teleported to a chic bar in Barcelona or Berlin, especially as, more<BR>=
often than not, the D.J. is from Europe. Germany, in particular, is<BR>the s=
piritual homeland for American dance hipsters these days. Most of<BR>the lea=
ding labels -- Kompakt, B-Pitch Control, Playhouse, Get<BR>Physical -- are b=
ased there. In fact, some North American D.J.'s and<BR>producers like Richie=
 Hawtin have moved to Germany because the climate<BR>for electronic music is=
 more supportive.<BR><BR>If neither sonic futurism nor underground edginess=20=
apply any longer,<BR>electronic dance music's remaining raison d'etre is, we=
ll, dancing.<BR>But in recent years it may have been beaten on the shake-you=
r-booty<BR>front by dancehall and Southern rap. In response, some dance prod=
ucers<BR>have started to draw upon raucously vibrant ''street'' beats: crunk=
,<BR>Miami bass, dancehall, grime and so forth.<BR><BR>The result is a growi=
ng hybrid genre, highlighted on the recent,<BR>excellent compilation ''Shock=
out,'' known as ''breakcore.'' Purveyed<BR>by artists like DJ/Rupture and Te=
amshadetek, the music combines<BR>rumbling basslines, fidgety beats and grai=
ny ragga vocals to create a<BR>home-listening surrogate for the ''bashment''=
 vibe of a Jamaican sound<BR>system party. Others within the breakcore genre=
, like Knifehandchop,<BR>Kid 606 and Soundmurderer, hark back to rave's own=20=
early days, their<BR>music evoking the rowdy fervor of a time when huge crow=
ds flailed<BR>their limbs to a barrage of abstract noise and convulsive rhyt=
hm. It's<BR>a poignant aural mirage of a time when techno music was made for=
 the<BR>popular vanguard rather than a connoisseurial elite, as it is today.=
<BR><BR>Today's sharpest contemporary dance music operators, like Tiefschwar=
z<BR>or LCD Soundsystem, are roughly equivalent to recombinant rock auteurs<=
BR>of the 90's like PJ Harvey and Pavement, who generated sounds that<BR>wer=
en't strictly innovative but managed to somehow feel original.<BR>Tiefschwar=
z's brothers-in-production duo Ali and Basti Schwarz and<BR>LCD's James Murp=
hy have an almost scholarly knowledge of dance music<BR>history. They're ade=
pt at getting period sounds, but they combine them<BR>in fresh ways.<BR><BR>=
On LCD's album and Tiefschwarz's superb remix collection ''Misch<BR>Masch,''=
 we don't really encounter the shock of the new; instead we<BR>get the friss=
on of novelty, subtle twists and cunning permutations<BR>within an establish=
ed form. Which will have to be enough for now,<BR>until dance music producer=
s once again figure out how to smack<BR>listeners upside the head with sonic=
 strangeness.<BR><BR><BR><BR>URL: http://www.nytimes.com</DIV></BODY></HTML>

-------------------------------1108672251--

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  *Ecstasy trials for combat stress*

--=====================_6364431==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

http://www.guardian.co.uk/usa/story/0,12271,1416073,00.html


*Ecstasy trials for combat stress*

*David Adam, science correspondent
Thursday February 17, 2005
<http://www.guardian.co.uk>*

American soldiers traumatised by fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan are to be 
offered the drug ecstasy to help free them of flashbacks and recurring 
nightmares.

The US food and drug administration has given the go-ahead for the soldiers 
to be included in an experiment to see if MDMA, the active ingredient in 
ecstasy, can treat post-traumatic stress disorder.

Scientists behind the trial in South Carolina think the feelings of 
emotional closeness reported by those taking the drug could help the 
soldiers talk about their experiences to therapists. Several victims of 
rape and sexual abuse with post-traumatic stress disorder, for whom 
existing treatments are ineffective, have been given MDMA since the 
research began last year.

Michael Mithoefer, the psychiatrist leading the trial, said: "It's looking 
very promising. It's too early to draw any conclusions but in these 
treatment-resistant people so far the results are encouraging.

"People are able to connect more deeply on an emotional level with the fact 
they are safe now."

He is about to advertise for war veterans who fought in the last five years 
to join the study.

According to the US national centre for post-traumatic stress disorder, up 
to 30% of combat veterans suffer from the condition at some point in their 
lives.

Known as shell shock during the first world war and combat fatigue in the 
second, the condition is characterised by intrusive memories, panic attacks 
and the avoidance of situations which might force sufferers to relive their 
wartime experiences.

Dr Mithoefer said the MDMA helped people discuss traumatic situations 
without triggering anxiety.

"It appears to act as a catalyst to help people move through whatever's 
been blocking their success in therapy."

The existing drug-assisted therapy sessions last up to eight hours, during 
music is played. The patients swallow a capsule containing a placebo or 
125mg of MDMA - about the same or a little more than a typical ecstasy tablet.

Psychologists assess the patients before and after the trial to judge 
whether the drug has helped.

The study has provoked controversy, because significant doubts remain about 
the long-term risks of ecstasy.

Animal studies suggest that it lowers levels of the brain chemical 
serotonin, and some politicians and anti-drug campaigners have argued that 
research into possible medical benefits of illegal drugs presents a falsely 
reassuring message.

The South Carolina study marks a resurgence of interest in the use of 
controlled psychedelic and hallucinogenic drugs. Several studies in the US 
are planned or are under way to investigate whether MDMA, LSD and 
psilocybin, the active ingredient in magic mushrooms, can treat conditions 
ranging from obsessive compulsive disorder to anxiety in terminal cancer 
patients.

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] DIRTY this Saturday - the final BSP

is anyone else relieved that it's finally friday?  but what's up with the 
rain?  don't let it dampen your spirits though, this weekend is packed with 
events to make you forget its gloomy and wet outside!

this saturday is Evil Break's first club event since the last Dirty in 
November with the Autobots.  and if you were there, you know what a rockin' 
night that was!  and we're gonna bring it again for all of you this weekend 
with Future Funk Squad!  hope you can join us as we get:

DIRTY
Saturday, February 19th
@ 330 Ritch, SF
2 rooms a'rockin'
9pm - 3am
$7 b4 11 / $10 after

Yeah you heard that right. DIRTY is back and comin at you with some 
nastiness. Come check out our new monthly venue that we'll be sharing with 
Subscience.  For our first night, we've got some wicked breaks and dirty 
techno.  Come to get down.

Featuring:
FUTURE FUNK SQUAD
(Functional breaks/Island/En:vision/Default/Cryptic) - UK
This man needs no introduction.  Making beats since 1999, Future Funk Squad 
has produced a consistent stream of breakbeat stormers and remixed the likes 
of Moloko, Stanton Warriors and Koma+Bones.  With over 10 years of DJing 
experience, he will do the unthinkably nasty to your earholes!

Breakbeat Extravaganza:
Smoove (Space Cowboys/Newsbreakz/Opel) - Nitevibe Dreamteam 2005
Aaron Jae vs. Bam (Evil Breaks/AaronJae.com/Invibe)
M.O.D. vs. Influence (Evil Breaks/In tha Mix)
Marc(O) (*THWAP!*/Moksha Tribe)

Techno Delights:
Forest Green (SisterSF/Dim Sum/Forestgreen.org)
Andy W (Resource Records/Viberation)
Juan Segovia (Hugger-Mugger/tech-on)
G.A.M.M.A. vs. Mek (Techno-truth/Stilldream)

9pm - 3am
@ 330 Ritch
$7 before 11pm and only $10 after that, so get there early.

--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

February 19th:  Dirty w/ Future Funk Squad @ 330 Ritch
March 4th:  ModILLfied @ Shadow Lounge
March 5th:  Clandestine in SF
March 11th:  Urbanology
March 19th:  Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary Party
April 29th:  Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty
---------------------

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Want It Radio - sundays 3-7pm PST

--0-1727127178-1108756493=:14655
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

introducing Want It Radio, another internet radio show set to blow up speakers and piss off the neighbors. check it out sundays from 3:00 - 7:00 pm (or whenever, really, depending on how much debauchery is going down in the studio that week). links below:
 
http://radio.wantit.org
 
or, if you want to skip a step: http://www.live365.com/stations/campwantit
 
and now for a bit of history: this project actually started as a burning man camp. as we all know, any group of 30+ is bound to have some DJs hanging around, so those of us local to SF got together and decided to broadcast a show once a week. the rest of our campmates are all over the country and in canada, so this was originally a way for them to get to hear the sounds of Want It all year round. 
 
now that we've ironed out some technical kinks, we've decided to share it with the masses. it is also going to be a vehicle through which we audition DJs for performances at our camp on the playa this year. i'm going to be up to my ears in demo CDs from all over the planet, but anyone local who would rather play for us live than record a demo should drop me an email. 
 
the show is going to focus primarily on house, breaks, and techno, but there will undoubtedly be times where we dig deep into the crates and play a bit of whatever-the-fuck. if this sounds like something you can get down to, then tune in.
 
word to your gramma...
 
love,
mo

> open-minded than most promoters in the bay area. :)
> 
> What I'm specifically looking for is more along the lines of IDM and
> weird acid tracks. Glitchy stuff is right up my alley too, so if you
> play anything abstract and noisey, I'd be interested in hearing some of
> it--as long as it's not too aggro. Anything that could be described as
> "deep", "dubby" and "minimal" works for me. Experimental trip-hop and
> anything else along those lines could work as well.
>

> to listen to MP3s, but if you want to send me a CD let me know and I'll
> give you my address. My next night to book is 3/8, but if I like your
> stuff and the lineup is full I'll gladly recommend you to one of the

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Not Your Parent's Drug Test

--=====================_15057451==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


Not Your Parent's Drug Test

By <http://www.alternet.org/authors/3513/>Paul Armentano, 
<http://www.reason.com/>Reason. Posted 
<http://www.alternet.org/ts/archives/?date%5BF%5D=02&date%5BY%5D=2005&date%5Bd%5D=15&act=Go/>February 
15, 2005.

A surge in the number of Americans peeing on demand has coincided with an 
explosion of alternative drug testing technology.

One look at the 
<http://www.cozart.co.uk/articles.asp?ConferenceID=34>Cozart RapiScan, a 
self-proclaimed complete "on-site oral fluid drugs of abuse diagnostic 
system," and it's obvious: This isn't your parents' drug test. Gone are the 
golden days of the plastic collection cup. The Cozart saliva testing system 
comes in a spiffy silver suitcase and consists of an oral fluid collection 
swab, a disposable test cartridge, its own handheld digital computer, and a 
portable printer "for a permanent record of test results."

The official U.S. distributor of the RapiScan, The Dominion Diagnostics 
Corporation, was one of many hi-tech exhibitors hawking their wares in 
Tampa last spring at a meeting of corporate drug testers, toxicologists and 
law enforcement officers, sponsored, in part, by the Office of National 
Drug Control Policy (a.k.a. the drug czar's office). But this White 
House-backed gathering was no trade show. The purpose of this symposium  
and the intent of the bodily fluid snoopers in attendance  was to call for 
an unprecedented, government-mandated expansion of both drug testing and 
the application of new drug-screening technology  and not just for those 
within the workplace. And the pee police may be close to getting their wish.

MORE:  http://www.alternet.org/drugreporter/21267/




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fwd: Simon Reynold's New York Times article  


> fuck this guy and the condescending attitude.

interesting interpretation.    Simon Reynolds isn't necessarily a pop journalist trying to create
a controversial spin.  His book "Generation Ecstasy"  is 389 pages of research into what we
lunatics do in dirty warehouses every weekend.

If his tone is condescending, he's probably doing it for journalistic objectivity (an Osby for
every AndyW, y'know )  You can't write about the importance of EDM culture without acknowledging
the negatives.  That would make it to easy for readers to dismiss as starry-eyed freshman
propaganda.

Or maybe this is the cynicism we all feel when the pills stop working.

see ya on the dance floor,
booms



> Subject: Simon Reynold's New York Times article                         
> HEADLINE: The Turn Away From the Turntable
> 
> BYLINE: By SIMON REYNOLDS
> 
> IN the first months of 2005, two of electronic dance music's biggest
> bands will release what are generally referred to as long-awaited
> albums. But what's uncertain is how many people are actually waiting
> to greet the Chemical Brothers' ''Push the Button,'' out this week, or
> Daft Punk's ''Human After All,'' due in March. If the humiliatingly
> lukewarm response to last fall's comeback albums by the top dance acts
> the Prodigy and Fatboy Slim is any measure, neither Daft Punk nor the
> Chemical Brothers ought to bank on teeming throngs at the record
> stores or a warm radio welcome.
> 
> During the halcyon days of the late 90's, these groups were the Big
> Four of crossover electronica, their music fusing techno's pounding
> machine rhythms with anthemic hooks and hard riffs that worked as well
> on rock radio as they did on the dance floor. The Prodigy's success
> eclipsed everybody else's (''The Fat of the Land'' sold nearly three
> million copies in America alone), but Daft Punk and Chemical Brothers
> enjoyed MTV hits (''Da Funk'' and ''Setting Sun,'' respectively),
> while tracks by Fatboy Slim achieved ubiquity via movie soundtracks
> and TV commercials.
> 
> In those days, electronica was so trendy that Madonna jumped on two
> different techno bandwagons in swift succession, assimilating the
> euphoric riffs of trance with ''Ray of Light'' and aping the spangly
> effervescence of French house on ''Music.'' The bullish mood in the
> electronic community back then was typified by Paul Oakenfold, the
> British superstar D.J., who tried to break his moistly emotional brand
> of trance in America, in the belief that this country was set to be
> dance music's next big commercial frontier.
> 
> Quite the opposite happened. In the new millennium, the mainstream
> profile of dance music dipped alarmingly. This downturn occurred on
> both sides of the Atlantic, but it was particularly precipitous in
> America, where electronica was edged off of the charts by the twin
> juggernauts of nu-metal and pop-punk, along with the perennial might
> of hip-hop. But it wasn't just a case of mass-media gatekeepers
> abandoning electronic music. Something was ailing at the grass roots
> of the scene. Formerly packed superclubs began to close, or move to
> smaller venues. Large raves, once the mainstay of dance culture,
> became nearly extinct. ''Rave is dead in the Los Angeles area,'' says
> the West Coast scene watcher Dennis Romero, who is news editor at the
> dance magazine BPM.
> 
> As recently as 2001, Southern California was still the most vibrant
> rave scene in America, but according to Mr. Romero, the kids just
> aren't coming out to big events anymore, partly because of Ecstasy
> burnout. ''The superclubs here are starting to see diminishing numbers
> as well,'' Mr. Romero says, ''with popular nights like Spundae taking
> a hiatus and Red closing down altogether.''
> 
> Not only were sales of crossover-oriented electronica plummeting; the
> underground dance music sold in specialist record stores also
> declined. Some of those shops have closed because business is slow and
> record labels are suffering. ''People I know who run labels keep
> getting worse and worse news,'' says William Linn, a San
> Francisco-based dance party promoter. ''Partly it's because of the
> Internet, people just taking the music for free. But it's also because
> people aren't buying the stuff in the way they were when the music was
> a really new thing back in the early 90's.'' During that rave culture
> heyday, an underground anthem could sell anywhere from 10,000 to
> 50,000 copies. Today, shifting a thousand copies of a 12-inch single
> is considered a good result.
> 
> What happened? One cause is the continued fragmentation of dance
> culture into myriad micro-genres with narrow aesthetic parameters and
> niche followings. Another factor is musical overproduction, which
> effectively divides the pie into smaller slices. But the overall pie
> also seems to be shrinking as well. Dance music has simply lost the
> ear of the floating consumer. This may be, in part, a matter of
> fashion: electronic dance music had been around long enough to lose
> its ''new kid on the subcultural block'' status. The music had become
> familiar, and familiarity bred ennui.
> 
> Other genres have certainly suffered this kind of problem; dance music
> is going through the kind of midlife crisis that afflicts any genre
> that's been around a while (think rock music in the 1980's). ''We're
> just waiting for the next Big New Thing in dance music to come
> along,'' says Norman Cook, the man behind Fatboy Slim. ''Right now
> we're between New Things, and no one quite knows what the next one
> will be.''
> 
> The central idea of electronic music's unwritten manifesto was always
> to surge full-tilt into the future. But in recent years many creators
> of dance music have been investigating the genre's own history,
> reworking ideas from electro, synthpop and Italodisco. Even more
> oddly, others have been looking to rock music for reinvigoration. Mr.
> Cook's ''Palookaville'' used rock instrumentation (guitar and bass)
> and more conventional verse/chorus song structures. Last year's
> biggest dancefloor anthem was Alter Ego's ''Rocker,'' whose simple,
> chugging rhythm and squealing riffs are transparently modeled on heavy
> metal. Swaths of Daft Punk's new album, ''Human After All,'' resemble
> an electronicized version of hard rock. Two highly touted early 2005
> albums, the self-titled debut from LCD Soundsystem and Mu's ''Out of
> Breach,'' have a rough-hewn, ''live'' garage punk feel to much of
> their contents.
> 
> Other currently hot outfits like Black Strobe, Tiefschwarz and Kiki
> hark back to 80's alternative rock genres like Goth and industrial.
> Kiki's ''End of the World,'' for instance, features the Finnish-born
> producer paying vocal homage to the doomy, hollow-drone baritone of
> Andrew Eldritch of the goth-rock gods Sisters of Mercy. Perhaps the
> most bizarre example of dance music ransacking rock's archives was
> last year's fad for schaffel (German for shuffle), which involved
> producers renovating the stomping rhythms of 70's glam rock artists
> like T. Rex and Gary Glitter. It's hard to say whether all these
> different forms of rockified techno represent a subconscious attempt
> by the scene to ingratiate its way back into the mainstream, or are
> simply a case of producers looking for genre-crossing thrills. But
> none of them exactly restake dance music's claim as the music of the
> future.
> 
> Alongside its commitment to constant innovation, another central tenet
> of dance culture was the idea of being underground, an outlaw scene.
> In the early days, dance culture was oriented around one-off raves in
> unusual locations, often involving organizers breaking into warehouses
> or invading outdoor spaces. Proper safety codes were rarely observed,
> drugs were rife and the behavior of the participants verged on
> anarchy. Gradually, the thrills and dangers of raves were replaced by
> the more reliable pleasures offered by superclubs -- organized by
> professionals and regularly scheduled but still fairly wild in terms
> of drug-fueled hedonism.
> 
> Today, the action is mostly in small clubs -- like APT (419 West 13th
> Street) and Ikon (610 West 56th Street) in Manhattan -- in some cases
> barely more than glorified bars. There, the audience exudes a
> clean-cut, metrosexual aura. At times it feels as if the room has been
> teleported to a chic bar in Barcelona or Berlin, especially as, more
> often than not, the D.J. is from Europe. Germany, in particular, is
> the spiritual homeland for American dance hipsters these days. Most of
> the leading labels -- Kompakt, B-Pitch Control, Playhouse, Get
> Physical -- are based there. In fact, some North American D.J.'s and
> producers like Richie Hawtin have moved to Germany because the climate
> for electronic music is more supportive.
> 
> If neither sonic futurism nor underground edginess apply any longer,
> electronic dance music's remaining raison d'etre is, well, dancing.
> But in recent years it may have been beaten on the shake-your-booty
> front by dancehall and Southern rap. In response, some dance producers
> have started to draw upon raucously vibrant ''street'' beats: crunk,
> Miami bass, dancehall, grime and so forth.
> 
> The result is a growing hybrid genre, highlighted on the recent,
> excellent compilation ''Shockout,'' known as ''breakcore.'' Purveyed
> by artists like DJ/Rupture and Teamshadetek, the music combines
> rumbling basslines, fidgety beats and grainy ragga vocals to create a
> home-listening surrogate for the ''bashment'' vibe of a Jamaican sound
> system party. Others within the breakcore genre, like Knifehandchop,
> Kid 606 and Soundmurderer, hark back to rave's own early days, their
> music evoking the rowdy fervor of a time when huge crowds flailed
> their limbs to a barrage of abstract noise and convulsive rhythm. It's
> a poignant aural mirage of a time when techno music was made for the
> popular vanguard rather than a connoisseurial elite, as it is today.
> 
> Today's sharpest contemporary dance music operators, like Tiefschwarz
> or LCD Soundsystem, are roughly equivalent to recombinant rock auteurs
> of the 90's like PJ Harvey and Pavement, who generated sounds that
> weren't strictly innovative but managed to somehow feel original.
> Tiefschwarz's brothers-in-production duo Ali and Basti Schwarz and
> LCD's James Murphy have an almost scholarly knowledge of dance music
> history. They're adept at getting period sounds, but they combine them
> in fresh ways.
> 
> On LCD's album and Tiefschwarz's superb remix collection ''Misch
> Masch,'' we don't really encounter the shock of the new; instead we
> get the frisson of novelty, subtle twists and cunning permutations
> within an established form. Which will have to be enough for now,
> until dance music producers once again figure out how to smack
> listeners upside the head with sonic strangeness.
> 
> 
> 
> URL: http://www.nytimes.com
> > ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

At 11:48 AM 2/19/2005, Apollo wrote:
>At 10:50 AM 2/19/2005, you wrote:
>>
>>If his tone is condescending, he's probably doing it for journalistic 
>>objectivity (an Osby for
>>every AndyW, y'know )  You can't write about the importance of EDM 
>>culture without acknowledging
>>the negatives.  That would make it to easy for readers to dismiss as 
>>starry-eyed freshman
>>propaganda.
>>
>>Or maybe this is the cynicism we all feel when the pills stop working.
>>
>>see ya on the dance floor,
>>booms

Hopefully with lots of b-boys:)




>> > Subject: Simon Reynold's New York Times article
>> > HEADLINE: The Turn Away From the Turntable
>> >
>> > BYLINE: By SIMON REYNOLDS
>> >
>>
>> >
>> > Alongside its commitment to constant innovation, another central tenet
>> > of dance culture was the idea of being underground, an outlaw scene.
>> > In the early days, dance culture was oriented around one-off raves in
>> > unusual locations, often involving organizers breaking into warehouses
>> > or invading outdoor spaces. Proper safety codes were rarely observed,
>> > drugs were rife and the behavior of the participants verged on
>> > anarchy. Gradually, the thrills and dangers of raves were replaced by
>> > the more reliable pleasures offered by superclubs -- organized by
>> > professionals and regularly scheduled but still fairly wild in terms
>> > of drug-fueled hedonism.


Yep, tis true.  When expectations are fulfilled life...and music...become 
boring.

>> >
>> > Today, the action is mostly in small clubs -- like APT (419 West 13th
>> > Street) and Ikon (610 West 56th Street) in Manhattan -- in some cases
>> > barely more than glorified bars. There, the audience exudes a
>> > clean-cut, metrosexual aura.

Save us from the metrosexual:)

>> > If neither sonic futurism nor underground edginess apply any longer,
>> > electronic dance music's remaining raison d'etre is, well, dancing.
>> > But in recent years it may have been beaten on the shake-your-booty
>> > front by dancehall and Southern rap. In response, some dance producers
>> > have started to draw upon raucously vibrant ''street'' beats: crunk,
>> > Miami bass, dancehall, grime and so forth.
>> >
>> > The result is a growing hybrid genre, highlighted on the recent,
>> > excellent compilation ''Shockout,'' known as ''breakcore.'' Purveyed
>> > by artists like DJ/Rupture and Teamshadetek, the music combines
>> > rumbling basslines, fidgety beats and grainy ragga vocals to create a
>> > home-listening surrogate for the ''bashment'' vibe of a Jamaican sound
>> > system party. Others within the breakcore genre, like Knifehandchop,
>> > Kid 606 and Soundmurderer, hark back to rave's own early days, their
>> > music evoking the rowdy fervor of a time when huge crowds flailed
>> > their limbs to a barrage of abstract noise and convulsive rhythm. It's
>> > a poignant aural mirage of a time when techno music was made for the
>> > popular vanguard rather than a connoisseurial elite, as it is today.
>> >

He is right on here.  As I have mentioned before many times...it 
has  become an obsession with me...good music and good times arise from the 
streets, not the technician's studio.  Hip hop and house, for  example, are 
coming together again I believe as dancers search for the cock-raising, 
booty shaking  beats lost when "fashion" replaced the sweat ;-)

Things are looking up IMHO.

Love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] SFRaves 13th Anniversary & SFR Calendar 10th Anniversary

Please note that SFRaves / Hyperreal.org are not for profit entities, this 
is a *FREE* resource that supports the local community. Our time is given 
voluntarily, Commercial-free, we love thee!

The SFRaves Calendar lives @ http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2

I send it out once per week, this year in November will be 7 years I've 
been administrating the calendar...

Next month, the calendar will be 10 years old :)
SFRaves will be 13 years old :)

It is quite a monumental year :) We are in the process of planning an 
event to celebrate the 13th year of SFRaves blessing this universe, and th 
10th year of the SFRaves calendar being a free resource. Keep posted for 
more information :)

I would love to get together in person, let me know when you are free, I 
am out and about and it would be an honour to be blessed with your 
presence :)

You can also Connect with SFRaves!

Connect with SFRaves Calendar! Free Event Publication, Promotions, Mailing 
List, Event Promotion Resources!

http://www.sfraves.org / http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf

1)
Connect with the SFRaves Calendar - FREE Promotions, Group & People 
Profiles, Event Self publication:

http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2

2)
Register to create an account @
http://hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/add_person_form

3)
If applicable, add a Group for your Collective, Production Crew, Label,
Event Promotion, et al:
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/groups/create_group_form

4)
Add/Publish and Event to the SFRaves Calendar:
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/add_event_form

SFRaves Extended Network Contacts:

SFRaves @ Livejournal.com - http://www.livejournal.com/~sfraves
SFRaves @ Tribe.net - http://sf-raves.tribe.net/
SFRaves @ Friendster.com - http://www.friendster.com/user.php?uid=73285
SFRaves Myspace Group - http://groups.myspace.com/sfraves
SFRaves @ Myspace -
http://www.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewProfile&friendID=1151756
SFRaves @ Orkut.com - http://www.orkut.com/Community.aspx?cmm=454199

Karina
karina@hyperreal.org :)

http://www.sfraves.org
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/

(Yucatec Maya)

happenings.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Review Thievery Corporation


<rant>

What is it about big name DJ's that figure they don't actually have to beat 
match or do anything other than play records.. they were straight up lame.. 
we left early.. they played mixes that breaks DJ's have been playing for 
over a year as part of their new tour.. unmixed.. it was so frikkin lame.. I 
was really dissapointed in quality.. on a positive note.. thier first few 
tracks were this conglomeration of 50's style beatnick and house rythems 
that were hella funky.. but then they would put on a another record and 
actually forget to mix it in.  That was once again super lame!! They thought 
they weree soo kewl.. and people were boooing them because they didn't know 
how to mix.. they got what they deserved.. stick to the studios.. it is 
obviously all they can do.

This is all after we waiting in line with everyone else who bought in 
advance for willcall with Blasthaus.com and was forced to wait outside in 
the rain for over an hour.  I urge you never to use this lame ass ticketing 
agengy for anyhting.. they treat you like shite.  Who sells tickets for TC 
and then checks you in one at a time with no conselation for how long they 
take.. they could have had so many people running that line.. but they had 
2.  Lame ass bitches,, they suck!!

</end rant>

Then we saw satsi spin three tracks at blue cube and it made my night.. 
desert breaks.. probably the best three tracks of the night cuz he went 
longer than he was supposed too.. even though the show was supposed to go to 
4.. they shut it down at 2.. wtf.. was everything screwed up last night.. I 
think people forget how to organize when they get wet.. as My friend Lisa 
says," I'm all wet.. and not in a good way!!"

Salut
Ranger

SFR: Ranger
Santa Cruz
plurranger@hotmail.com
Who knows where the night leads
It's dark and no one can see

Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY w/ Future Funk Squad - Saturday, Feb. 19th

BIG BIG THANKS to Brandon & Aaron for allowing me to spin last night...I had 
a good time, and was happy to see people spilling in as I left around 11pm 
or so. (working at 6am on Sundays blows ass by the way...ugh)

The beats were pretty tasty, the spot was nice and the sound was better than 
at the last DIRTY...all good things.

Looking forward to the Evil Breaks Anniversary party - it's gonna be sick!!!

Thanks again guys...it was much appreciated!!

~Marc(O)

References: <BAY103-F34FDCCD6CE4F5F1F9455A4D06B0@phx.gbl>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY w/ Future Funk Squad - Saturday, Feb. 19th


Good times!

So I was kinda thinking to myself how it's a breaks party.  And breaks 
people are kinda fun oriented.  And I'm kinda fun oriented, especially 
after a couple drinks.  And so is ghettotech.  And I'd seen a couple 
ghettotech DJs play lately who bust no tricks and rather than complain I 
thought it better to just go out and do some chicken right.  So I figured, 
this would be a fun ghettotech booking despite it saying that it's a 
techno room and all.

So I pack a crate of the foulest accelerated funk crap I own, and make it 
out to Dirty.

And the crossfader is just fucked.

So yeah, sorry to anybody who felt they got a less than typical Andy GT 
experience.  Not being able to cut and scratch does affect ghetto tech.  
All that said, somehow the energy in there was good and I managed to eek 
out some hotmixes and doubles crud with just the levels, so I'll chalk it 
up to 330 Ritch's excellent Long Island Iced Teas (had three of them 
*hick*, highly recommended!) and of course, the fact that people secretly 
love tracks like "Dick by the Pound" and "Tip'dat Bitch" no matter how 
they're dropped.

Didn't hear too much of the music otherwise except for settling in to 
Aaron & Brandon bumping it when we got there... good times, and as we left 
the whole breaks room was going apeshit.  Defintely would have stayed but 
the ride was leaving and alas, muni night owl service in the rain with a 
dislocated shoulder and a box of records is not my idea of fun.

andyw

(could I like, get a rain check for when you guys have a working 
crossfader Bam? ;) )

X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20050219160837.19435.qmail@web21521.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0502201019000.9860@atari>
References: <20050219160837.19435.qmail@web21521.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] help I've fallen down and I have an itch I can't
 scratch


Best bet is people selling collections if you like that Surgeon style 
sound (keep an eye open for Advent, Regis, Ben Long, Space Djs for more of 
that sorta sound).  Not too much coming out like that these days.  Best 
store would be Open Mind, they pack a reasonable domestic techno section, 
some imports, and an admirable backstock of used techno... both randomly 
throughout the store and also organized by label (they might even have 
label sections for Counterbalance and Downwards which put out the lion's 
share of Surgeon's best work).

It's actually funny that there has been a little bump in interest in 
techno lately.  It's a really broad genre, spanning everything from 
minimal borderline dance music to almost gabber hard stuff to tech house 
to advent style rippers to tech breaks to Joey Beltram rave classics to 
seriously experimental shit.  Even sub genres of techno like "detroit" 
span a range of sounds from Plastikman's deepest downtempo acid wobbling 
to Jeff Mill's superchaotic 2 beat asswhoopins.  Probably moreso than any 
other genre, you can load up on old records and carve out your own sound 
and not sound totally cheesy (unless you stock up on too much early Adam 
Beyer and MHS*).  Something to consider for any DJs that are starting out.

andyw

* MHS stands for Minimal Hard Shit, and it's that stuff that's just pretty 
hard, fast, sounds like it's just a drum machine and some distortion 
pedals and really does it for like 5% of any given dancefloor while boring 
the shit out of everybody else.  It's also what people are usually 
referring to when they say they hate techno which is a bummer cause techno 
really is this like bin where anything that doesn't fit anywhere else 
goes.  As in "oh, it's not 2-step or house or breaks or jungle so I'll 
just put it in here".

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
"Nothing real can defeat us.  Nothing unreal exists." - Buckaroo Banzai

> So I was kinda thinking to myself how it's a breaks party.

> people are kinda fun oriented.  And I'm kinda fun oriented,

> after a couple drinks.  And so is ghettotech.  And I'd seen a
> couple 
> ghettotech DJs play lately who bust no tricks and rather than
> complain I 
> thought it better to just go out and do some chicken right. 
> So I figured, 
> this would be a fun ghettotech booking despite it saying that
> it's a 
> techno room and all.
> 
> So I pack a crate of the foulest accelerated funk crap I own,
> and make it 
> out to Dirty.
> 
> And the crossfader is just fucked.
> 
> So yeah, sorry to anybody who felt they got a less than
> typical Andy GT 
> experience.  Not being able to cut and scratch does affect
> ghetto tech.

> managed to eek 
> out some hotmixes and doubles crud with just the levels, so
> I'll chalk it 
> up to 330 Ritch's excellent Long Island Iced Teas (had three
> of them 
> *hick*, highly recommended!) and of course, the fact that
> people secretly

farrell song makes me want to sell all of my downtempo records.

collins.  it's that lame.

seeing em if all they're gonna do is play records.
