> > this would be a fun ghettotech booking despite it saying that
> > it's a
> > techno room and all.
> >
> > So I pack a crate of the foulest accelerated funk crap I own,
> > and make it
> > out to Dirty.
> >
> > And the crossfader is just fucked.
> >

> > typical Andy GT

> > ghetto tech.

> > managed to eek
> > out some hotmixes and doubles crud with just the levels, so
> > I'll chalk it
> > up to 330 Ritch's excellent Long Island Iced Teas (had three
> > of them
> > *hick*, highly recommended!) and of course, the fact that
> > people secretly
> > love tracks like "Dick by the Pound" and "Tip'dat Bitch" no

of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Author Hunter S. Thompson Kills Himself 

--=====================_23549372==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Author Hunter S. Thompson Kills Himself


Monday February 21, 2005 4:31 AM

AP Photo NY123

ASPEN, Colo. (AP) - Hunter S. Thompson, the acerbic counterculture writer 
who popularized a new form of journalism in books like ``Fear and Loathing 
in Las Vegas,'' fatally shot himself Sunday night at his Aspen-area home, 
his son said. He was 67.

``Hunter prized his privacy and we ask that his friends and admirers 
respect that privacy as well as that of his family,'' Juan Thompson said in 
a statement released to the Aspen Daily News.

Pitkin County Sheriff Bob Braudis, a personal friend of Thompson, confirmed 
the death to the News. Sheriff's officials did not return calls to The 
Associated Press late Sunday.

and Funky techno tribe in the mid nineties..I hope some of you old 
schoolers like me can make it out...

Blue Lagoon Cocktail Lounge - 0.4 miles SE - 923 Pacific Ave, Santa Cruz, 
95060 - (831) 423-7117

TONIGHT @ 9pm - 1:30 AM

<3 Karina

From sfraves-return-119613-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Feb 21 05:31:48 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-119613-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 8300 invoked by uid 1103); 21 Feb 2005 05:31:47 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 8281 invoked from network); 21 Feb 2005 05:31:46 -0000
Date: Sun, 20 Feb 2005 21:31:41 -0800
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <20050221053141.GM617@hubble>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>,
	sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Reviews: DJ Hell, Alien Autopsy, Dirty, and another brief rant

DJ Hell was OK. Too bad the space sucks. I'm really sick of the Rx
Gallery... shitty location (a guy tried to extort money out of me when I
was parking my car because he said it needed to be "protected"), shitty
sound (apparently there are residences upstairs, so there's nothing they
can do about it), shitty bar (no liqour, and they ran out of all the
good beer by like midnight), and a genuinely weird crowd. I saw a lot of
people there I knew, but that didn't really help. The opening DJ sucked,
and once it got crowded the whole place just took on this weird meat
market techno snob vibe. Like Andy said, it wasn't quite bad enough to
make me want to leave, but it wasn't good enough to make me stay either.
Dreakfast at Sparky's was way more entertaining.

Alien Autopsy was a blast, but I have some issues. First of all, I don't
particularly like hard techno. At least, I don't like the "MHS" that
some of the DJs were playing that night. I was there primarily because I
knew that most of my friends would be, and I'm supposed to be a techno
geek so supposedly my attendance was mandatory. Anyway, my favorite set
by far was Michael's, and it's a shame he played so early in the night.
I'm just going to come right out and say that this 5150 guy was really
bad; totally uninspired track selection and piss-poor mixing. Sorry
dude, it just didn't do it for me. I didn't hear much of Yap's set
because I was chillin' outside, but I came back in for Surgeon and he
was pretty good. Nothing groundbreaking, but solid and funky enough for
me to dance to for a bit. I left shortly thereafter because Michael was
sticking his finger out of his fly and acting out a tip-to-tip with
Eric. The party would have kicked a lot more ass had it been downstairs.
The crowd at the OW has also been increasingly young and ghetto lately.
There were some *really* young kids at this party, and even I felt old
when I overheard a girl say, "this is, like, an *adult* rave". When I
got home I reeked of cigarettes even though I hadn't smoked one all
night; there really should have been a dedicated (tobacco) smoking area.

Dirty was a lot of fun. I arrived really early and was a little toasty
by the time the place got bumpin'. Marco played a nice opening set, and
Bam and Aaron played some pretty funky stuff. Thanks for laying off the
cheese, guys! :) M.O.D. was playing well when I left; bonus points for
playing that breaks remix of Dave Brennan's "Drink Deep", that was hot.
The techno room was hit or miss. First of all, opening that room with
hard techno was just silly. And it got progressively worse until Andy
came on and threw down that totally sick (and, apparently, unauthorized)
ghetto-tech set. Toward the end he even mixed in some old jungle and did
a half-tempo mix into hip-hop--classy! Forest played well for the half
hour or so that I heard. It would really have been nice to hear some
more tech-housey or electro stuff in that room though. Overall, the
party was a blast. The space is nice, the drinks were well-mixed, and
the crowd was fun.

I have a general complaint about both Alien Autopsy and Dirty, and
that's the lack of musical diversity. Even if I were into hard techno, I
would not have been impressed by Alien Autopsy's lineup because I seek
VARIETY in my partying experiences. And I imagine that if half of the
audience weren't drug-addled teens, it would've been a lot more poorly
attended. Pretty much everyone I knew was outside the entire time,
offering the kids water as they stumbled out of the bathroom. Evil
Breaks should be commended for pulling off a party with two very
different styles, but the programming in the "techno" room left
something to be desired. EB deserves some of the blame, but more
importantly, DJs should know not to play really really hard stuff so
early in the evening.

In general, I think techno DJs have a lot to learn about creating some
semblance of flow in their sets, and either finding records that
actually DO something, or learning how to mix really quickly (and
skillfully) so that people like me don't get bored after 32 bars of the
same fucking distorted drum machine loops. And would it *really* hurt to
throw an electro track in every once in a while, or even break things
down with some tech-house, perhaps something with an actual BASSLINE?
Seriously, people: there's too much good music out there for everyone to
be playing that crap exclusively.

It's not like my standards are impossibly high. I know there's a time
and a place for "MHS", I just don't understand why every fucking DJ
feels the need to constantly bang it out all the time. Do any of you
seriously listen to really minimal, hard, fast stuff all day long? If
so, you're a freak. I want to be taken on a journey, which means playing
tracks that I can differentiate and process relative to one another.
There's nothing memorable for me about a party where the same
ridiculously hard stuff is played for 6 hours straight. There's no way
to pinpoint a particular moment in time because everything sounds way
too similar. And there's no talent or artistry involved in just
beatmatching two really similar records over and over again. I could
probably say the same about any style of EDM (house in particular, at
least the way it's played at most of the parties I've been to in the
past 3 years), but it's closer to my heart with techno because that's
what I like to call most of the music that I like. It pisses me off to
no end that the word "techno" is constantly soiled by all this totally
uninspired, unimaginative, and downright misrepresentative bullshit.

FWIW, I had a great weekend. I'm actually in a really good mood right
now, but I feel the need to be brutally honest because I don't want to
see the recent upsurge in techno here ruined by bad DJs. Think I'm being
a snob? Well if all you play or enjoy is hard techno, I *am* holier than
thou. Stop being so selfish with your techno ego and play something that
people can get down to without having to be whacked out on drugs.  And
for the record, allow me to share two totally different--but equally
great--techno experiences with you, just so you know I'm not a
curmudgeon:

1) Tronic Treatment in Miami at the WMC last year. Phil Kieran, Mistress
Barbara, Smith & Selway, Marco Bailey and T-1000 on the main floor at
Privilege. Only slightly drunk and without the aid of any stimulants, I
danced my *ass* off to these guys (and girl) for nearly 6 hours. Forest
Green has pictures and a broken pair of glasses that I stomped on to
prove it. Hard techno, sure, but there was something funky about it that
took things to a whole new level. Most of them were also very skillful
DJs that made appropriate use of tricks to keep things interesting. And
somebody played Carl Craig's "The Climax" over something totally minimal
and booming, which just made my night.

2) John Tejada at the most recent OW NYE. I was fucked up, but I
abstained from geeking out on all the tracks and just let his set move
my ass. After the fact, what's really great is that I can remember
specific moments, like when he played Nathan Fake's "The Sky Was Pink",
and the breakdown of Roman Flugel's "Geht's Noch" timed perfectly with
the countdown. You'd either have to be seriously jaded or just
completely brainwashed by bad music not to appreciate how good his set
was that night.

Call me a snob, I can take it. Pretty much all of the other "techno"
events I've been to in the last couple of years have just been so
disappointing. I'm not jaded yet, I just want more experiences like
those few good ones. And more importantly, I want other people to have
those experiences too, because then I have an even *better* time.
Everyone wins when you increase production value rather than sacrificing
some aspect of your party to draw a particular demographic.

Promoters, I know you hate me. But try to think of me as representative
of a small slice of the raver demo: young, geeky guys who love
electronic music and want to go out a lot, but don't necessarily like
doing lots of drugs. Our tastes may be specific when it comes to certain
styles, but you can keep us interested by mixing things up and featuring
more than one or two styles of music. Grab our attention with a
talented, diverse lineup and we'll probably buy presales. Find a good
venue, encourage your DJs to do something crazy and unexpected, and
we'll probably stay all night. Keep things fresh from party to party and
you may very well make loyal partygoers out of us.

Toodles,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

From sfraves-return-119615-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Feb 21 05:43:49 2005

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Received: (qmail 12139 invoked from network); 21 Feb 2005 05:43:48 -0000
Message-ID: <421974FF.1040208@cannabass.com>

Subject: [sfraves] (BSP) Cannabass :: Wed 2/23

Wed 2/23
E$kr (Solution, Rhythm Method)
Phaedrus (Moksha Tribe)

Every Wednesday

OPEN DECKS from 8p-10p. Get out of your bedroom and come play on a 
professional sound system in an awesome booth. Bring your vinyl and/or 
CDs, and your headphones and come grab a 1/2 hour slot. This is open to 
ALL styles of music.

 From 10p-2a come hear weekly headliners, mostly Drum & Bass, but we mix 
in some UK Grime, 2-Step, Hip Hop and other juicy sounds. Featuring the 
Cannabass residents: Happy, Lewt, Spicious Taste and Zigmund Void.

The Bench and Bar is a huge club in downtown Oakland, with a LOUD sound 
system, large wooden dance floor, 3-mile long bar and a smoking patio. 
It's just 2 Blocks from the 19th St BART Station.

21+ / No Cover
$3 Margaritas

Bench and Bar
2111 Franklin St
Oakland, CA
510-444-2266

www.cannabass.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Reviews: DJ Hell, Alien Autopsy, Dirty, and another brief rant

I <3 Shawn...he my baby daddy.
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "shawn allen" <shawn@alterior.net>
To: "sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Sunday, February 20, 2005 9:31 PM
Subject: [sfraves] Reviews: DJ Hell, Alien Autopsy, Dirty, and another brief 
rant


> DJ Hell was OK. Too bad the space sucks. I'm really sick of the Rx
> Gallery... shitty location (a guy tried to extort money out of me when I
> was parking my car because he said it needed to be "protected"), shitty
> sound (apparently there are residences upstairs, so there's nothing they
> can do about it), shitty bar (no liqour, and they ran out of all the
> good beer by like midnight), and a genuinely weird crowd. I saw a lot of
> people there I knew, but that didn't really help. The opening DJ sucked,
> and once it got crowded the whole place just took on this weird meat
> market techno snob vibe. Like Andy said, it wasn't quite bad enough to
> make me want to leave, but it wasn't good enough to make me stay either.
> Dreakfast at Sparky's was way more entertaining.
>
> Alien Autopsy was a blast, but I have some issues. First of all, I don't
> particularly like hard techno. At least, I don't like the "MHS" that
> some of the DJs were playing that night. I was there primarily because I
> knew that most of my friends would be, and I'm supposed to be a techno
> geek so supposedly my attendance was mandatory. Anyway, my favorite set
> by far was Michael's, and it's a shame he played so early in the night.
> I'm just going to come right out and say that this 5150 guy was really
> bad; totally uninspired track selection and piss-poor mixing. Sorry
> dude, it just didn't do it for me. I didn't hear much of Yap's set
> because I was chillin' outside, but I came back in for Surgeon and he
> was pretty good. Nothing groundbreaking, but solid and funky enough for
> me to dance to for a bit. I left shortly thereafter because Michael was
> sticking his finger out of his fly and acting out a tip-to-tip with
> Eric. The party would have kicked a lot more ass had it been downstairs.
> The crowd at the OW has also been increasingly young and ghetto lately.
> There were some *really* young kids at this party, and even I felt old
> when I overheard a girl say, "this is, like, an *adult* rave". When I
> got home I reeked of cigarettes even though I hadn't smoked one all
> night; there really should have been a dedicated (tobacco) smoking area.
>
> Dirty was a lot of fun. I arrived really early and was a little toasty
> by the time the place got bumpin'. Marco played a nice opening set, and
> Bam and Aaron played some pretty funky stuff. Thanks for laying off the
> cheese, guys! :) M.O.D. was playing well when I left; bonus points for
> playing that breaks remix of Dave Brennan's "Drink Deep", that was hot.
> The techno room was hit or miss. First of all, opening that room with
> hard techno was just silly. And it got progressively worse until Andy
> came on and threw down that totally sick (and, apparently, unauthorized)
> ghetto-tech set. Toward the end he even mixed in some old jungle and did
> a half-tempo mix into hip-hop--classy! Forest played well for the half
> hour or so that I heard. It would really have been nice to hear some
> more tech-housey or electro stuff in that room though. Overall, the
> party was a blast. The space is nice, the drinks were well-mixed, and
> the crowd was fun.
>
> I have a general complaint about both Alien Autopsy and Dirty, and
> that's the lack of musical diversity. Even if I were into hard techno, I
> would not have been impressed by Alien Autopsy's lineup because I seek
> VARIETY in my partying experiences. And I imagine that if half of the
> audience weren't drug-addled teens, it would've been a lot more poorly
> attended. Pretty much everyone I knew was outside the entire time,
> offering the kids water as they stumbled out of the bathroom. Evil
> Breaks should be commended for pulling off a party with two very
> different styles, but the programming in the "techno" room left
> something to be desired. EB deserves some of the blame, but more
> importantly, DJs should know not to play really really hard stuff so
> early in the evening.
>
> In general, I think techno DJs have a lot to learn about creating some
> semblance of flow in their sets, and either finding records that
> actually DO something, or learning how to mix really quickly (and
> skillfully) so that people like me don't get bored after 32 bars of the
> same fucking distorted drum machine loops. And would it *really* hurt to
> throw an electro track in every once in a while, or even break things
> down with some tech-house, perhaps something with an actual BASSLINE?
> Seriously, people: there's too much good music out there for everyone to
> be playing that crap exclusively.
>
> It's not like my standards are impossibly high. I know there's a time
> and a place for "MHS", I just don't understand why every fucking DJ
> feels the need to constantly bang it out all the time. Do any of you
> seriously listen to really minimal, hard, fast stuff all day long? If
> so, you're a freak. I want to be taken on a journey, which means playing
> tracks that I can differentiate and process relative to one another.
> There's nothing memorable for me about a party where the same
> ridiculously hard stuff is played for 6 hours straight. There's no way
> to pinpoint a particular moment in time because everything sounds way
> too similar. And there's no talent or artistry involved in just
> beatmatching two really similar records over and over again. I could
> probably say the same about any style of EDM (house in particular, at
> least the way it's played at most of the parties I've been to in the
> past 3 years), but it's closer to my heart with techno because that's
> what I like to call most of the music that I like. It pisses me off to
> no end that the word "techno" is constantly soiled by all this totally
> uninspired, unimaginative, and downright misrepresentative bullshit.
>
> FWIW, I had a great weekend. I'm actually in a really good mood right
> now, but I feel the need to be brutally honest because I don't want to
> see the recent upsurge in techno here ruined by bad DJs. Think I'm being
> a snob? Well if all you play or enjoy is hard techno, I *am* holier than
> thou. Stop being so selfish with your techno ego and play something that
> people can get down to without having to be whacked out on drugs.  And
> for the record, allow me to share two totally different--but equally
> great--techno experiences with you, just so you know I'm not a
> curmudgeon:
>
> 1) Tronic Treatment in Miami at the WMC last year. Phil Kieran, Mistress
> Barbara, Smith & Selway, Marco Bailey and T-1000 on the main floor at
> Privilege. Only slightly drunk and without the aid of any stimulants, I
> danced my *ass* off to these guys (and girl) for nearly 6 hours. Forest
> Green has pictures and a broken pair of glasses that I stomped on to
> prove it. Hard techno, sure, but there was something funky about it that
> took things to a whole new level. Most of them were also very skillful
> DJs that made appropriate use of tricks to keep things interesting. And
> somebody played Carl Craig's "The Climax" over something totally minimal
> and booming, which just made my night.
>
> 2) John Tejada at the most recent OW NYE. I was fucked up, but I
> abstained from geeking out on all the tracks and just let his set move
> my ass. After the fact, what's really great is that I can remember
> specific moments, like when he played Nathan Fake's "The Sky Was Pink",
> and the breakdown of Roman Flugel's "Geht's Noch" timed perfectly with
> the countdown. You'd either have to be seriously jaded or just
> completely brainwashed by bad music not to appreciate how good his set
> was that night.
>
> Call me a snob, I can take it. Pretty much all of the other "techno"
> events I've been to in the last couple of years have just been so
> disappointing. I'm not jaded yet, I just want more experiences like
> those few good ones. And more importantly, I want other people to have
> those experiences too, because then I have an even *better* time.
> Everyone wins when you increase production value rather than sacrificing
> some aspect of your party to draw a particular demographic.
>
> Promoters, I know you hate me. But try to think of me as representative
> of a small slice of the raver demo: young, geeky guys who love
> electronic music and want to go out a lot, but don't necessarily like
> doing lots of drugs. Our tastes may be specific when it comes to certain
> styles, but you can keep us interested by mixing things up and featuring
> more than one or two styles of music. Grab our attention with a
> talented, diverse lineup and we'll probably buy presales. Find a good
> venue, encourage your DJs to do something crazy and unexpected, and
> we'll probably stay all night. Keep things fresh from party to party and
> you may very well make loyal partygoers out of us.
>
> Toodles,
> -- 
> shawn allen
>  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
>  phone://+1.415.577.3961
>  http://alterior.net
>  aim://shawnpallen
>
>

> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>

Subject: [sfraves] nrr Writer Hunter S. Thompson Commits Suicide




Writer Hunter S. Thompson Commits Suicide

1 hour, 34 minutes ago

By ROBERT WELLER, Associated Press Writer

ASPEN, Colo. - Hunter S. Thompson, the hard-living
writer who inserted himself into his accounts of
America's underbelly and popularized a first-person
form of journalism in books such as "Fear and Loathing
in Las Vegas," has committed suicide.

Photo
AP Photo

AP Photo Photo
AP Photo
Slideshow Slideshow: Author Hunter S. Thompson Kills
Himself

AP Video Thompson's Story Ends with Suicide
(AP Video)
 

Thompson was found dead Sunday in his Aspen-area home
of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, sheriff's
officials said. He was 67. Thompson's wife, Anita, had
gone out before the shooting and was not home at the
time. His son, Juan, found the body.

Thompson "took his life with a gunshot to the head,"
the wife and son said in a statement released to the
Aspen Daily News. The statement asked for privacy for
Thompson's family and, using the Latin term for Earth,
added, "He stomped terra."

Neither the family statement nor Pitkin County
sheriff's officials said whether Thompson left a note.
The sheriff and the county coroner did not immediately
return telephone messages Monday.

Besides the 1972 classic about Thompson's visit to Las
Vegas, he also wrote "Fear and Loathing: On the
Campaign Trail '72." The central character in those
wild, sprawling satires was "Dr. Thompson," a
snarling, drug- and alcohol-crazed observer and
participant.

Thompson is credited alongside Tom Wolfe and Gay
Talese with helping pioneer New Journalism  or, as he
dubbed his version, "gonzo journalism"  in which the
writer made himself an essential component of the
story.

Thompson, whose early writings mostly appeared in
Rolling Stone magazine, often portrayed himself as
wildly intoxicated as he reported on such figures as
Jimmy Carter, Richard Nixon and Bill Clinton (news -
web sites).

"Fiction is based on reality unless you're a
fairy-tale artist," Thompson told The Associated Press
in 2003. "You have to get your knowledge of life from
somewhere. You have to know the material you're
writing about before you alter it."

Thompson also wrote such collections as "Generation of
Swine" and "Songs of the Doomed." His first ever
novel, "The Rum Diary," written in 1959, was first
published in 1998.

Thompson was a counterculture icon at the height of
the Watergate era, and once said Nixon represented
"that dark, venal, and incurably violent side of the
American character."

Thompson also was the model for Garry Trudeau's
balding "Uncle Duke" in the comic strip "Doonesbury."
He was portrayed on screen by Bill Murray in "Where
The Buffalo Roam" and Johnny Depp (news) in a film
adaptation of "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas."

That book, perhaps Thompson's most famous, begins: "We
were somewhere around Barstow on the edge of the
desert when the drugs began to take hold."

Other books include "The Great Shark Hunt," "Hell's
Angels" and "The Proud Highway." His most recent
effort was "Hey Rube: Blood Sport, the Bush Doctrine,
and the Downward Spiral of Dumbness."

"He may have died relatively young but he made up for
it in quality if not quantity of years," Paul
Krassner, the veteran radical journalist and one of
Thompson's former editors, told The Associated Press
by phone from his Southern California home.

"It was hard to say sometimes whether he was being
provocative for its own sake or if he was just being
drunk and stoned and irresponsible," quipped Krassner,
founder of the leftist publication The Realist and
co-founder of the Youth International (YIPPIE) party.

"But every editor that I know, myself included, was
willing to accept a certain prima donna journalism in
the demands he would make to cover a particular
story," he said. "They were willing to risk all of his
irresponsible behavior in order to share his talent
with their readers."

The writer's compound in Woody Creek, not far from
Aspen, was almost as legendary as Thompson. He prized
peacocks and weapons; in 2000, he accidentally shot
and slightly wounded his assistant trying to chase a
bear off his property.

 

Born July 18, 1937, in Kentucky, Hunter Stocton
Thompson served two years in the Air Force, where he
was a newspaper sports editor. He later became a proud
member of the National Rifle Association and almost
was elected sheriff in Aspen in 1970 under the Freak
Power Party banner.

Thompson's heyday came in the 1970s, when his
larger-than-life persona was gobbled up by magazines.
His pieces were of legendary length and so was his
appetite for adventure and trouble; his purported
fights with Rolling Stone editor Jann Wenner were
rumored in many cases to hinge on expense accounts for
stories that didn't materialize.

It was the content that raised eyebrows and tempers.
His book on the 1972 presidential campaign involving,
among others, Edmund Muskie, Hubert Humphrey and Nixon
was famous for its scathing opinion.

Working for Muskie, Thompson wrote, "was something
like being locked in a rolling box car with a vicious
200-pound water rat." Nixon and his "Barbie doll"
family were "America's answer to the monstrous Mr.
Hyde. He speaks for the werewolf in us."

Humphrey? Of him, Thompson wrote: "There is no way to
grasp what a shallow, contemptible and hopelessly
dishonest old hack Hubert Humphrey is until you've
followed him around for a while."

The approach won him praise among the masses as well
as critical acclaim. Writing in The New York Times in
1973, Christopher Lehmann-Haupt worried Thompson might
someday "lapse into good taste."

"That would be a shame, for while he doesn't see
America as Grandma Moses depicted it, or the way they
painted it for us in civics class, he does in his own
mad way betray a profound democratic concern for the
polity," he wrote. "And in its own mad way, it's
damned refreshing."

___

Associated Press writer John Rogers in Los Angeles
contributed to this report.

Subject: [sfraves] nrr did Bush smoke pot?

this is fucking hilarious...especially because the
journalist's last name who taped him doing this is
coincidently "wead" heheh:)


Sun Feb 20, 7:02 PM ET

By Sue Pleming

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - President George W. Bush (news
- web sites) has indicated in interviews secretly
taped by a friend before he became president that he
used marijuana but would not admit it for fear of
setting a bad example for children.

Photo
Reuters Photo

 

Portions of the tapes, recorded from 1998 to 2000 by
author Doug Wead without Bush's knowledge, were aired
on ABC News on Sunday and published by The New York
Times. Their authenticity was verified by the media
outlets but has not been independently checked by
Reuters.

"I wouldn't answer the marijuana question. You know
why? Because I don't want some little kid doing what I
tried," Bush purportedly says on the tape.

He added: "But you got to understand, I want to be
president. I want to lead. I want to set -- Do you
want your little kid say, 'Hey, Daddy, President Bush
(news - web sites) tried marijuana, I think I will?'"

In the tape, Bush mocks former Vice President Al Gore
(news - web sites) -- who fought him for the
presidency in 2000 -- for admitting he smoked
marijuana.

White House officials did not dispute the tapes'
veracity and indicated the president was disappointed
by their release.

"These were casual conversations that then Gov. Bush
was having with someone he thought was a friend, and
that's what they are," White House spokesman Scott
McClellan told reporters traveling with Bush to Europe
aboard Air Force One.

NOT AWARE

McClellan said Bush, who was governor of Texas when
the tapes were made, was not aware he was being
recorded and the White House found out only when
contacted by the New York Times for comment.

"Look, I think that, one, the comments in the tapes
speak for themselves. And two, I think that what I
just said pretty much speaks for itself," McClellan
said when pressed about the details.

"Those were issues that were addressed ad nauseam four
years ago and they were conversations that took place
more than four years ago," he said, adding that Bush
had not been in contact with Wead for several years.

Wead, a former aide to Bush's father President George
H.W. Bush, released portions of the tapes to coincide
with the publication of his new book and told ABC he
made the tapes because he believed the president was
an historic figure.

"If I'd had a chance to tape record Gandhi or had
conversations with Churchill, I probably would have
recorded them too," he said.

He also insisted his goal was not to hurt the
president's credibility and said if this were the case
he would have released the tapes during the 2004
election campaign.

Asked about the tapes in an interview with CNN, the
president's father said he was not aware of them and
declined comment.

Sitting next to Bush was ex-President Bill Clinton
(news - web sites), who admitted to smoking marijuana
when he campaigned for the White House but said he
never inhaled the illegal drug.

The two former presidents are touring areas affected
by the December 26 Indian Ocean tsunami.

> 
> >From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
> >To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> >Subject: [sfraves] Reviews: DJ Hell, Alien Autopsy,
> Dirty, and another 
> >brief rant
> >Date: Sun, 20 Feb 2005 21:31:41 -0800
> >
> >DJ Hell was OK. Too bad the space sucks. I'm really
> sick of the Rx
> >Gallery... shitty location (a guy tried to extort
> money out of me when I
> >was parking my car because he said it needed to be
> "protected"), shitty
> >sound (apparently there are residences upstairs, so
> there's nothing they
> >can do about it), shitty bar (no liqour, and they
> ran out of all the
> >good beer by like midnight), and a genuinely weird
> crowd. I saw a lot of
> >people there I knew, but that didn't really help.
> The opening DJ sucked,
> >and once it got crowded the whole place just took
> on this weird meat
> >market techno snob vibe. Like Andy said, it wasn't
> quite bad enough to
> >make me want to leave, but it wasn't good enough to
> make me stay either.
> >Dreakfast at Sparky's was way more entertaining.
> >
> >Alien Autopsy was a blast, but I have some issues.
> First of all, I don't
> >particularly like hard techno. At least, I don't
> like the "MHS" that
> >some of the DJs were playing that night. I was
> there primarily because I
> >knew that most of my friends would be, and I'm
> supposed to be a techno
> >geek so supposedly my attendance was mandatory.
> Anyway, my favorite set
> >by far was Michael's, and it's a shame he played so
> early in the night.
> >I'm just going to come right out and say that this
> 5150 guy was really
> >bad; totally uninspired track selection and
> piss-poor mixing. Sorry
> >dude, it just didn't do it for me. I didn't hear
> much of Yap's set
> >because I was chillin' outside, but I came back in
> for Surgeon and he
> >was pretty good. Nothing groundbreaking, but solid
> and funky enough for
> >me to dance to for a bit. I left shortly thereafter
> because Michael was
> >sticking his finger out of his fly and acting out a
> tip-to-tip with
> >Eric. The party would have kicked a lot more ass
> had it been downstairs.
> >The crowd at the OW has also been increasingly
> young and ghetto lately.
> >There were some *really* young kids at this party,
> and even I felt old
> >when I overheard a girl say, "this is, like, an
> *adult* rave". When I
> >got home I reeked of cigarettes even though I
> hadn't smoked one all
> >night; there really should have been a dedicated
> (tobacco) smoking area.
> >
> >Dirty was a lot of fun. I arrived really early and
> was a little toasty
> >by the time the place got bumpin'. Marco played a
> nice opening set, and
> >Bam and Aaron played some pretty funky stuff.
> Thanks for laying off the
> >cheese, guys! :) M.O.D. was playing well when I
> left; bonus points for
> >playing that breaks remix of Dave Brennan's "Drink
> Deep", that was hot.
> >The techno room was hit or miss. First of all,
> opening that room with
> >hard techno was just silly. And it got
> progressively worse until Andy
> >came on and threw down that totally sick (and,
> apparently, unauthorized)
> >ghetto-tech set. Toward the end he even mixed in
> some old jungle and did
> >a half-tempo mix into hip-hop--classy! Forest
> played well for the half
> >hour or so that I heard. It would really have been
> nice to hear some
> >more tech-housey or electro stuff in that room
> though. Overall, the
> >party was a blast. The space is nice, the drinks
> were well-mixed, and
> >the crowd was fun.
> >
> >I have a general complaint about both Alien Autopsy
> and Dirty, and
> >that's the lack of musical diversity. Even if I
> were into hard techno, I
> >would not have been impressed by Alien Autopsy's
> lineup because I seek
> >VARIETY in my partying experiences. And I imagine
> that if half of the
> >audience weren't drug-addled teens, it would've
> been a lot more poorly
> >attended. Pretty much everyone I knew was outside
> the entire time,
> >offering the kids water as they stumbled out of the
> bathroom. Evil
> >Breaks should be commended for pulling off a party
> with two very
> >different styles, but the programming in the
> "techno" room left
> >something to be desired. EB deserves some of the
> blame, but more
> >importantly, DJs should know not to play really
> really hard stuff so
> >early in the evening.
> >
> >In general, I think techno DJs have a lot to learn
> about creating some
> >semblance of flow in their sets, and either finding
> records that
> >actually DO something, or learning how to mix
> really quickly (and
> >skillfully) so that people like me don't get bored
> after 32 bars of the
> >same fucking distorted drum machine loops. And
> would it *really* hurt to
> >throw an electro track in every once in a while, or
> even break things
> >down with some tech-house, perhaps something with
> an actual BASSLINE?
> >Seriously, people: there's too much good music out
> there for everyone to
> >be playing that crap exclusively.
> >
> >It's not like my standards are impossibly high. I
> know there's a time
> >and a place for "MHS", I just don't understand why
> every fucking DJ
> >feels the need to constantly bang it out all the
> time. Do any of you
> >seriously listen to really minimal, hard, fast
> stuff all day long? If
> >so, you're a freak. I want to be taken on a
> journey, which means playing
> >tracks that I can differentiate and process
> relative to one another.
> >There's nothing memorable for me about a party
> where the same
> >ridiculously hard stuff is played for 6 hours
> straight. There's no way
> >to pinpoint a particular moment in time because
> everything sounds way
> >too similar. And there's no talent or artistry
> involved in just
> >beatmatching two really similar records over and
> over again. I could
> >probably say the same about any style of EDM (house
> in particular, at
> >least the way it's played at most of the parties
> I've been to in the
> >past 3 years), but it's closer to my heart with
> techno because that's
> >what I like to call most of the music that I like.
> It pisses me off to
> >no end that the word "techno" is constantly soiled
> by all this totally
> >uninspired, unimaginative, and downright
> misrepresentative bullshit.
> >
> >FWIW, I had a great weekend. I'm actually in a
> really good mood right
> >now, but I feel the need to be brutally honest
> because I don't want to
> >see the recent upsurge in techno here ruined by bad
> DJs. Think I'm being
> >a snob? Well if all you play or enjoy is hard
> techno, I *am* holier than
> >thou. Stop being so selfish with your techno ego
> and play something that
> >people can get down to without having to be whacked
> out on drugs.  And
> >for the record, allow me to share two totally
> different--but equally
> >great--techno experiences with you, just so you
> know I'm not a
> >curmudgeon:
> >
> >1) Tronic Treatment in Miami at the WMC last year.
> Phil Kieran, Mistress
> >Barbara, Smith & Selway, Marco Bailey and T-1000 on
> the main floor at
> >Privilege. Only slightly drunk and without the aid
> of any stimulants, I
> >danced my *ass* off to these guys (and girl) for
> nearly 6 hours. Forest
> >Green has pictures and a broken pair of glasses
> that I stomped on to
> >prove it. Hard techno, sure, but there was
> something funky about it that
> >took things to a whole new level. Most of them were
> also very skillful
> >DJs that made appropriate use of tricks to keep
> things interesting. And
> >somebody played Carl Craig's "The Climax" over
> something totally minimal
> >and booming, which just made my night.
> >
> >2) John Tejada at the most recent OW NYE. I was
> fucked up, but I
> >abstained from geeking out on all the tracks and
> just let his set move
> >my ass. After the fact, what's really great is that
> I can remember
> >specific moments, like when he played Nathan Fake's
> "The Sky Was Pink",
> >and the breakdown of Roman Flugel's "Geht's Noch"
> timed perfectly with
> >the countdown. You'd either have to be seriously
> jaded or just
> >completely brainwashed by bad music not to
> appreciate how good his set
> >was that night.
> >
> >Call me a snob, I can take it. Pretty much all of
> the other "techno"
> >events I've been to in the last couple of years
> have just been so
> >disappointing. I'm not jaded yet, I just want more
> experiences like
> >those few good ones. And more importantly, I want
> other people to have
> >those experiences too, because then I have an even
> *better* time.
> >Everyone wins when you increase production value
> rather than sacrificing
> >some aspect of your party to draw a particular
> demographic.
> >
> >Promoters, I know you hate me. But try to think of
> me as representative
> >of a small slice of the raver demo: young, geeky
> guys who love
> >electronic music and want to go out a lot, but
> don't necessarily like
> >doing lots of drugs. Our tastes may be specific
> when it comes to certain
> >styles, but you can keep us interested by mixing
> things up and featuring
> >more than one or two styles of music. Grab our
> attention with a
> >talented, diverse lineup and we'll probably buy
> presales. Find a good
> >venue, encourage your DJs to do something crazy and
> unexpected, and
> >we'll probably stay all night. Keep things fresh
> from party to party and
> >you may very well make loyal partygoers out of us.
> >
> >Toodles,
> >--
> >shawn allen
> >   mailto://shawn@alterior.net
> >   phone://+1.415.577.3961
> >   http://alterior.net
> >   aim://shawnpallen
> >

Subject: [sfraves] WR: Thursday Night... The Last Tech Support

So like I was talkin' 2 Supha on the computer like all day  & he like
totally persuaded me to go 2 Il Pirata 4 1 last serving of Tech Support..
it was fun!!  Oh my Go... OK.. so wait..

B4 that.. i was suppose 2 go 2 a meeting @ this club... never happned & I
was standing outside the club.. LoL.. it was fun though... LoL..

So I went 2 Butter.. Big J told me there was a private party there.. so i
left & I went 2 DNA.. spoke 2 like 2 of the bouncers there (the long blond
hair & the 1 I bought a burger 4) & got earplugs there 'cause I 4got them
@ home....

OK.. got 2 Il Pirata like a lil' early.. well.. I got 2 read my book..
Dope!!  But man.. as soon as things got crackin' oooh man.. So dope!!  It
was a perfect night!  OK.. the vibe was Groovy.. there were alota people
there who were just totally feelin' the Groove & familiar faces.. ok.. but
this is what's weird though.. like despite the like Groovy vibes that
night from every1... when i grabbed floor that night & Grooved.. I felt
all these other strange vibes on the floor that I had 2 just like keep
dancing through 2 get some solid time Groovin... but yeah.. that was
weird...

I LOVED all the tag sets that night... but the Sleeveless tag set w/ Femme
Fatal & Eva was Sick!!  I mean... I've been a big fan of those 2 Jungle
Chicas 4 as long as I can remember & they dropped alota good nice hard
tunes as well as some dubby stuff.. YUM!!!

Wow.. it was fun.. after went 2 an afterparty & played xbox & HELLO 2DAY,
went skiing in the snow.. Hella fun!

Yeah man.. Dope!  I mean.. it's nice that well.. it all was just way 2 fun
after spending the day not thinkin' of anything that I'd be doin' that
night!!

Oh yeah.. 1 of the biggest highlights of that night were all the MCs that
were spitting on the mic!!  I mean.. the only 3 that I knew were Colonel,
Soljah, & Child.. oh my goodness... I finally saw Child after like 3
years, that fool is tryin' 2 come back out again after he well.. had to
live life & stuff... so yeah.. that was Awesome hangin' out w/ him again..
LoL... YAY!!!  Love Child.. Mondo highlight 4 me 'cause we had
soooooooooooo much 2 talk about & catch up on!!!  Dope!! Oh oh oh... if U
wann C how he looks.. this is him...
http://www.twinphish.net/images/element_nasty/06_mc_child.jpg

So yeah... it was a Dope night!!  LoL

> this is fucking hilarious...especially because the

>=20
> Sun Feb 20, 7:02 PM ET
>=20
> By Sue Pleming
>=20
> WASHINGTON (Reuters) - President George W. Bush (news
> - web sites) has indicated in interviews secretly
> taped by a friend before he became president that he
> used marijuana but would not admit it for fear of
> setting a bad example for children.
>=20
> Photo
> Reuters Photo
>=20
> Portions of the tapes, recorded from 1998 to 2000 by
> author Doug Wead without Bush's knowledge, were aired
> on ABC News on Sunday and published by The New York
> Times. Their authenticity was verified by the media
> outlets but has not been independently checked by
> Reuters.
>=20
> "I wouldn't answer the marijuana question. You know
> why? Because I don't want some little kid doing what I
> tried," Bush purportedly says on the tape.
>=20
> He added: "But you got to understand, I want to be
> president. I want to lead. I want to set -- Do you
> want your little kid say, 'Hey, Daddy, President Bush
> (news - web sites) tried marijuana, I think I will?'"
>=20
> In the tape, Bush mocks former Vice President Al Gore
> (news - web sites) -- who fought him for the
> presidency in 2000 -- for admitting he smoked
> marijuana.
>=20
> White House officials did not dispute the tapes'
> veracity and indicated the president was disappointed
> by their release.
>=20
> "These were casual conversations that then Gov. Bush
> was having with someone he thought was a friend, and
> that's what they are," White House spokesman Scott
> McClellan told reporters traveling with Bush to Europe
> aboard Air Force One.
>=20
> NOT AWARE
>=20
> McClellan said Bush, who was governor of Texas when
> the tapes were made, was not aware he was being
> recorded and the White House found out only when
> contacted by the New York Times for comment.
>=20
> "Look, I think that, one, the comments in the tapes
> speak for themselves. And two, I think that what I
> just said pretty much speaks for itself," McClellan
> said when pressed about the details.
>=20
> "Those were issues that were addressed ad nauseam four
> years ago and they were conversations that took place
> more than four years ago," he said, adding that Bush
> had not been in contact with Wead for several years.
>=20
> Wead, a former aide to Bush's father President George
> H.W. Bush, released portions of the tapes to coincide
> with the publication of his new book and told ABC he
> made the tapes because he believed the president was
> an historic figure.
>=20
> "If I'd had a chance to tape record Gandhi or had
> conversations with Churchill, I probably would have
> recorded them too," he said.
>=20
> He also insisted his goal was not to hurt the
> president's credibility and said if this were the case
> he would have released the tapes during the 2004
> election campaign.
>=20
> Asked about the tapes in an interview with CNN, the
> president's father said he was not aware of them and
> declined comment.
>=20
> Sitting next to Bush was ex-President Bill Clinton
> (news - web sites), who admitted to smoking marijuana
> when he campaigned for the White House but said he
> never inhaled the illegal drug.
>=20
> The two former presidents are touring areas affected
> by the December 26 Indian Ocean tsunami.

my gosh man.. 3 years???  but yeah man.. that was fuckin' sick.. he hella
clowned me when I tried bein' Mr Bam.. LoL.. it was funnny!!  But yeah
man.. it was Dope hangin' out w/ family the whole night!!@  Loved it!!!!

the ride home!

Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 15:19:39 -0800 (PST)
From: Chel-C Faith <chelcfaith@defsf.com>
X-Sender:  <chelcfaith@dragon.greengraphics.net>
To: <shawn@alterior.net>, SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.30.0502211454440.6697-100000@dragon.greengraphics.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Reviews: DJ Hell, Alien Autopsy, Dirty, and another
 brief rant

I do agree with you on the lack of diversity in the techno scene right
now, and I've thought about this a lot....

I hate to say it, but I think the hard hard hard ass stuff is what techno
kids want at present.  I've found that with our DEF events, people have
been happiest when we've given them straight-up hard techno.  The times
we've tried to branch out an explore different sides of techno were not
exactly our most successful events.  When we threw Robot Feelings, a
techno and electro party at Cellspace last year, the Droid Behavior guys
who came up for the party complained that we weren't "techno enough".  I
want to do parties the way I like them, but I want to make the people who
attend happy too.  This may be an impossibility, as we're not quite
"techno enough" for techno kids I guess.

Alien Autopsy satisfied all the usual techno party requirements.  Dark;
check. Hard; check. Spooky and evil; check. Anoraks; well, I didn't see
any, but I'm sure there must have been an anorak or two being worn there
somewhere.  And I did notice a few bald guys.  Maybe techno ravers don't
want their party formula to be messed with.  It seems to me that this is
how they like it.  There was no question of this party not being "techno
enough".  It had all the bases covered, and people loved it.

There are so many different facets of the SF techno scene, lots of little
micro-scenes. I would love to see the scene become more united, but the
problem with techno snobs is that they get so into their thing that they
have a hard time looking beyond their own subgenre oriented microscene.

Maybe this is a bad analogy, but I see it like this--  The Democratic
party has become increasingly weak because of all the squabbling and
divisions within the party, whereas the Republican party is much more
united and unfortunately has become a lot stronger than the Democrats
because of their unity and passion.  Despite the lack of quality in the
trance scene, the enthusiasm and unity found in the candy kid world has
kept the trance scene alive and strong long after we've all declared it
dead several times. SF's techno scene, like the Democrats, will never be
strong if we continue to be divided along sub-genre lines.  Furthermore,
your average techno fan now, after seeing their music be ignored by most
rave promoters and regularly get confused with trance, has become jaded
and apathetic.  If we are divided, jaded, and apathetic, techno will be
going nowhere fast!

I want to see anorak-wearing minimal guys dancing to funky techno! I want
nosebleed schranz DJs to start buying electro records!  I want to see
people support the techno scene with enthusiasm and passion! And I have no
problem with hearing janky piano riffs in techno tracks!

Perhaps you have been slightly dissapointed with recent techno events, but
things are changing.  This is going to be our year.  ;)


Love Chelsea


P.S.  I think you would have enjoyed Terrac and Disconnect's sets on
Friday night, though they were on pretty late so most people missed them.
(except for the contents of that e-puddle in the corner....).  I had never
heard Terrac play before, he was really great.  Good track selection, good
mixing, and I'm always happy when someone plays Chris Jackson's "Check Our
Beats"!   Sean played some cool stuff too, hypnotic, groovy, and melodic.
A couple new Adam Beyer tracks, some Kanzleramt stuff, and somehow he fit
Messiah's "Temple of Dreams" in there too.  Nice!


-- 
       [[[defsf.com]]]
a west coast techno alliance
       [415.289.6886]

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary - March 19th

Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary
Saturday, March 19th
9:00pm - 4:00am
330 Ritch Street, SF
$10, $15 and $20

Evil Breaks invites you to join us in celebrating our one year anniversary.  
For this very special night, we present:

GENERAL MIDI
(TCR / Kilowatt / Distinctive / UK)

ROXILLER
Chris Carter and JHz - Live PA
(TCR / Record Records / Sober / UK)

Special Guest:
COREY EDWIN
(IAG / Bless Records / Miami)

And the entire Evil Breaks crew:
AARON JAE
ATHENA
BAM
INFLUENCE
M.O.D.
NICK NYQUIL

Lasers by Stimulights.
Culinary art by Chef Jauncy.

Presales available in March @ Groovetickets.com, Skills, Reverb and EB crew 
members.

More info soon @ www.evilbreaks.com

Thank you to everyone for your continued support.  We love you!

--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

March 4th:  ModILLfied @ Shadow Lounge
March 5th:  Clandestine in SF
March 11th:  Urbanology
March 19th:  Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary Party
April 14th:  Turntablaze Radio on 102.5FM
April 29th:  Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty

From sfraves-return-119631-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Feb 21 23:35:54 2005

Received: (qmail 25857 invoked by uid 1103); 21 Feb 2005 23:35:53 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 25839 invoked from network); 21 Feb 2005 23:35:53 -0000
Message-ID: <20050221233549.28516.qmail@web81302.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 15:35:49 -0800 (PST)
From: Chris Jackson <cjax@sbcglobal.net>
To: Chel-C Faith <chelcfaith@defsf.com>, shawn@alterior.net,
  SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.30.0502211454440.6697-100000@dragon.greengraphics.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Reviews: DJ Hell, Alien Autopsy, Dirty, and another brief rant

ok.  here's my take:


what ever happened to playing a lil minimal glitchy
funk, hard shit, electro, tracky swingy stuff, breaks
and beat-less stuff all in ONE SET???  why the pigeon
holing?

shit.  every time i play i try and be super
diverse...cover a lot of different techno and its
derivatives.  i can't remember the last time i played
straight up techno!  actually, i can't remember the
last time i played!  hahaa.  the problem i see, and
i've been around for a loooooong time, is that these
'newish' techno dj's have NO BALLS!  they're scared of
their own shadows and aren't willing to take any
chances!  and like shawn was saying, who the hell
wants to hear a distorted tech loop for 6 minutes
[besides me]?  quick mixing is the key, and there
aren't a lot of techno dj's that i've seen in SF that
can do it effectively.  perhaps they're barking up the
wrong tree?  maybe they should be playing 'songs'
instead of 'tracks'.  you can't 'pretend' to be a
techno dj like these fucking trance dj's can.  they
can 'wing' their way through a set because they take
no chances and play 'songs' that do everything for
them.  lame.

my answer = fucking practice and show off your skills.
 either that or stop playing techno and pick up some
house or trance records or something..

my 4 cents...thats right...inflation bitches!

c h r i s




--- Chel-C Faith <chelcfaith@defsf.com> wrote:

> I do agree with you on the lack of diversity in the
> techno scene right
> now, and I've thought about this a lot....
> 
> I hate to say it, but I think the hard hard hard ass
> stuff is what techno
> kids want at present.  I've found that with our DEF
> events, people have
> been happiest when we've given them straight-up hard
> techno.  The times
> we've tried to branch out an explore different sides
> of techno were not
> exactly our most successful events.  When we threw
> Robot Feelings, a
> techno and electro party at Cellspace last year, the
> Droid Behavior guys
> who came up for the party complained that we weren't
> "techno enough".  I
> want to do parties the way I like them, but I want
> to make the people who
> attend happy too.  This may be an impossibility, as
> we're not quite
> "techno enough" for techno kids I guess.
> 
> Alien Autopsy satisfied all the usual techno party
> requirements.  Dark;
> check. Hard; check. Spooky and evil; check. Anoraks;
> well, I didn't see
> any, but I'm sure there must have been an anorak or
> two being worn there
> somewhere.  And I did notice a few bald guys.  Maybe
> techno ravers don't
> want their party formula to be messed with.  It
> seems to me that this is
> how they like it.  There was no question of this
> party not being "techno
> enough".  It had all the bases covered, and people
> loved it.
> 
> There are so many different facets of the SF techno
> scene, lots of little
> micro-scenes. I would love to see the scene become
> more united, but the
> problem with techno snobs is that they get so into
> their thing that they
> have a hard time looking beyond their own subgenre
> oriented microscene.
> 
> Maybe this is a bad analogy, but I see it like
> this--  The Democratic
> party has become increasingly weak because of all
> the squabbling and
> divisions within the party, whereas the Republican
> party is much more
> united and unfortunately has become a lot stronger
> than the Democrats
> because of their unity and passion.  Despite the
> lack of quality in the
> trance scene, the enthusiasm and unity found in the
> candy kid world has
> kept the trance scene alive and strong long after
> we've all declared it
> dead several times. SF's techno scene, like the
> Democrats, will never be
> strong if we continue to be divided along sub-genre
> lines.  Furthermore,
> your average techno fan now, after seeing their
> music be ignored by most
> rave promoters and regularly get confused with
> trance, has become jaded
> and apathetic.  If we are divided, jaded, and
> apathetic, techno will be
> going nowhere fast!
> 
> I want to see anorak-wearing minimal guys dancing to
> funky techno! I want
> nosebleed schranz DJs to start buying electro
> records!  I want to see
> people support the techno scene with enthusiasm and
> passion! And I have no
> problem with hearing janky piano riffs in techno
> tracks!
> 
> Perhaps you have been slightly dissapointed with
> recent techno events, but
> things are changing.  This is going to be our year. 
> ;)
> 
> 
> Love Chelsea
> 
> 
> P.S.  I think you would have enjoyed Terrac and
> Disconnect's sets on
> Friday night, though they were on pretty late so
> most people missed them.
> (except for the contents of that e-puddle in the
> corner....).  I had never
> heard Terrac play before, he was really great.  Good
> track selection, good
> mixing, and I'm always happy when someone plays
> Chris Jackson's "Check Our
> Beats"!   Sean played some cool stuff too, hypnotic,
> groovy, and melodic.
> A couple new Adam Beyer tracks, some Kanzleramt
> stuff, and somehow he fit
> Messiah's "Temple of Dreams" in there too.  Nice!
> 
> 
> -- 
>        [[[defsf.com]]]
> a west coast techno alliance
>        [415.289.6886]
> 
> 
>

> sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

>> >want their party formula to be messed with.  It seems to me that this is
>> >how they like it.  There was no question of this party not being "techno
>> >enough".  It had all the bases covered, and people loved it.
>> >
>> >There are so many different facets of the SF techno scene, lots of 
>> >little
>> >micro-scenes. I would love to see the scene become more united, but the
>> >problem with techno snobs is that they get so into their thing that they
>> >have a hard time looking beyond their own subgenre oriented microscene.
>> >
>> >Maybe this is a bad analogy, but I see it like this--  The Democratic
>> >party has become increasingly weak because of all the squabbling and
>> >divisions within the party, whereas the Republican party is much more
>> >united and unfortunately has become a lot stronger than the Democrats
>> >because of their unity and passion.  Despite the lack of quality in the
>> >trance scene, the enthusiasm and unity found in the candy kid world has
>> >kept the trance scene alive and strong long after we've all declared it
>> >dead several times. SF's techno scene, like the Democrats, will never be
>> >strong if we continue to be divided along sub-genre lines.  Furthermore,
>> >your average techno fan now, after seeing their music be ignored by most
>> >rave promoters and regularly get confused with trance, has become jaded
>> >and apathetic.  If we are divided, jaded, and apathetic, techno will be
>> >going nowhere fast!
>> >
>> >I want to see anorak-wearing minimal guys dancing to funky techno! I 
>> >want
>> >nosebleed schranz DJs to start buying electro records!  I want to see
>> >people support the techno scene with enthusiasm and passion! And I have 
>> >no
>> >problem with hearing janky piano riffs in techno tracks!
>> >
>> >Perhaps you have been slightly dissapointed with recent techno events, 
>> >but
>> >things are changing.  This is going to be our year.  ;)
>> >
>> >
>> >Love Chelsea
>> >
>> >
>> >P.S.  I think you would have enjoyed Terrac and Disconnect's sets on
>> >Friday night, though they were on pretty late so most people missed 
>> >them.
>> >(except for the contents of that e-puddle in the corner....).  I had 
>> >never
>> >heard Terrac play before, he was really great.  Good track selection, 
>> >good
>> >mixing, and I'm always happy when someone plays Chris Jackson's "Check 
>> >Our
>> >Beats"!   Sean played some cool stuff too, hypnotic, groovy, and 
>> >melodic.
>> >A couple new Adam Beyer tracks, some Kanzleramt stuff, and somehow he 
>> >fit
>> >Messiah's "Temple of Dreams" in there too.  Nice!

Those of you who have been around for awhile remember Mark Ameba.

I recently ran into him again on Tribenet as he begins to expand his 
network, or as Mark puts it:  "so now since tribe looks like craigslist 
meets friendster...maybe I'll visit more...in the meantime shoot me a 
message and join my net..... "

Mark has a "tribe" and is throwing a party called "Naked Funk."  Old 
friends might want to connect again :-)


NAKED FUNK

Phatty Beat Lovin, Bass Bin Thumpin, Keep it Pumpin!!!
We bring the BASS, Hook up the SPACE, Get you off your FACE......
(but it's really all about you...)
YOU MAKE THE PARTY !!!!

Phatty Beat Lovin, Bass Bin Thumpin, Keep it Pumpin!!!

Public URL: <http://nakedfunk.tribe.net>nakedfunk.tribe.net

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"Sometime in your life, hope that you might see one starved man, the look 
on his face when the bread finally arrives.  Hope that you might have 
bought it or baked it or even kneaded it yourself.  For that look on his 
face, for your meeting his eyes across a piece of bread, you might be 
willing to lose a lot, or suffer a lot, or die a little, even."
-Daniel Berrigan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Reviews: DJ Hell, Alien Autopsy, Dirty, and another
 brief rant

I think it's not just the techno DJs that have no balls, but the listeners
too.  I often see people leave the dancefloor in droves when a DJ pulls
out a different style. No wonder newer techno DJs are afraid to be
adventurous!  We all say that we want variety, but when it's given to us
we won't accept it.  This obsessive subgenre loyalty could be the downfall
of the techno scene, in my opinion.

I would love to see both techno DJs and techno ravers open up to more
styles.... But alas, I can't force people to like music they don't like.

It seems there has been a little surge of interest in techno lately.  If
we all drop the cliquey "I only like my kind of techno" thing and come
together for once, new people might actually take interest and help our
scene to grow.  If there is a renewed interest in techno and new blood
coming into the scene, more and hopefully better parties will pop up, good
techno DJs will be getting more gigs, and we will all be complaining less.
Wait.... no.. this is SFR I'm talking about here... we live for
complaining.

Variety in techno, unity under techno, a greater sense of community, and a
welcoming attitude towards newcomers.... That's what I'd like to see
happen this year.  Maybe I'm idealistic.

Love Chelsea

Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 16:28:00 -0800
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <20050222002800.GQ617@hubble>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>,
	SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.30.0502211454440.6697-100000@dragon.greengraphics.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.30.0502211454440.6697-100000@dragon.greengraphics.net>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] another brief rant

quoth Chel-C Faith:
> I do agree with you on the lack of diversity in the techno scene right
> now, and I've thought about this a lot....

We both have. And I don't know what the next step is because I still
haven't been able to figure out what the fuck people *want* from me, or
the "scene", or techno in general. I'm not entirely sure that the kids
want just really hard techno. The cynic in me assumes that most of those
kids on Friday night were totally fucked up on drugs, and I'm just not
interested in music that only sounds good when I'm high. But the techno
parties at (mostly lame) clubs in SF haven't really been doing it for me
either. I don't dance at raves because the music doesn't make me, and I
can't dance at the Rx because they don't have a fucking license and the
sound sucks to begin with. I honestly think people would get down to the
stuff I hear at little techno events if it were played in a grungy old
warehouse on a big underground soundsystem.

I know, I'm not the typical raver. I don't go to parties to get high; I
go to hear good music in good company. I'm not a typical techno geek
either: I started out DJ'ing DnB and house, so I appreciate the aspects
of "funk" and "jack" that make some electronic music particularly
danceable. The really hard techno lacks sufficient qualities of both,
and as I've said time and time again I think the popularity of that
style has soiled the word "techno" for the rest of us. There's so much
more to it than over-compressed grinding machine sound loops. Maybe I'm
just not "hardcore" enough to give people the impression that I like
"techno"?

I've seen this all happen with industrial/EBM already, as musicality was
slowly edged out by, well, edginess for its own sake. I look back on
when I was a teenager first discovering IDM, and it saddens me because I
fear that the kids going to today's parties won't be exposed to anything
even remotely "progressive" or "interesting". I'm not saying we should
be pushing Aphex Twin on the kids (although I am looking forward to
playing some of the new Analord records on a big 'ol soundsystem), but I
think we owe it to them to give them some variety, some choice.

Exposure under the right circumstances is what made me fall in love with
so much of the music I listen to today, and maybe that's why hard techno
is so popular right now: kids go to a party because their friends are
going to be there, they get high, and they associate that barrage of
distorted kick drums with a good time. I just wish we could supplement
the really hard stuff with something more interesting or imaginative. If
the kids don't demand any variety though, nothing's going to change.

So, fellow partygoers: DEMAND VARIETY. BOYCOTT MONO-STYLISTIC PARTIES.
EXPAND YOUR HORIZONS WITH MUSIC YOU'VE NEVER HEARD BEFORE.

That is all,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Reviews: DJ Hell, Alien Autopsy, Dirty, and another brief rant

I wish people would stop being so fucking serious about dance music...like, 
for real.

It's made for ... *GASP*  - dancing!!! Not preening and being an elitist 
label whore or genre specific tight-ass.

I for one am actually shocked that the techno & breaks heads got together on 
a party judging by how little most techno-heads tend to like breaks (and 
their apparently more "commercial" sound).  And all this jibber-jabber about 
people taking "chances" and playing different styles in a set...wtf???? I 
have been doing that from day one and really don't see it as a huge leap. I 
mean, if it's all in the same frickin' BPM range or mixable in 1/2 time, how 
hard is it to mix, and how much of a "chance" are you taking (unless you 
have a struck up crowd that only wants one sound all night long)? 99% of EDM 
that has come out since the mid 90's practically mixes itself!!!

I think people just need to pull the poles out of their dances and start 
having fun. Either tha or they need to STFU and get off the damn dancefloors 
so people who wanna get down and have fun can do so unobstructed by the 
party-pooper massive.
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Chel-C Faith" <chelcfaith@defsf.com>
To: "Chris Jackson" <cjax@sbcglobal.net>
Cc: <shawn@alterior.net>; "SFRaves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, February 21, 2005 4:43 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Reviews: DJ Hell, Alien Autopsy, Dirty, and another 
brief rant


>I think it's not just the techno DJs that have no balls, but the listeners
> too.  I often see people leave the dancefloor in droves when a DJ pulls
> out a different style. No wonder newer techno DJs are afraid to be
> adventurous!  We all say that we want variety, but when it's given to us
> we won't accept it.  This obsessive subgenre loyalty could be the downfall
> of the techno scene, in my opinion.
>
> I would love to see both techno DJs and techno ravers open up to more
> styles.... But alas, I can't force people to like music they don't like.
>
> It seems there has been a little surge of interest in techno lately.  If
> we all drop the cliquey "I only like my kind of techno" thing and come
> together for once, new people might actually take interest and help our
> scene to grow.  If there is a renewed interest in techno and new blood
> coming into the scene, more and hopefully better parties will pop up, good
> techno DJs will be getting more gigs, and we will all be complaining less.
> Wait.... no.. this is SFR I'm talking about here... we live for
> complaining.
>
> Variety in techno, unity under techno, a greater sense of community, and a
> welcoming attitude towards newcomers.... That's what I'd like to see
> happen this year.  Maybe I'm idealistic.
>
> Love Chelsea
>
>

>> > events, people have
>> > been happiest when we've given them straight-up hard
>> > techno.  The times
>> > we've tried to branch out an explore different sides
>> > of techno were not
>> > exactly our most successful events.  When we threw
>> > Robot Feelings, a
>> > techno and electro party at Cellspace last year, the
>> > Droid Behavior guys
>> > who came up for the party complained that we weren't
>> > "techno enough".  I
>> > want to do parties the way I like them, but I want
>> > to make the people who
>> > attend happy too.  This may be an impossibility, as
>> > we're not quite
>> > "techno enough" for techno kids I guess.
>> >
>> > Alien Autopsy satisfied all the usual techno party
>> > requirements.  Dark;
>> > check. Hard; check. Spooky and evil; check. Anoraks;
>> > well, I didn't see
>> > any, but I'm sure there must have been an anorak or
>> > two being worn there
>> > somewhere.  And I did notice a few bald guys.  Maybe
>> > techno ravers don't
>> > want their party formula to be messed with.  It
>> > seems to me that this is
>> > how they like it.  There was no question of this
>> > party not being "techno
>> > enough".  It had all the bases covered, and people
>> > loved it.
>> >
>> > There are so many different facets of the SF techno
>> > scene, lots of little
>> > micro-scenes. I would love to see the scene become
>> > more united, but the
>> > problem with techno snobs is that they get so into
>> > their thing that they
>> > have a hard time looking beyond their own subgenre
>> > oriented microscene.
>> >
>> > Maybe this is a bad analogy, but I see it like
>> > this--  The Democratic
>> > party has become increasingly weak because of all
>> > the squabbling and
>> > divisions within the party, whereas the Republican
>> > party is much more
>> > united and unfortunately has become a lot stronger
>> > than the Democrats
>> > because of their unity and passion.  Despite the
>> > lack of quality in the
>> > trance scene, the enthusiasm and unity found in the
>> > candy kid world has
>> > kept the trance scene alive and strong long after
>> > we've all declared it
>> > dead several times. SF's techno scene, like the
>> > Democrats, will never be
>> > strong if we continue to be divided along sub-genre
>> > lines.  Furthermore,
>> > your average techno fan now, after seeing their
>> > music be ignored by most
>> > rave promoters and regularly get confused with
>> > trance, has become jaded
>> > and apathetic.  If we are divided, jaded, and
>> > apathetic, techno will be
>> > going nowhere fast!

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] another brief rant

one suggestion:

support mixed genre parties!  support DJs and crews that you know bring a 
diversity of sounds.

or better yet, start throwing parties!  if that scares the shit out of you, 
join an existing crew that is already throwing parties.  start small.  
promote.  invite folks you think would enjoy the sounds you enjoy.  smile 
and laugh and scream and throw your hands in the air when you are at a party 
and the music moves you.

if you want change, make change.  do something.  if you told me one year ago 
that Evil Breaks would be doing what we are doing now...i'd have rolled my 
eyes and shaken my head.  but in one year's time we pushed and pushed and 
pushed and put ourselves on the line and played and played and played and 
promoted and networked and pushed and pushed and pushed until we were on the 
verge of emotional breakdowns and couldnt pay our bills and then we pushed 
some more and we kept playing and playing and playing.  are we perfect?  no. 
  are we fantastic DJs.  no.  are we really any different than anyone on 
this list?  no.  but we wanted more breaks parties and we wanted to hear 
more breaks and we wanted things to be fun and we wanted everyone who came 
to our parties to enjoy themselves.

we still got a lot to work on.  but we're working on it.

--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

March 4th:  ModILLfied @ Shadow Lounge
March 5th:  Clandestine in SF
March 11th:  Urbanology
March 19th:  Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary Party
April 14th:  Turntablaze Radio on 102.5FM
April 29th:  Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty

>From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
>To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] another brief rant
>Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 16:28:00 -0800
>
>quoth Chel-C Faith:
> > I do agree with you on the lack of diversity in the techno scene right
> > now, and I've thought about this a lot....
>
>We both have. And I don't know what the next step is because I still
>haven't been able to figure out what the fuck people *want* from me, or
>the "scene", or techno in general. I'm not entirely sure that the kids
>want just really hard techno. The cynic in me assumes that most of those
>kids on Friday night were totally fucked up on drugs, and I'm just not
>interested in music that only sounds good when I'm high. But the techno
>parties at (mostly lame) clubs in SF haven't really been doing it for me
>either. I don't dance at raves because the music doesn't make me, and I
>can't dance at the Rx because they don't have a fucking license and the
>sound sucks to begin with. I honestly think people would get down to the
>stuff I hear at little techno events if it were played in a grungy old
>warehouse on a big underground soundsystem.
>
>I know, I'm not the typical raver. I don't go to parties to get high; I
>go to hear good music in good company. I'm not a typical techno geek
>either: I started out DJ'ing DnB and house, so I appreciate the aspects
>of "funk" and "jack" that make some electronic music particularly
>danceable. The really hard techno lacks sufficient qualities of both,
>and as I've said time and time again I think the popularity of that
>style has soiled the word "techno" for the rest of us. There's so much
>more to it than over-compressed grinding machine sound loops. Maybe I'm
>just not "hardcore" enough to give people the impression that I like
>"techno"?
>
>I've seen this all happen with industrial/EBM already, as musicality was
>slowly edged out by, well, edginess for its own sake. I look back on
>when I was a teenager first discovering IDM, and it saddens me because I
>fear that the kids going to today's parties won't be exposed to anything
>even remotely "progressive" or "interesting". I'm not saying we should
>be pushing Aphex Twin on the kids (although I am looking forward to
>playing some of the new Analord records on a big 'ol soundsystem), but I
>think we owe it to them to give them some variety, some choice.
>
>Exposure under the right circumstances is what made me fall in love with
>so much of the music I listen to today, and maybe that's why hard techno
>is so popular right now: kids go to a party because their friends are
>going to be there, they get high, and they associate that barrage of
>distorted kick drums with a good time. I just wish we could supplement
>the really hard stuff with something more interesting or imaginative. If
>the kids don't demand any variety though, nothing's going to change.
>
>So, fellow partygoers: DEMAND VARIETY. BOYCOTT MONO-STYLISTIC PARTIES.
>EXPAND YOUR HORIZONS WITH MUSIC YOU'VE NEVER HEARD BEFORE.
>
>That is all,
>--
>shawn allen
>   mailto://shawn@alterior.net
>   phone://+1.415.577.3961
>   http://alterior.net
>   aim://shawnpallen
>
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

>>Frank Broughton the "costume" of Northern soul was: "...high-waisted 
>>pleated trousers with wide flapping legs known as 'Brummie bags,' bowling 
>>shirts, singlets, or Ben Shermans, white socks, flat leather soled shoes, 
>>and an Adidas or Gola sports bag..."  I don't think any of those things 
>>are Anorak's.  Incidentally I am not entirely sure what the word Anorak

>>>>> >been happiest when we've given them straight-up hard techno.  The 
>>>>> >times

>>>>> >not
